movie_review_blurb: 30 Days of Night manages to do for the vampire genre what 28 Days Later did for the zombie flick: give age-old monsters a modern-day makeover.

Plays like an after-school TV special. Shot after school. At the gym.
[Hart] gives Ride just enough buoyancy to keep it afloat, despite a story that would sink most performances.
When the story gets stale, the movie inserts a "nuts" pun or, worse, resorts to a gas or burp joke. It doesn't work the first time, nor the fifth.

The story is nothing short of miraculous.

Musters enough laughs to be passable, if not memorable. And that's thanks to Morgan Freeman's showmanship.
Not only stands as the best installment (by bounds) of Johnny Knoxville's hidden-camera franchise; it's one of the sharpest comedies of the year.
Schwarzenegger seems to be the only one here who correctly takes the film as a lark.

Film lovers will see how Cameron not only came up with ideas like The Abyss and Titanic, but how his drive turns obsession into commercial movies, usually very profitable ones.

A heartfelt if heavy-handed sermon about chasing dreams, forgiving sins and honoring Woody Allen.
Rage is so full of cliché, convention and just plain odd narrative choices that it can't get out of its own way.
Even horror neophytes won't be spooked by a film that looks as if it were shot with a smartphone and an Itty Bitty Booklight.
A film that's less than half as funny as its predecessor, and a sliver as clever as the original.
The Transformers are brilliant, brave, world-conquering space travelers. Time to morph into something entertaining.
Though some characters go underdeveloped, Hellion marks one of Hollywood's most realistic examinations of rural high school angst since Friday Night Lights, another teen drama set in Texas.
A dark romantic comedy that has plenty of the first, a little of the second and none of third.
Has enough nods to classic capers to make for effective pulp fiction - and revive Don Johnson's career.

movie_review_blurb: There isn't a franchise around that matches the kids' moves in the Step Up series. We just need a better reason to dance along.

movie_review_blurb: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them is a fun treat for Harry Potter fans, especially when the CGI creatures grace the screen.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Chloë Grace Moretz and some cool alien destruction set the film apart from other young adult novel adaptations.
While fans of the books should be satisfied, it may only serve as mild entertainment to general movie audiences.
Has the power to make audiences think and potentially change safety in industry for the better.
Impressive stop-motion animation, a fun voice cast, and a story that will draw in people, but a slow pace and dreamy tone may lull audiences to sleep.
A fantastic cast, lighthearted tone, and fun soundtrack make Suicide Squad one of the most entertaining films of 2016.
Finding Dory has some excellent animation, impressive 3D effects, and fun new characters.
It's possible to enjoy this film if you turn off your brain and don't overanalyze it.
While it's a disappointment compared to a lot of other animated films, it's not entirely bad.
Cool action, a strong performance by Ben Affleck, and Gal Gadot as Wonder Woman make Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice worth checking out on the big screen.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's the weakest of the three films, but hopefully it tees up the fourth film for a big finish.

Deadpool fans and comic fans should love this movie.
It's not worth shelling out money for in theaters.
Denzel Washington and Chris Pratt make an entertaining pair, but The Magnificent Seven doesn't bring anything new to the genre.
This Means War makes a decent date movie, but it doesn't have much to offer beyond the charm of Witherspoon, Hardy, and Pine.
Hugh Jackman, Anne Hathaway and the excellent cast make "Les Misérables" an enjoyable film even for people that aren't fans of musicals.
Fun songs, great humor, and a lot of entertaining cameos make The Muppets a fun movie for both adults and children. It's a good revitalization of the Muppets franchise.
Spider-Man 2 is one of the best comic movies ever made.
What's interesting about Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban is that it is both darker and funnier at the same time than the earlier films.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Shrek 2 is a fun film that the whole family can enjoy. I think the adults may enjoy it even more than the kids.
Epic battles are the main draw of Troy, but the excellent cast help keep things interesting.
I think it's worth checking out on the big screen if you're even slightly interested. I think seeing it with an audience may help.
Whether you enjoy the film or not, it is undeniably something that will generate good discussion and that makes it worth checking out.
If you saw Kill Bill Vol. 1, then Kill Bill Vol. 2 is required viewing. However, I don't think you'll find it as unique a movie-going experience as its predecessor.

Fantastic animation, a great cast, and hilarious laughs make Finding Nemo a must see movie for the summer.
Great music from Phil Collins and a couple of familiar moose make Brother Bear an animated film worth checking out with the whole family.
Both kids and adults will thoroughly enjoy this movie. It's a lot of fun and well worth checking out. I highly recommend checking it out on the big screen.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: First off, the movie looks fantastic. The sets are amazing and the effects are wonderful.

movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Anchorman is an absurd, stupid comedy that's a lot of fun and well worth checking out at the theater with friends.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Bad Boys II' has all the elements of a great popcorn flick, but not even the wonderful chemistry between Smith and Lawrence can save the film from gore, a confusing plot, a long running time, and slow motion scenes of people looking cool.
Overall the movie is a fun ride and an interesting tale about the life of one of America's greatest con men.
While it wasn't a movie I'd rush out to see on my own, it didn't bore me either.
My recommendation? Skip this movie and buy the soundtrack instead.
I highly recommend you check this out on the big screen.
A good sequel and should please all the Potter fans who made the first film a blockbuster.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: I would not recommend this movie for even renting. Flee while you can.
It's not first rate horror, but it gets the job done.
After a great opening that pulled me into the story, the movie quickly self-destructed into predictability.

A fun action adventure and a cool new entry to the spy movie genre.
Shyamalan definitely keeps his title as the master of suspense with Signs. He's able to take the simplest everyday things and scare the crap out of you with them.
This film is fun for kids and tolerable for adults.
Out of all the sub movies ever made, this is one of the better ones.
If you're looking for a decent action flick, Timeline should fit the bill.

movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Adults will pretty much have to check their brains in at the door, sit back, and enjoy the popcorn and snacks.

If you liked the first Fantastic Four film, you'll probably enjoy the sequel even more.

Mohammad Assaf's (Tawfeek Barhom) quest to become the next Arab Idol plays out much in the same manner as the routine biographical backstory segment one expects to find on the talent contest just prior to a contestant taking to the stage.
Not unlike Ali MacGraw in the equally apocryphal Love Story, the closer our heroine inches toward death's door, the more physically attractive she becomes. Phooey!
Had the filmmakers slathered as much mascara on their characters' eyelids as they did stoking the plot with sentiment, the cast would have spent the last third of the picture bumping into things.
You may not recognize the name going in, but after spending 82 minutes watching director Victor Kanefsky cast a heartfelt lens in Cenedella's direction, you'll never forget him.

Shooting on actual locations and with a cast of nonprofessional actors, writer-director Jacques Audiard keeps the neorealism pumping until a third act concession to conventionality (and vigilantism) leads it in the direction of Cannon Pictures.
Yes, it's predictable. Of course, it follows a formula. But damn if this isn't Guzman's show.
Fantasy fulfillment for those wondering what would happen if Ma & Pa Kettle hauled Mr. Ed to Del Mar and pulled up a stall adjacent to the high-hatted muckety mucks.
No better than what you'd expect to find on American Idol and The Voice, both of which are a lot more upfront in their cynicism.
So compelling is Kerslake's handling of the material that by the time it was over, I felt as though I had lost a friend.
movie_title: As I AM: The Life and Times of DJ AM (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Burton had a chance to make a powerful statement on the struggle for a woman to achieve artistic recognition and instead settled for another childlike fairy tale.
You're bound to leave hungry.

Secondary characters - a gruff but loveable manager who never expected his first champion was going to be a girl, and a brief romantic subplot involving her sparring partner - help to take some of the edge off.
It's only outside the workplace, on the streets of New York ca. 1929 or paying a visit to a small blues bar for an impromptu rendition of "Flow Gently Sweet Afton," that the film comes to life.

With all the grace and symmetry of a peacock fanning its tail, director Gabriel Mascaro reveals his hand in quixotic blasts of expressionistic color, graphic sensuality, and a few things we've never before seen on film...
Unoriginal behavior such as this should be shunned, not encouraged.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Audiences softened by Hollywood cynicism are bound to be confounded by filmmaker Hirokazu Koreeda's (After Life, Like Father, Like Son) gentle, upbeat tone.
Jarmusch's use of stock footage and snippets of old movies provides perfect backup for the personification of punk nihilism.
It starts well, but the deadpan humor quickly runs out of gas.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully filmed and performed - the opening sequence using mirrors and doorframes to fuse the torsos of two characters to form a whole - is stunning, but in the end, the overall concept left me in the dark.
A film school thesis project that somehow found its way into general release.
As drama, it's predictable, simplistic, exploitative, and otherwise wholly unredeemed.
First-time director Sophie Goodhart coaxes a grown-up performance out of Kroll, and Scott's smarmy contentiousness has never been put to better use.
One's appreciation of this regulation cable biodoc hinges on one's interest in the subject matter, not the medium.

It's the ever-spellbinding Timothy Spall who will make audiences squirm. His knotty-pouted advocate for the myth of the six million displays all the seductiveness and in-built logic of a pedophile luring a kindergartner into the back seat of a Buick.
The end ultimately justifies the means; whether viewers will want to stick it out is another thing.
The DVD box should warn prospective buyers that its contents could cause drowsiness.
Berg's relaxed handling of small talk among the crew members makes the set-up a delight to watch, while the ensuing disasters are convincing enough to give multiplex armrests a gripping workout.
Forget about the incongruous use of movie posters; the mugging these nerdy CIA agents display would give Milton Berle cause for alarm.
The film is adapted from a stage play, and it shows in every frame.

Watching Lyonne smoke and drink the trimesters away reminds one just how much her absence from the big screen has been missed. She's pretty much the whole show until the arrival of Meg Tilly whose performance...ranks as one of the year's finest.
Love is blind, but the audience isn't, and why these future contestants on The Jerry Springer Show stay together is anyone's guess, particularly Maïwenn's.

Shoring together small moments from the lives of believable characters, in a manner free of special effects and fluky plotting, and with the same dramatic and visual gusto one would apply to an epic is what independent filmmaking should be all about.
Hanks's Sullenberger is by far Eastwood's most untarnished standard-bearer to date. Not even Nelson Mandela came off looking this good.
[Director] Cianfrance has one chance to lighten the load, to unleash a little visual magic to boost the narrative contrivance, and all he can summon are handheld shots of crashing foam.
Panic Room meets Wait Until Dark in this pitiless, uncommonly serviceable horror thriller.
Vincent descends on his subject like an angel of mercy, casting light on the disenfranchised denizens that found in the arcade a home away from home.
Though it's based on Piotr Rowicki's play Clinging, director Marcin Wrona's spirited staging keeps it from ever dissolving into canned theater.
King Hu's masterwork is guaranteed to out-Marvel any of the major blockbusters on this summer's release schedule.
Before Mr. T and Steven Seagal, there was Evel Knievel. For those who remember these simple, simpler-minded times, Being Evel is a sure bet.
Bateman and Nicole Kidman, too old to convincingly pull off this sibling pair, would have fared better as the parents.
The mystery-movie-of-the-week premise is buoyed by the evenly detailed performances from the four female leads

Boyle, known best for a string of winning romantic comedies (Surrogate Valentine, Daylight Savings) now finds himself making a successful leap to the dark side with this decidedly "hard-Boyled" genre picture.
This is the comedy surprise of the year.
At the very least, Craig is an unlikable character that Lloyd and Reisberg still manage to make compelling, even though there's not a moment in the film that found me squarely rooted in his corner.
The cast helps to keep things moving -- particularly the hilarious interplay between Arkin and Goodman. And is it me, or should Bryan Cranston be in every film released?
In its own saintly manner, it's as exploitative as anything critics accused Django Unchained of being, minus Tarantino's eye for idiosyncrasy and sense of humor.
There are many words to describe Interstellar. Entertainment isn't one of them.
Hats off to any film that tries (and succeeds) at presenting challenging, off-putting characters from whose palms I'm reluctantly persuaded to eat.
As a director, Chris Rock makes a fine stand-up comic.

Melissa McCarthy keeping pace in foot chases with actors who spend the better portion of their lives in a gym is about as funny as it gets, unless you count the antonymous editing of the action sequences.
Hardy makes for a compelling psychological tour guide, utilizing much more than his right foot to add forward momentum.
Don't adjust your set: the film is (strikingly) photographed in Bergman-esque shades of gray-and-white.
A gritty urban comedy noir, a scathing, Network-worthy disembowelment of television newsgatherers that will leave you craving a shower.
Rise of the Planet of the Apes alone justified the advent of CGI. With it comes a worthy successor.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Fueled by implausibility, and for a good portion of the ride much better for it, Bong-Joon Ho's Snowpiercer posits a nonstop, Earth-encircling train containing the microcosmic survivors of a society killed off by a global warming-induced deep freeze.

Linklater's casual hand at storytelling, dealing out reel after reel of naggingly forthright enlightenment, turns this simple tale of a mother trying to do her best into something worth every second of the time it took to produce.
This witty, handsomely appointed 3-D animated feature is the most delightful Santa biopic since Edmund Gwenn donned the fat suit.
Frozen is a glacially stiff, perpetually unamusing animated musical with a talk-singing score that will leave one pining for the lifeless soundtrack to The Princess and the Frog.
First time director Jill D'Agnenica and her outstanding, albeit unheard-of cast skillfully skirt the pitfalls inherent in the Lifetime Channel material.
The trailer for The Conjuring is scarier than most horror features of recent vintage, and the feature makes good on the promise.
This is the sharpest, most reasonable tale of espionage and intrigue since John Boorman's Tailor of Panama.

Bullying, poverty, closeted sexuality, drug abuse, and racial strife combine to form an overworked agenda of cultural woes that's more concerned with rubber-stamping issues than telling an original story.
The suffocating level of redundancy on display kneecaps any legitimate chance the film had at embracing social satire.
A powerhouse Iranian documentary.
Countless shots of the Christ the Redeemer statue notwithstanding, for all we're told about the titular location, they might just as well spread the love in Jersey.
movie_title: Rio, I Love You (Rio, Eu Te Amo) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A culture-clash comedy at once so-bad-it's-good and so-good-it's-bad that it kept me laughing throughout.
Credit star Michelle Chen for playing it with a straight face. Her performance alone prevents this from fully degenerating into the Lindsay Lohan vehicle it otherwise is.
It takes a while for the solid premise to unravel...and for the better portion of its running time Green Room functions as a highly effective thriller.
Is it me, or is the big climactic reveal not really worth all the hubbub?
John Carney (Begin Again) once again tries to reheat a Once soufflé and instead serves up a flat, cheerily antiseptic period musical.
John Carroll Lynch shares credit with a superb ensemble, but it's his halcyon turn as a pitiable demon that unifies the action.
When it comes to overstrung, antisocial characters, Jake Gyllenhaal sure knows how to pick (and breathe new life into) them.
Given the cultural boundaries, there is much in the film that we may never fully grasp, but the less we're told, the more were sucked in by the film's hypnotic, ever-expanding aura of mystery.
There is no actor currently at work capable of embodying the complexity of this character like Plummer.
What was it about this cramped, underdeveloped parlor drama -- the majority of which takes place on one set -- that caused Tarantino to think 70mm?
You won't have a merrier time at the movies this holiday season.
An English-language remake of Juan José Campanella's far superior Argentinian thriller.
What eventually helps to separate it from the rest, other than a war-torn backdrop, is director Ali F. Mostafa's refusal to make any of the trio all that likeable.
Taxi is easily the director's most accessible work to date.
See it now, if you must, because the chances of a post-Oscar celebratory reissue are looking slim.
If Atonement, Wright's neatest work to date, is a master class on CGI restraint, Pan's densely pixielated final battle is busy to the point of indecipherability.
Handsomely shot by Damian Garcia in full-frame black-and-white, Güeros is at times both painfully arty and arbitrarily plotted.
The Gift chillingly illustrates what happens when fate reunites a class bully (Jason Bateman) with his prize victim, Gordo (Edgerton).
Killing focused on the surreal reenactment of mass genocide by its elderly perpetrators. Silence makes it personal.
With a 90-minute running time, Unexpected would fit comfortably, with room for commercial breaks, in a two-hour network time slot. How did it ever find a theatrical release?
An equitable, beautifully crafted document about a pair of married but emotionally ever-changing dance partners.
You'll need a shield to help deflect all the irony director Antonio Campos and screenwriter Craig Shilowich throw before the camera.

Director Huseyin Karabey and cinematographer Anne Misselwitz know how to frame landscapes, but it's the night exteriors of silhouetted windows lit from inside that add to the film's tight-knit feelings of a society undivided.
Doubling down as director and cinematographer, Craig Atkinson proves worthy at both assignments.

For most of its running time, director and co-writer Joachim Lafosse gives the impression that he's drilled a hole into the side of a married couple's home in order to afford audiences an unmediated, worm's eye view of their gradual dissolution.
Be prepared for what will prove to be far and away the longest 83 minutes you'll spend watching a movie this year.
The four lead performances keep what might have been a contrived comedy of errors on an even keel.
movie_title: Tales Of An Immoral Couple (La Vida Inmoral De La Pareja Ideal) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The performances are all first-rate - particularly Bridget Everett as Macdonald's haggard mother - but first time writer-director Geremy Jasper makes more bad choices than his misguided characters here.
Be it divine intervention or just pure dumb luck, Fancher never lost his foothold on the fringes of cinema. He lived his life as if it was a movie waiting to be made.
The major culprit in the picture is screenwriter Allan Loeb (Here Comes the Boom, Collateral Beauty) a once and future Happy Madison gagman who wants nothing more than to be the next Woody Allen.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Deneuve has made a career out of playing these types of eccentric arch-kooks; she could act the role in her sleep.
The curious are welcome, but this one fits snugly in the category of "You Don't Have to Be Jewish, But..."
In the very least, Hal Needham's Smokey and the Bandit films displayed a fair amount of affection amid the hamming for their shit-kicking rubes.
Those expecting the brand of hefty satire found in Andò's last film, Long Live Liberty, will have to wait.
Dark, dysfunctional, and filled with blinding hope, this is one glass house that's difficult to throw stones at.
Call it an exercise in staring at a screen for two hours that couldn't have ended soon enough.
Made with the basest of intentions and aimed at the lowest form of humanity there is, let this be the first and last feature from Damien Power.
Honestly, you'd be better off finding the MGM version from 1943.
movie_title: Marie Curie: The Courage of Knowledge (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The press notes call it "a crowd-pleaser at the Sundance Film Festival," but don't expect this Pop Aye to be "strong to the finnich."
It puts one in the mind to make a meme: Hitler reacts to Oliver Hirschbiegel's prosaic flashback transitions.
Is there anything more gratifying than a sweepingly downcast story told in a uniquely exhilarating manner?

Around the 77-minute mark, the film appears to reach its logical conclusion, and then proceeds to hit the audience with another satisfying 10 minutes of twists. The real delight comes in watching Baye play mouse to Devos' cat.
With precious cargo like Spall and Meaney to transport, even Freddie Highmore behind the wheel - and the occasional narrative detour - didn't give sufficient cause to incite road rage.
Director Virzi has made moves that are worth your time: Caterina in the Big City, My Name is Tanino. This isn't one of them.
Not awful, just uninspired.
What we have here is less an exploration of personal artistry than an entry-level history lesson.
movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The sole fresh twist, one that should have been more than enough to drive the show - one friend dedicating his life to exonerating the other - is repeatedly undermined by their unequal presentation.
Let's call this what it is: a fetishistic After-School Special complete with closeups of trimmed pubes and squeaky-clean sphincters.
While I'm generally a sucker for imaginative art direction, the Technicolor gargle of overflorid hues on display here barely sticks to the screen, let alone to the memory.

It is that rare commodity in today's superhero-driven cinema, and unless I'm forgetting something, one has to go back as far as Igby Goes Down to find an honest, brave, and bracingly comic look at adolescence such as this.
The pun-fueled dialogue is a perfect match for the visual ugliness.
Think High Noon set in Kinshasa and backed by a Congolese beat.
Streep is superb. What else is new?
[Robbie] transforms what could easily have been just another grotesquerie in a grand guignol into a fully rounded, albeit unsympathetic, character.
One couldn't help but think of the obvious, heavy-handed messaging we'd be spared if all directors followed Kaurismäki's expert smuggling techniques.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "What he does with cards, a magician can't do," says [Turner's] son and stage manager Asa Spades Turner. Director Luke Korem's documentary proves the lad's point.
Biggest takeaway? Nye's previous mission of making science accessible to children is nothing compared to the challenge in convincing adults of the perils of climate change.
A must for fans of upstanding citizenry.

The pair makes an oddly compelling Harold and Maude coupling, touring the countryside in a minibus-cum-box camera and honoring the locals by turning the facades of buildings into ephemeral open-air portrait galleries.
Keep moving, folks; there's nothing here you haven't seen done better a hundred times before.
As is the case with almost all anthology pictures this size, two or three segments stand out.
movie_title: Susan Hero (Lost in New Mexico: The Strange Tale of Susan Hero) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Recreations of the master's past are laughably bad: a numbing state of self-congratulatory and overly theatrical theatricality appears to have stricken all participants. So why was I never bored?
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If it's a quality film about surfing you crave, track down John Milius' Big Wednesday.
movie_title: Take Every Wave: The Life of Laird Hamilton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A film comprised of first-rate actors, each given the opportunity to spin a yarn or two.
When it comes to chronicling their accomplishments on film, all they have to show for themselves is 90 flashy minutes' worth of rockumentary clichés.
The romance is forced and phony - after only two weeks together, the two are behaving like an old married couple.
All that's expected from the leads is that they put forth a competent degree of mimicry; the secondary characters, meanwhile, are left with little to do but flounder.

The last thing one expected was for the Belgian Dardenne brothers to dote on a murder mystery, particularly one involving a medico turned amateur sleuth that's fraught with coincidence like so much of what's already out there.
Maybe one temple of learning will inspire a visit to another: see the movie, then pop into your local biblioteca.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The one-joke soon wears thin, and nothing - particularly the labor-saving animation and hideous-to-behold character design - can keep Underpants from stinking.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Strictly for those with a strong stomach and a decidedly bent outlook.
J.P. Passi's hand-held black-and-white cinematography cries out for big-screen viewing.
movie_title: The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki (Hymyilevä mies) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Lower what little expectation you have going in and you'll still be disappointed.
Who needs voiceovers when a director's camera has this much to say?
Dignified to the point of absurdity, this fact-based dud never gets off the ground, thanks to director Vincent Perez's failure to create - let alone maintain - any level of suspense.
Sure enough, Andy Kaufman's prankster and premeditatedly abrasive second-self was the impetus behind this epic one-joke comedy from German writer-director Maren Ade.
A filmmaker telling his story in pictures and the limitlessness of control he brings to his art. What more can one ask of cinema?
Robrecht Heyvaert's brooding nighttime cinematography is the film's one saving grace.
The film is well worth a look, if just for the performances; just know going in that director Mills calls upon his cast and script to do most of the heavy lifting.

Alas, Andrea Berloff's screenplay has more holes than a trawlerman's net, none bigger than a gut-cut Foxx nursing a gaping wound for two-thirds of the picture while still managing to dodge bullets and roll with the punches.
Audiences could do (and have done) a lot worse than this genial throwback to a time when Kurt Russell was Disney's #1 living, breathing attraction.
The deck (and performance) stacked as they are - the guy is even determined to put an end to his illiteracy - rookie writer-director Joshua Locy makes it difficult to dislike the hapless jamoke.
As the sweltering Colombian rainforest becomes the personification of a threatening norm, Torres's growing anxiety translates to audience tension.
The fresh-faced cast and first-time director Jackson Stewart give it their best, but once the tape enters the machine, all bets are off.
This is one crowd-pleaser worth getting behind.
Together [director Larrain and star Portman] trap the character on film, like a rose frozen in a block of ice.
Even a third act demolition derby tribute to The Blues Brothers can't revitalize this stiff.
Following a pair of sojourns to the adorable Marigold Hotel, John Madden (Shakespeare in Love) takes a giant step forward with this perfectly timed tale of how to draw and quarter a lobbyist.
Most episodes of The Twilight Zone run 30 minutes, and there's barely enough material here to justify a feature, but Ezban makes it work.
If you can buy into the premise, good luck to you. I didn't.
There might have been more to say about juxtaposing dark laughs against a sunny backdrop, were it not for the director's insistence at setting his dial on fluff.
movie_title: Kiki, Love to Love (Kiki, el amor se hace) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately the identity of the masked attacker is moot: in [director] Verhoeven's eyes every man is capable of rape.
The shift from family drama to djinn game is so subtle as to be barely perceived
A pair of solemn, unostentatious performances by Ruth Negga and Joel Edgerton help to raise the bar just slightly higher than the one set by a benignly routine Lifetime movie.
Using never-before-seen footage and interviews, Bar-Lev's warts-and-all approach fits a band that backed into fame in spite of itself.
movie_title: Long Strange Trip: The Untold Story of The Grateful Dead (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A biographical, cinematic corollary of Al Gore's canned Learning Annex lecture, Luc Jacquet's Antarctica condenses 22 polar missions - all told, they consumed ten years of Lorius's life - into one visually breathtaking documentary.
movie_title: Antarctica: Ice & Sky (La glace et le ciel) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For two-thirds of its running time, attention must be paid to an exquisitely realized suspense-thriller. It isn't until Farhadi borrows a calculable cup of revenge from the Death Wish cookbook that his soufflé begins to flatten.
I'm not calling for Marvin the Martian to lead a parade of pink elephants down Main Street, but what's the point of animating if the end goal is to simply trace over an ABC Afterschool Special?

The snail's-pace horizontal pans, under-the-flight-path score, and other arthouse affectations had collided with the overall unlikeability of the major characters violently enough to make me consider jumping ship.

Much of the poop humor is surprisingly fresh and funny, as in the scene where only a shower curtain separates an enormous man bent on relieving himself and the hidden, breath-holding boy he's been chasing. You know, if you go for that sort of thing.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The downfall isn't as satisfying as the setup, and a sudden burst of energy associated with the introduction of cocaine actually acts to slow things down, but it's worth seeing for the performances.

Is there a more rewarding way of spending 90 minutes than watching Lynch putter, reminisce, and work on a sculpture? Maybe, but you'd need to give Lynch the budget to produce another feature to find out.
Potential game-changing touch: this time, it's the politician and not his middle-class brother who is in favor of exposing the truth.

Trying hard to play against expectations, writer-director Michael O'Shea casts a black teenager in the lead role of an urban vampire film. It's a decision that ultimately works in the film's favor, but only up to a point.

Cornfed curse words fuel a script that doesn't amount to much more than a hateful snatch of Tarantino's set-bound posturing, spiked with a blend of pre-Madonna, semi-intelligible Guy Ritchie oddballs.
Not a patch on its conceptually oriented precursor Exit Through the Gift Shop, so long as the subject of filmmaking is avoided, this should spark lively debate on the drive home.
Not your typical cancer drama anchored in grief, instead a clear-sighted journey that makes demands on one's emotions in the most unlikely ways.
[Director] Rosenstein's greatest achievement is his recognition of the massive efforts put forth by Wolfson, lawyer and civil rights advocate Mary Bonauto, and many others.

A sprawling, '60s-style epic with just enough political intrigue to prop up the occasionally wobbly romantic triangle formed by Oscar Isaac, Charlotte Le Bon, and an uncharacteristically ill-fitting Christian Bale.
A surprisingly better-than-average sports biopic with standout performances.
A nod to politically correct species reassignment surgery livens the third act, but the film eventually sinks under the weight of its own silly excess.
The perhaps too-beautifully manicured black-and-white 'Scope cinematography and Paula Beer's bravura turn as the German girl who got left behind make it worth your while.
A bland departure from the director's normally madcap norm.
The occasionally retired Ms. MacLaine is ever quick with a retort, but this is one lead-footed comeback we all could have done without.
A ballsy debut by [writer-director-star] Avedisian and one that's not to be missed.
Deutch's naturalistic performance grounds the various layers of the story in a manner that keeps it from becoming either boring or wildly unrealistic.

Screenwriter Guy Hibbert and Asante pull off a precision balancing act, illuminating the intensity of the love the couple shared and never once allowing their romance to take a back seat to the issues.
Two out of four is not a bad average, particularly when the half in question aren't pestiferous enough to warrant a ruckus. Fans of this sort of thing won't go hungry.
If you're in the mood for a monster movie, revenge-tinged romance, social satire, or simply a good time at the multiplex, consider Colossal entertainment.
The documentary is an enlightening journey to a dark corner of contemporary punk's dank little basement.
Forget what you think you know about horror. This one's a game-changer.
By far the best elements are the regular flashbacks, which showcase the crazy comic book vibe at its best and have some truly spectacular Charlie's Angels-style moments.
Some of the most fiercely inventive and twisted trap-based bloodletting we've had in ages.
Despite a story that flatlines too often and a last second twist that comes too late, this is still a nice first effort from Biehn who clearly has more to give us.
Right from the start there's a cheeky sense of Hammer coming into the 21st century.
After the shock tactics of Shivers, Cronenberg's next venture into body horror is more subdued, but holds up surprisingly well.
H.P. Lovecraft's From Beyond gets a 21st century revamp in Blair Erickson's solid first feature.
Much of it is heartbreaking but there's an undeniable warmth and sensitivity to Hanák's approach.
movie_title: Obrazy starého sveta, (Pictures of the Old World) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Essential viewing for anyone with an interest in the genre, or who wants to see Pam Grier at her very best.
The kids will like its simplicity and manic motion, but if you want more than that, you won't find it here.
movie_title: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The visual daring and pure imagination of every image leave it as an elegiac farewell to an era of Italian cinema; and Sutherland's performance is the most astonishing piece of screen acting since Brando's in Last Tango in Paris.
It's always fascinating to watch; the thrills and spills are so classy and fast that the movie becomes in effect what horror movies seemed like when you were too young to get in to see them.
The movie could be trying to say that for some people religion is an escape from their sexuality, but it seems unlikely.
Dumb and Dumber To is exactly the Dumb and Dumber sequel that we deserve.
The Homesman, Tommy Lee Jones's grim yet witty feminist western, features a terrific star turn from Hilary Swank.

As terrific as that first act is and as mostly entertaining as what follows is, Hunger Games: Catching Fire part I is half of a single story and mostly concerned with setting up however the series ends.
That it works is a testament to its strong performances and a real sense of empathy toward both sides of the featured relationship.

John Wick features a terrific movie star turn by Keanu Reeves along with superb action sequences and robust/creative world-building that puts the would-be "Let's make a Marvel-style expanded universe" copycats to shame.
Tadashi's school pals are an absolute blast to hang out with, and I frankly would have almost preferred a film about the Hiro, his brother, and the gang trying to win a science fair.
Interstellar is not quite a success. I can't insult those involved by grading on an admiration-based curve.
Foxcatcher is a supremely well-acted and well-constructed motion picture with too little going on and too little at its core.

Do I think The Imitation Game is among the year's best films? Absolutely not, but that should not be held against the film that is, warts and all, an intelligent and mostly entertaining historical drama.
Wild is more than just Reese Witherspoon's strong lead performance, and it's good enough to stand tall even absent its role in the Oscar race.
There is a richness and a subtle sadness to the core relationship between Anna and Elsa.
It is the second Angelina Jolie directorial effort that I can admire even if I cannot recommend.
To be absolutely fair, even if Exodus were cast with 100% racial/ethnic authenticity, it would still be a terrible film.
If The Nightmare Before Christmas is the go-to animated feature for Halloween and/or Christmas, then The Book of Life has a lock on Día De Los Muertos.
Maybe I'm growing soft in my old age, but I can't muster too much aggravation over a film that offers this much entertainment value and showmanship.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Interview flirts with some fascinating moral and societal subtexts but uses unrelated jokes as a crutch.
Big Eyes is as much a Tim Burton film as Big Fish or Frankenweenie, and it is a high water mark on a fascinating filmography.
My daughter liked it just fine, and I'd imagine she's more the target audience than I am.
I can still slightly recommend Into the Woods for its genuine entertainment value for the majority of the picture, and for the strong performances that almost salvage the weaker final third.
Ava DuVernay's Selma is good as you've heard. It's delicious as well as nutritious.
It is not so much "bad" as it is stunningly indifferent to providing anything beyond occasional surface-level entertainment value.
Birdman, with a terrific star turn by Michael Keaton, is one of the best movies of 2014.
Whiplash is a somewhat rare example of a heavily hyped film that lives up to said hype.
The entire film is overacted, overwritten, and overplayed to the point of insult.
47 Ronin looks from the outset like a picture that went off without a hitch.
Lone Survivor comes off as a celebration of the martyred American soldier, that myth that makes it that much easier for old men to send young men to their deaths.

I genuinely fear an entire generation of young would-be financial gurus seeing this film as their Scarface, reveling in the wish-fulfillment excess while dismissing any and all social commentary or moral condemnation.

Her is a winning discussion of the idealization of women and the possessive nature of monogamous relationships in a somewhat warmer fashion than Vertigo or Ruby Sparks while admitting that its a problem for both genders.
The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug is technically "better" than The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey in the same way Attack of the Clones was technically "better" than The Phantom Menace.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The picture is eventually about the therapeutic limitations of art even while celebrating the very real effect it can have on people who need it.
It may be the Coen Brothers playing well inside their comfort zone, but what a fine and thoughtful comfort zone it is.
Set in a place where the American Dream has been dead for so long that no one even thinks to question its loss, the picture features terrific performances from its game cast.
It is perhaps my mistake that I still walk into an Expendables picture expecting either a film of real quality or a top-notch action picture.
It is the kind of film that is almost entirely made up of world-building and exposition with just a token amount of story progression tacked on in the final reel.
Eva Green powers the main story and provides a solid counter-balance to the original film in which most of the women were victims.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Denzel Washington is in fine form, and the film shows off the very specific qualities that make him among our last true-blue movie stars.
Kristen Stewart and Peyman Moaadi are quite good, and the sequences that focus on their would-be relationship make up enough of the running time for the film to qualify as an acting treat.
If it doesn't quite hit the highs of Coraline and ParaNorman, it nonetheless cements Laika as one of the most exciting animation studios currently working today.
There is much to appreciate in this, Kevin Smith's eleventh film. But it also shows the limits of his growth over the last two decades.
I'd rather see Neeson spend his time cranking out more like this instead of making Taken 4: Dawn of Taken
Much of The Maze Runner feels not like a post-apocalyptic action fantasy but an out-and-out horror film.

The picture is at its strongest when it doesn't obsess about the technology at play and simply concentrates on the human drama, which may qualify as irony if you consider what the film is trying to be about.
Gone Girl is a high-quality mainstream crowd-pleaser in the best possible sense of the phrase.
It's a fine example of the kind of "kid-centric" live-action entertainment that has become an endangered species as the industry has focused on "for all ages" PG-13 fantasy spectaculars.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Cake indeed features a strong dramatic turn from Jennifer Aniston and it may or may not win her an Oscar nomination. But aside from that it's just a solid small-scale character study.

Filled with fine performances and authentic period details while refreshingly lacking in patronizing melodrama, "Fury" nonetheless stumbles thanks to thin character development and a mostly passive narrative.
Taken 3 makes Taken 2 look like Taken.
Fox may have a new franchise on its hands with this witty and occasionally spectacular homage to 1970's-era James Bond adventures.
Mortdecai works as a low-stakes comic mystery that is refreshingly aimed squarely at adult moviegoers.
Melissa McCarthy has more than just a great star vehicle and a likely box office winner on her hands. She may have just "stumbled" into her first franchise.
I can (and will) nitpick storytelling choices and character development, but those merely wanting "Look out, earthquake!" will get their money's worth.
Cameron Crowe's newest romantic comedy doesn't quite work, but it is entertaining enough thanks to clever dialogue and old-school movie star charisma.
Inside Out is a gloriously imaginative rebuttal to anyone who would claim that Pixar's best days are behind it.
Jurassic World accomplishes the task of being something of an original adventure within the confines of being a sequel.
Minions has an inspired visual lunacy and some solid gags, but it can't sustain a feature-length story and barely tries to tell one.
There is no future, there is no past. Let's hope this Terminator is the last!
Ant-Man is thematically thin, but it uses its small size to its advantage, crafting a winning comic adventure with spellbinding special effects.

If you're not someone who is automatically shocked or in awe of the notion of a vulgar, profane, and sexually laced comedy that happens to have a female lead, then Trainwreck is going to feel a lot less transgressive and a lot more formulaic.

Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation finally makes Ethan Hunt into not just "Tom Cruise - Action Man" but perhaps the defining role of his long career. The twist is that it may be his most autobiographical as well.
The highly entertaining and sprawling biopic starts out with its pulse on the nation only to somewhat devolve into standard Behind the Music backstage melodrama.
Jonathan Demme and Diablo Cody shrewdly avoid genre conventions, and this late-summer gem offers Meryl Streep another showy star turn.
If you don't like Shaun the Sheep, then baa-ram-ewe!
I wish the whole film were as terrible as its final 2/3, because there is just enough promise, just enough good acting and interesting dialogue that I started to hope that the hype was wrong.
Guy Ritchie's adaptation of the 1960′s television show offers a skewed Daniel Craig/Roger Moore 007 fantasy team-up.
It's not exactly a bad movie. You get what you pay for, and it's somewhat entertaining. But it seems to have stopped thinking as soon as it finished the logline.
Hitman: Agent 47 has enjoyable action, paper-thin characters, and an incomprehensible plot. Well, one out of three ain't bad.
Everest offers a gripping and refreshingly unsentimental reenactment of its grim true-life tale.
Jason Statham is gone but not forgotten in this silly, energetic romp that is so brazenly sexist that it almost qualifies as satire.
This polished sequel lacks the forward momentum of its predecessor and ends up running in place.
Just because I laughed doesn't mean Ride Along is a good movie.
The third act is a profound disappointment, but the journey is enjoyable enough to merit a trip.
Blackhat may not rise to the level of Collateral or The Insider, but nor does it deserve the indignity of a mid-January release.
Pitch Perfect 2 is bigger, faster, and more energetic than the original. It is also a little better.
I take no pleasure from expressing my displeasure in a film like Hot Pursuit.
I think I'll call this review: "The time I was outrageously disappointed by the generic and rehashed Aquaman origin story!"
M. Night Shyamalan roars back to life with this deliciously creepy and funny little triumph.

The Wachowskis' newest science-fiction fantasy is a visual wonder and a big-screen delight, but it suffers from overly complicated storytelling in service of thin characters and redundant action sequences.
It is likely to be one of the worst films of the year, but I'd be lying if I said I didn't enjoy myself. Yes, Seventh Son is that kind of movie.
McFarland, USA is basically the movie you expect it to be, with the caveat that it's a pretty good variation of said movie.
Fifty Shades of Grey is an entertaining, witty, and yes occasionally sexy fable of female assertiveness disguised as a tale of submission.
The Second Best Exotic Hotel barely skates by on the strength of its older cast members, which of course is "the reason for the season" anyway.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Walt Disney's Cinderella is the best film yet in their "turn our animated classics into live-action blockbusters" sub-genre.
Focus is a pretty terrific little movie.
The picture isn't good enough to earn my full-throated defense. A half-hearted defense will have to do.
This second Divergent entry is a more propulsive and action-centric outing, but it turns star Shailene Woodley into a passive observer in her own adventure.
The film works best as a straight character drama as opposed to the elaborate action thriller that it arguably doesn't want to be.
The Gunman is beautiful on the outside but ugly on the inside.

The result is not just an examination of showbiz for aging actress versus emerging starlets, but a treatise on how we examine and judge the fictional choices of fictional characters as opposed to the choices we make in so-called reality.
"Home" is a solid double in a time when DreamWorks really needs a home run.
"Furious 7" isn't so much goodbye as it is merely the end of something.
I wish the on-point shots taken at the so-called investor class weren't just a prelude to a rather generic, weak-willed, and vulgar farce.
Wickedly smart and often wickedly funny, this delightfully entertaining science fiction drama is one of the best films of the year.
Child 44 has strong actors, solid production values, and good intentions. But it mixes too many plot threads and ends up telling none of them particularly well.
Not only is Unfriended a much better film than you might have expected, it's a genuinely terrifying little ride and might just be a new horror classic.
Avengers: Age of Ultron plays like an obligation, a box to be checked off on a list before all parties move onto the things they really want to do.
Mad Max: Fury Road is a remarkable and glorious motion picture, not just one of the great action movies of our time but also a great film, period.
Non-Stop is the kind of film that Hitchcock might have made in his heyday, or at least one he would have enjoyed.
Valkyrie is every bit as good as you remember a Tom Cruise movie being, back when you still liked Tom Cruise.
It has no reason to exist save for entrapping the next generation of kids while hoping to ensnare adults who grew up with the property the first time around.

Quote not available.

Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Disney is back in prime form and lovers of quality can rejoice.
Quote not available.
Boyle and Tandan have made an enchanting story about the power of knowledge, knowledge gained from experiences and gained from life itself.
I predict in Saw VI that Jigsaw will be punishing people for tilting pinball machines, loving their children too much, and driving in the carpool lane unaccompanied.
Quarantine is worth seeing for its solid first two acts, some terrific acting by some favorite character actors, and a several solid spook-show scares.
It is a rock-solid entertainment, made by adults, starring adults, and intended for adults
Knowing may not be a great film, but it is a genuinely good science fiction thriller that is genuinely haunting.
Quote not available.
A film that succeeds at being good without really succeeding in being worthwhile.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Mortdecai is still the best Johnny Depp movie of 2015.
