movie_title: Exorcist: The Version You've Never Seen (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
The title says "Batman" and his face takes up most of the box art, but this is less an adaptation of the Batman/Arkham video games than a straight-up Suicide Squad movie.
It's the rare movie that is almost too realistic and too down-to-earth.
The characters do not stand out, the drama is not compelling, and the screenplay is light on even remotely interesting dialogue.
The film is a narrative disaster, but the character work is mostly solid and the terrific action scenes are worth the price of admission.
It is not only a bad film, it is a rather boring film.
It's an engaging and entertaining adventure story, refreshingly centered around a group of distinct female characters and even directed by a woman to boot.
It is a testament to how spoiled we have become by mainstream animated features that a film as visually arresting as Epic would be considered run-of-the-mill.
The first act of Despicable Me 2 is so winning and engaging that it's almost a tragedy how the rest of the film falls into bargain basement formula.
Cloudy With A Chance of Meatballs 2 is an example of a superior animated sequel that builds on the ideas of the first film and enriches its mythology.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: By going off the proverbial reservation, making what amounts to a Lego movie for adults, even at the risk of displeasing those who wanted nothing more than a nostalgic wink fest, The Lego Movie merits praise as a true work of thematic richness.
The film sometimes plays like a Bible story filtered through the lens of a Snow White and the Huntsman -type re-imagining.
There are moments in The Raid 2 that count among the best action set pieces in modern cinema. I just desperately wish they were in service of a better movie.
It's not a problem that they went and remade Robocop. But the biggest problem with this Robocop is that it's a remake.
You want a pretty decent idea of how a live-action "Justice League teams up to stop Darkseid from destroying the Earth" adventure will go, here you are.
The film feels unique and vibrant if only for the fact that it's the painfully rare DCAU title that doesn't revolve around Batman, Superman, or a Batman/Superman-led Justice League.
movie_title: DCU: Justice League: The Flashpoint Paradox (2013)

movie_review_blurb: I wouldn't want every DCAU film to be like Trapped In Time. But it's nice to have one like it, one that I don't have to hide from my kids.
It says something that an actress like Knightley is now taking high profile roles where her biggest moment is getting a light bulb shoved in her mouth while she tries not to cry.
The picture is a study of how Maslow's Hierarchy of Human Needs applies during a time when the only priority perhaps should be on the physiological.
The Muppets wanted you to laugh and cry. Muppets Most Wanted wants to you cry with laughter.
For this first film at least, much of the fantastical elements feels as much like window dressing as the post-apocalyptic material in After Earth.
If Need For Speed was 15% less overtly dumb and 15% less pandering to the stereotypical boy audience, it might have been a completely enjoyable B-movie romp.
It's not much of a movie, but it's a mostly good time with old friends.
Eva Green is flat-out spectacular here, giving a fully physical and genuinely shaded star turn that is almost as exciting as all of the hacking and slashing.
Into the Storm is a visually dazzling update of the disaster film for the YouTube age, but it is marred by contrived characters and icky politics.
It operates as a genuinely funny, but not obnoxiously course, mediation on the bumpy and uncertain transition to adulthood.
If a movie like My Bloody Valentine plays like a dime-store slasher picture, then adding 3D to the proceedings will only make it look like a 3D dime-store slasher picture.
It has wonderful visuals and some terrific beats, yet has little-to-no story with woefully thin and passive characters.
That the film is arguably far too emotionally and psychologically bleak for its target audience would be excusable, even laudable, if it were better.
A movie so shamelessly derivative of so many other movies that it ought to have a work-cited page at the start of the closing credits.
A top-notch entry in its respective genre and an all-around fine character drama.
What could have been a cheap and easy spin-off is instead a surprisingly engaging and richly constructed adventure film.
Chronicle is a thoughtful and empathetic story of three disparate teens who end up with special powers and how it does or does not change them.
It is easily the best hockey movie since Miracle, for whatever that's worth.
Guardians of the Galaxy is an absolutely crackling action-adventure film, a dazzling and engaging bit of optimistic sci-fi melodrama.
What starts as a terrific and grounded little thriller becomes less interesting as it gets less "little".
Thor: The Dark World survives purely on the charisma of its insanely attractive cast and periodic bursts of good humor.
Those who have spent the last decade upset that Neo didn't start The Matrix Reloaded as all-powerful as he seemed to be at the end of The Matrix will get something of a reckoning with Lucy.
The film absolutely delivers in the realm of Dwayne Johnson participating in massive fight scenes and epic battles.
The key to the film's relative success is the fact that it simply tells its straight dramatic story with a bare minimum of zany comic interludes.
The Purge: Anarchy is a superior horror sequel that once again shows how the disrespected horror genre can often better confront the issues of the day better than most major studio releases.
If Dawn of the Planet of the Apes isn't quite as profound as it wishes to be, it remains an entertaining and intelligent piece of popcorn entertainment.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Susan Sarandon is terrific; delivering a superb and shaded turn for what could have been a broad "rude grandma" phone-in.
Iron Man 3 is, perhaps by default, the best comic book superhero "threequel" yet.
I'm not going to say that Transformers: Age of Extinction is quite "good." But it is arguably the least "bad" of the franchise.
Its adhering to formula nearly kills the film for that middle hour while the bromance plot thread is arguably based in latent homophobia.
The Fault in Our Stars is exceptionally high-quality mainstream entertainment, a genuine work of art that exists in the often maligned sub-genre of teen girl-centric melodrama.

How to Train Your Dragon 2 isn't just a great sequel, a great animated spectacle, or a great example of successful franchise-expansion/world-building. How to Train Your Dragon 2 is flat-out great film, period
Tom Cruise once again shows why he's still a movie star in this exciting, inventive and witty sci-fi actioner.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There is plenty to amuse in A Million Ways to Die in the West, but it's not a very good movie.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This is the seventh X-Men film, the fifth team movie, and we're still dealing with the same "Eric says kill the humans before they kill us" vs. "Charles says give peace a chance" plot.
Sicario is a bracing and powerful indictment of an inherently immoral policy that has turned otherwise good people into villains while making genuine villains into outright monsters.
Still too reliant on nostalgic fan-service, but a clear step in the right direction for these newfangled 'Star Wars' movies.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It is tempting to dismiss films of this nature or to quantify their success in lesser terms as a matter of course. But that would be a mistake. 'The Intern' is truly superb.
To its credit, the film is closer in tone and spirit to hard sci-fi like 'Ex Machina' than an action swashbuckler like 'Guardians of the Galaxy'.
It is very much about the whole "Smurfette Syndrome" thing...
It's one of the weaker installments, one which finds the franchise straining for artistic reasons to continue...
The most realistic action scenes since 'Monty Python and the Holy Grail'.
Like a number of Marvel "part 2" entries, it suffers from the push-pull between being a smaller, more character-driven sequel and providing the required mega-bucks action and spectacle.
It's every bit as formulaic and generic as you feared, with not nearly enough flights of gonzo fantasy.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: One of the happiest surprises of the year...
It's a satisfying have-your-cake and eat-it-too 'Alien' prequel that's more of a 'Prometheus' sequel and thus should satisfy both camps.
It's a slight, but enjoyable epilogue to what was once a groundbreaking franchise.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's just a rock-solid genre exercise with a great cast, superb production values and a strong sense of zero-gravity claustrophobia.
Less a satire or commentary on its source than a straight-faced episode of 'Baywatch' with R-rated jokes thrown in.
It's funny, it's visually inventive and it's just a little bit sweet.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This may be Tom Cruise's worst starring vehicle ever...
A self-critical subversion of the conventional comeback narrative which also operates as a metaphorical defense of the CARS franchise.
It's a good time spent with good company...
It tones down the insanity and the spectacle but leaves little of value in its place.
Andy Serkis may actually get that Oscar nomination this time out...
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I will not penalize a good movie for merely being good.
It's thin, but it's witty and constantly entertaining.
This is a de-facto origin story, one that makes us wait for the sequel for a Spider-Man who isn't a menace to society.
It's a lot closer to 'Batman Begins' than 'Green Lantern'.

At its best, 'Power Rangers' is a throwback to a time when getting a darker, more serious big-budget feature based on your favorite kid-friendly property, one that felt like a real film, was a rare and splendored thing.
I'd like to think we've advanced beyond the whole "that mean/scary dude is really a sweetheart once you get to know him" trope.
It's a visually striking, character-driven monster mash adventure. So yeah, it's pretty darn good.
'Miss Sloane' is superb adult entertainment for adults as well as a grim treatise on feminism and power-friendly media narratives.
It looks great and has a firm moral backbone, but thin characters, pacing issues, and a main narrative that is less interesting than the worldbuilding bring this well-intentioned blockbuster down.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It features a gloriously nuanced movie star performance from Hailee Steinfeld and a host of strong supporting turns in service of Kelly Fremon Craig's thoughtful and often hilarious comedic drama.
This fine adult thriller casts the successful pursuit of those responsible for the Boston Marathon bombing as a cathartic victory for a nation still scarred by the 9/11 attacks.
A great comedic cast playing enjoyable characters in funny situations. What more do you want from a movie called 'Office Christmas Party'?
It's sadly just as bad as the trailers have suggested...
There are plenty of almost random music cues, but all too little soul and too little time spent fleshing out the leads.
It's a true original, it's well-acted by a deep bench of terrific actors, and it works more often than it doesn't.
A flashy, star-driven sci-fi melodrama that gets undercut by a generic (and convenient) finale.
It's the Anakin Skywalker of video game movies, a promising project meant to redeem a bedeviled sub-genre that merely leaves it covered in more darkness.
By default, this is the best 'Underworld' yet.
'Split' is thrilling in the moment but bungles the final stretch in a way that invalidates its arcs and subtexts.
The colorful cast of eclectic (and inclusive) action stars, along with some jaw-dropping action beats, makes this return to the Xander Zone a trip worth taking.
The action is chaotically edited and the supporting characters are dull, but it provides just enough finality to justify itself.
It juggles too many interesting story threads in the air and ends up doing justice to none of them.
It doesn't clear the bar set by THE LEGO MOVIE, but it's an enjoyable and visually inventive comic adventure.
Nitpicks aside, this is one stylish, gorgeous, well-acted, and creative action spectacular.
Everest offers a gripping and refreshingly unsentimental reenactment of its grim true-life tale.
It's less of a white savior trope than a story of a white American who realizes that China is super awesome.
If you remove the graphic violence, it's not all that different from 'The Wolverine,' with Logan again finding someone to protect after turning his back on life.
It wears its homages on its sleeve, yet it's a true original that itself will be homaged in generations to come...
It stumbles in the middle and runs out of narrative gas, but the first act is awesome and, my god, it is a beautiful motion picture.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: 'Descendants 2' has a better villain, some fun action beats, and a willingness to dive deeper into its subtext.
It's the most essential "see it on the big screen or else" experience since 'The Walk'.
Charlize Theron has a new action franchise for the taking if she wants it.
'The Post' is another great Steven Spielberg movie, but is it fighting a battle that America has already forfeited?
It works on its terms and succeeds as a clever and witty kid-friendly adventure without relying on nostalgia or IP awareness.
Not a great time to be releasing a "He's an abusive jerk, but it's okay because he's a genius!" movie, but 'The Phantom Thread' does have a little fun with the genre.
'The Last Jedi' is not a great movie because it's a 'Star Wars' film. It reasserts 'Star Wars' as a top-tier blockbuster franchise by being a great movie.
'Pitch Perfect 3' is a sequel that hates its franchise, hates its characters and thus hates itself.
It has plenty of enjoyable musical numbers and absolutely nothing else.
Ridley Scott's new thriller is exactly the kind of "one for me" offering you want from a big-name director after a big commercial hit.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This would-be streaming blockbuster comes off as a pale, almost Asylum-like imitation of big-scale Hollywood product.
Liam Neeson and Jaume Collet-Serra again team up for another stylish and pulpy Hitchcock homage.
'Paddington 2' is so good that, yes, I would compare it to 'Babe'.
Ryan Coogler's superhero adventure is a crowd-pleasing spectacle and an introspective examination of the moral duty of those who avoided the scars of oppression.
It's essentially 'Rushmore' for kids.
It's a campy mix of wealth porn and affirmative consent fantasy.
Wes Anderson crafts a stop-motion fable blending delightful fantasy, visual wonder and timely political parable.
It's about as funny as an above-average episode of an above-average sitcom episode.

Annihilation is a terrific piece of big-studio sci-fi. It's superbly acted by its refreshingly female-ensemble cast, it's well-written and its staged as both a deeply introspective journey and an unapologetic horror show.

I wish the film dove a little deeper into its subtext (the film teases the notion of other variations of Batman side-by-side with the Adam West version but doesn't go in that direction), but what's there is enjoyable and entertaining.
movie_title: Batman: Return Of The Caped Crusaders (2016)

movie_review_blurb: 'Red Sparrow' is a big, sprawling and unapologetically nasty spy drama, one more rooted in character, sex and violence than action beats.
It's a well-told version of an oft-told tale.
A heartbreaking miss, even if there is much to admire about its intent and social value.
A terrific cast makes up for a pretty standard crime comedy.
It didn't belong in theaters, but it's amusing and enjoyable.
It has big ideas and an unconventional structure, and it is rather engaging when it dives deep into the trade of language translation.
'Shape of Water' is Del Toro's best American movie yet.
One of the best movies of the Oscar season...
It's not the worst thing ever made, but it is seemingly afraid to commit to being a coming-out parable.
Kathryn Bigelow's latest is another demystification of genre, this time detailing an act of historical evil as a grindhouse snuff film.
The second half is better than the first half, but this isn't remotely the sprawling epic that fans arguably deserved.
A classic star+concept studio programmer, one that works thanks to strong chemistry and just enough clever action to justify itself.
A Chinese variation on the white savior myth, but also a slam-bang action spectacular.
This is less an adaptation of the book and more a Cliff Notes version of the TV mini-series.
It's a bad movie, which means its toxic politics have no plausible defense.
It's a terrific horror movie and the most twisted improv game you've ever seen.
Spends too much time undoing the plot beats of the first film, while oddly kid-friendly in tone (if not content).
A terrific Tom Cruise performance anchors a dark, cynical dive into Reagan's America that serves as a counterpoint to 'Top Gun'.
It looks great and boasts solid performances from an underused cast, but (like the original) it's a triumph of style over substance.
Live.Die.Enjoy
It's at its best when Jackie Chan's revenge thriller is mucking up Pierce Brosnan's political drama.
Strong visuals, gonzo action and a high comedy compensate for generic plotting, a padded midsection and a lack of drama.
It wants to be both a cynical reimagining of 'To Kill A Mockingbird' and a Coen Bros' black comedy.
It doesn't justify a seven-years-later return of a once novel/unique horror franchise.
There is something depressing about how scenes of adult women merely having fun with each other in public is seen as almost taboo and/or hilarious.
Francis McDormand anchors an excellent drama about flawed folks dealing in futile ways good and bad with understandable anger.
It works as old-school entertainment with just enough melodrama and visual splendor to earn its keep.
Works best when it's just letting this surrogate family bond over their mutual guilt and fears.
Roman J. Israel, Esq. is an acting treat and a thoughtful bit of old-school character study.
One of Pixar's best movies.
Disney delivers another potent and primal piece of girl-powered mythmaking...
As feared, this wretched story nullifies everything positive about 'Fifty Shades Of Grey.'
'Trumpland' becomes a passionate case not for voting against Donald Trump but for Hillary Clinton.

I suggest you check out In the Heart of the Sea over the next seven days before The Force Awakens steals every IMAX, PLF, 4DX, D-Box, warehouse, farmhouse, henhouse, outhouse and doghouse in your area.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It is not a little disheartening to see this new 'Star Wars' installment not blazing its own path but rather chasing its tail and rehashing its former glories for our approval.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Another uber-violent Mel Gibson directorial project about a man who does his darnedest to avoid violence in a violent environment.
The Hateful Eight is a step backward from one of our best filmmakers, playing like a film by Tarantino the stereotype rather than Tarantino the artist.
'Ride Along 2' is a painfully unfunny retread that can't even live up to the meager pleasures of its predecessor.
13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi is a thrilling and intense action thriller that hides its politics in plain sight.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While visually gorgeous and generally entertaining, this third installment of the DreamWorks Animation franchise is a comedown from the first two superb entries.
Decidedly old-fashioned, The Finest Hours nonetheless shines as a "take it for granted" special effects adventure with just enough character development to make us care about the outcome.
The picture is such an affectionate ode to the business of movies and the potential for cinematic wonder that I'm half-inclined to presume that its flaws are intentional.
I found myself both enjoying the character and certain gags while wishing I could skip ahead 2-3 years to see the presumably superior sequel.
Existing less as a feature film and more as an excuse for endless celebrity cameos, Zoolander, No. 2 is a lazy and often painfully unfunny sequel.

It's funny, it's clever, it's exciting and suspenseful, and it operates as one of the more potent "social issues" pictures that we've seen from a major studio (even during the Oscar season) in quite some time.
At the risk of having to turn in my Social Justice Warrior card, I inexplicably dug the heck out of Alex Proyas's gonzo Gods of Egypt. Please forgive me.
Whiskey Tango Foxtrot features a terrific star turn from Tina Fey, which in turn elevates a somewhat generic (but pointed and entertaining) fish-out-of-water story.
By upping the nationalism while slightly toning down the cartoonishly violent excess, London Has Fallen is both less entertaining and more offensive.
' Allegiant' is superior to 'Insurgent' without qualifying as "good."
Jeff Nichols has crafted a modern-day fable, one rich in character and subtext, and one that in its best moments qualifies as haunting.
As a film, it's pretty thin, but it is an often remarkable technical exercise with just enough narrative invention to justify itself as more than a demo reel.
Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice is a treat for the eyes, but it will hurt your brain and break your heart.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: 'The Jungle Book' is a remarkable achievement and yet more reason to be optimistic about Disney's "turn an animated classic into a live-action feature" sub-genre.
'The Boss' is just a rock-solid and genuinely funny comic vehicle from one of our biggest/brightest comedic movie stars.
If the sum of its parts don't add up to much, the fact remains that the specific parts are often breathtaking.
'Captain America: Civil War' Is Great Fun, Even As It Alternates Between Shameless Fan Service Bits And Subversive Narrative Choices.
It's not the disaster that may be implied by the lack of pre-release reviews or the last minute embargo, but nor is it a new holiday classic.
The delayed and much-debated The Good Dinosaur is a perfectly good family-friendly animated feature that shouldn't be taken for granted on account of its simpler pleasures.
Hotel Transylvania 2 is a surprisingly charming and funny animated sequel.
The Walk offers a genuinely unique cinematic experience in precisely the manner that it promises.
Truth passionately retells a vital nugget of recent American history, but it misses the essential contradiction in its morality play.
'Pan' Is A Pretty Poor Peter Pan Prequel
Goosebumps is positioned to be the first live-action theatrical horror movie for an entire generation of emerging moviegoers.
Room becomes something specific and something genuinely powerful.
Danny Boyle and Aaron Sorkin's Steve Jobs is a fantastically entertaining cinema.
Steven Spielberg's casual excellence has reached a point where we take it for granted. The overwhelming success of a film like Bridge of Spies shows why we do so to our detriment.
Crimson Peak is a triumph of production design that attempts to cover for a generic story with little in the way of complexity or incident.
Our Brand Is Crisis features a great Sandra Bullock star turn in a comedic political romp that is more biting and cynical by virtue of how conventional it feels.
Excitement? Adventure? Glamour? Glitter? Fashion? Fame? The 'Jem' movie contains not these things.

It is impressively staged, superbly acted, and efficiently authentic in its portrayal of not-so-ancient history. Carey Mulligan is terrific, which is important since she is in almost every moment of the film.
The film hums along pleasantly without really engaging you beyond the surface level pleasures of watching attractive people make high-class cuisine.
I am apparently allergic to 'Peanuts.'
'Spectre' Is The Worst 007 Movie In 30 Years.
Brooklyn is one of the best movies of the year and something of a miracle. See it on the big screen or you don't get to complain about anything ever again.
The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2 ends the franchise on a high note, solidifying it as a defining blockbuster series for a generation born after 9/11.
Spotlight is all about the importance of getting the story absolutely right.

In its own way, it is as loving an homage as something like House of the Devil, Super 8, or Hobo With A Shotgun in terms of painstakingly crafting a seemingly original film that mostly lives to remind audiences of a different movie from long ago.
At its core, Concussion is about the disillusionment of an uncommonly idealistic American immigrant.
The great irony of Ryan Coogler's Creed is that it is among the more grounded entries in the Rocky series yet acts as a direct sequel to the ultra-fantastical Rocky IV.
Fair or not, Adam McKay's entertaining and intelligent The Big Short feels like a case of subtext becoming text.
Without maligning its predecessors, it might be the best of the three.
Sisters is an old-school laugh riot, with a parade of talented comedians scoring here, there, and everywhere.
The majority of 'The Huntsman' is an act of narrative justification, spending more time explaining where the pieces are on the chessboard than actually playing chess.
One of the best movies of the year...
By today's standards, it's an example of restraint.
Its relative amorality is almost counts as an act of audience trust.
This is a fresh inversion on the usual "is the artificial lifeform an actual human being?" story.
The second act is worth the price of even the most expensive IMAX ticket.
Oh wait, so you decided to wait until September to give us a halfway decent summer action movie? Thanks, I think.
A mostly enjoyable animated romp with some a few winning digressions along the way.
It's about as good as you hoped it would be...
A sprawling, meditative, and visually beautiful magical history tour filled with inspiring sights and profound observations.
movie_title: Voyage of Time: The IMAX Experience (2016)

movie_review_blurb: 'Pete's Dragon' is the best "big" movie of the summer.
Desierto is a lean and brutally efficient piece of horror filmmaking.
It's a simpler, more conventional genre offering than the first film, but it gets the job done.
I liked the last fifty minutes enough to forgive the first fifty minutes.

The visuals are worth the price of admission, but this is as generic and by-the-numbers an origin story as the MCU has ever made. It's better than 'Green Lantern,' but it will remind you of 'Green Lantern'.

Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children is a middle-of-the-road Tim Burton movie, with enough "good" regarding visuals and subtext to counteract the overly complicated narrative, thinly developed supporting characters and often arbitrary plot beats.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It is a taut, mostly engaging, and just slightly melodramatic (in a good way) "you are there" retelling of the events that took place on April 20, 2010.

La La Land works as a musical, as a romance, as a love letter to old-school Hollywood, and as a thoughtful meditation on the sacrifices that creative people must make in order to share that creativity with us.
Jeremy Saulnier's Green Room is a white-knuckle thriller that flirts with becoming something approaching a comedy of errors.
It's not as gonzo crazy as 'Angels & Demons,' but it's more spirited than 'The Da Vinci Code'.
A strong first 2/3 devolves into a final third which is almost entirely retroactive exposition.
A huge improvement over the middling original...
Well, it's better than 'Suicide Squad,' for what that's worth...
I like what the film eventually becomes about and that it's not trying to be anything more than it is.
It tackles "mommy guilt" while letting men and dads off the moral hook.
It is (perhaps by default) probably the worst "big" DC Comics live-action movie since 'Catwoman'.
Easily the worst "team" X-MEN movie ever made. Makes X-MEN: THE LAST STAND look like X-MEN: FIRST CLASS.
'Money Monster' is a good movie, one worth seeing, but it is a good movie that I just couldn't buy.
What 'The Angry Birds Movie is about is better than how it's about it.
Shane Black's 'The Nice Guys' is exactly the movie you wanted it to be.
It's better than the first film without being "good."
A shocking 180-degree turnaround from its atrocious predecessor, 'Out of the Shadows' is exactly the movie you wanted two years ago.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: You'll need a strategy guide to make it through this one...
It eventually devolves into basically the same core "scare" repeated over and over again.
Its appeal lies not in special effects, violence, action, or romance, but merely a good idea played out by an enjoyable cast.
Perhaps the best live-action comedy sequel since 'Addams's Family Values'.
' Lights Out' is a well-written and well-acted dysfunctional family drama that works even absent the supernatural elements that eventually take center stage.
It's neither as good as you hoped nor as bad as you feared.
It starts and ends exceptionally well, but it gets bogged down in the middle.
"Okay" is not the enemy of perfect.
It's not as good as the last film, and it probably won't change any hearts-and-minds, but this third 'Purge' film remains a potent work of cultural criticism.
A disagreeable effort, made more so by turning Margot Robbie into a full-time hostage.
It's entertaining enough, but it's another round of BOURNE Mad Libs...
Blake Lively gives a terrific "solitary" performance in this effective little horror drama.
This might shock you, but that Steven Spielberg guy made another good movie.
Dwayne Johnson and Kevin Hart are terrific together, and the well-written potboiler doesn't let them down.
It's an extinction level event...
Cars 3 is inspiring, heartfelt, and fun. It's everything I wanted from the first two films and a lot more.
Tucci and Timlin light up the screen and deliver one of the best performances of their careers thus far.
Women and moviegoers deserve better than anything found in Rough Night . Female writers and directors should strive to make films that stand out and are better than their male counterparts.
Hollywood needs more films like this one. Films that aren't afraid to take chances and challenge genre as well as audiences.
Madelyn Deutch, Zoey Deutch, and Lea Thompon are a triple threat in this quarter life crisis tale that deserves your attention.
Annabelle: Creation will be hard to top as the year's most inventive and scariest film
War for the Planet of the Apes is the perfect emotional ending to one of the best movie trilogies of all time.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I pretty much adored everything about First Girl I Loved.
The Emoji Movie should not be supported because it celebrates lazy filmmaking, bad storytelling, and materialism.
Spider-Man: Homecoming is better than Spider-Man 3 but not by much.
Luc Besson has achieved visual perfection that has far surpassed what Marvel and Disney have achieved over the past decade.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I never expected Girls Trip to be the funniest film of the year but it is. Girls Trip is not only raunchy comedy done right but feminism done right.
The Glass Castle isn't an easy watch but is easily one of the best films of the year.
A poor man's version of a Woody Allen movie with a 88-minute runtime that feels like it lasts for over three hours.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An underdog story but one with a young female protagonist that isn't afraid to go after what she wants and strives to achieve her dream.
Battle of the Sexes is the feel good female empowerment film that the world needs right now.
Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie celebrates friendship, creativity, animation, and potty humor.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are honestly two different films here and the second one is almost unbearable to sit through.
the best family film of the summer movie season
Opening Night is an absolute delight from start to finish.

Richard Turner's story is inspirational and makes you think about your life and shortcomings. This is the type of documentary that will make you feel alive while reminding the viewer to always live each day to the fullest.
Before I Fall is a life-affirming and inspirational film.
Franco brings his A game to this project and puts his heart and soul into the material.
This is a rare sequel that I would argue is just as good, if not somewhat better the original.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Zoe Lister-Jones has crafted a near-perfect film that will connect with almost every married couple in some way.
Baywatch is easily one of the worst films of the summer and one that I hope audiences won't spend any of their hard-earned money on.
All in all, Everything Everything is a watered-down modern day rehash of the Boy in the Plastic Bubble with a female lead.
Alien Covenant tries to recreate the first two films but gets lost in its own laziness.
All in all, King Arthur: Legend of the Sword is unnecessary but forgettable fun. While not a must-see film, it is pure popcorn entertainment.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 2 is just like your standard mixtape; it's an uneven experience filled with highs and lows.
I think studios need to take more chances on films like this. Films that try to be different and push boundaries. Get Out is bold and daring and most importantly, unique.
Wonder Woman is a game changer because it is not only the best film of the DCEU but one of the best superhero films ever made.

Horror-comedy is one of my favorite genres, so I am delighted to report that Tragedy Girls is easily one of the best of it's kind. It is the perfect blend of horror and comedy with a story that feels fresh and relevant. #Blessed
Gemini is a who cares whodunit. It is a mystery thriller without any mystery or thrills.
It is nice to finally see a romantic comedy that isn't afraid to tackle dark subject matters in a mature way.
The Boss Baby is a fun and refreshing animated film that feels like an homage to classic early morning cartoons.
If you are a fan of shark flicks, this is a must see and one that will leave you gasping for air.
Baby Driver proves once again that Edgar Wright is a creative genius and can take on any genre and knock it out of the park.
A deeply psychological 146-minute roller coaster ride
Disney has developed a winning formula by hiring talented directors that can take their beloved classics and turn them into live action masterpieces.

After seeing this film, I have determined that I want to live inside the mind of David Lowery. He is one of the most inventive directors of this generation and is capable of making great films no matter how big or small.

Home Again is a throwback to what I consider the lost "romantic comedy" genre. Everything nowadays has to be vulgar and filled with adult humor while Home Again is just a nice film that is enjoyable because it is simple and lighthearted.
This is John Krasinski's third feature film and is without question his best. Krasinski has found his calling as a genre director and A Quiet Place will knock your socks off.
Brad's Status is a simple yet brilliant film that is one of the biggest surprises of the year.
This is the type of independent film that I wish more indie films would strive to be like.
The Best Animated Film of 2017.
Dwayne Johnson, Jack Black, Kevin Hart, and Karen Gillan are all perfectly cast. Each of these actors commits to the material and becomes their character.
The Last Jedi may not be a flawless film but continues to push the story forward. The film has a lot going for it and Rian Johnson seems to understand exactly what Star Wars fans are looking for.
A remarkable celebration of music, creativity, and imagination. It is 2017 's La La Land and a cinematic love letter to dreamers everywhere.
Pitch Perfect 3 is so bad that it's hard to comprehend how it even exists.
What Bo Burnham has accomplished with his directorial debut is nothing short of extraordinary. He manages to bring to life a genuine story about a 13-year-old girl that will redefine the genre.
Lizzie is a refreshing new take on the Lizzie Borden story and one that will speak to a modern audience.
Justice League is the most fun that I had at the movies all year.
Search is an innovative and intense roller coaster ride. It has not only redefined the mystery genre but storytelling as a whole.
Won't You Be My Neighbor? isn't just the best documentary of 2018 but one of the best documentaries ever made.
As someone who appreciates filmmakers that dare to push boundaries and break conventions, I couldn't help but fall in love with this wild and crazy world that Riley created.
Black Panther has surpassed Iron Man as the best film of the MCU.
Hearts Beat Loud is a charming and heartwarming film that I loved every moment of.
Flower is a bold, unpredictable, and unconventional dark comedy with a career-making performance by Zoey Deutch.
Gyllenhaal and Maslany could be nominated for their honest and genuine performances while Jeff's story will remind audiences that there is always something in life worth fighting for.

Blockers is just as good as most male-driven sex comedies such as Superbad and American Pie. With that being said, the film is very much standard sex comedy fare and filled with several moments of pure stupidity.
A groundbreaking visual spectacle that combines all types of popular media and rolls them into one massive and must-see motion picture experience.
Marlo is an incredibly complex character and Theron has no problem emerging herself into this role.
The feel-good film of the year and one that reminds the world to be kind to one another.

The Post is the best film about journalism since All the Presidents Men. It is timely and important. It proves that history sadly does repeat itself and speaks very loudly to what is currently going on in America.
Thor: Ragnarok is the best Thor yet but it is still a Thor Movie.
Professor Marston and The Wonder Women will forever change the way that you look at Wonder Woman.
This is the type of film that I cannot wait to own as I will be watching it over and over again.
mother! is one of the most memorable films of the year and is bound to get people talking. It's entertaining, engaging, and leaves the audience with plenty to think about upon exiting the theater.
While I can't deny that I was somewhat entertained by Super Size Me 2: Holy Chicken, I would be lying if I admitted that I learned more than one or two minor things while watching it.
If you somehow make it through the last 20-30 minutes of this film without shedding a tear, you might want to check your pulse because you might be dead inside.
The Man Who Invented Christmas is the very definition of festive fun for the entire family. It is an instant holiday classic and one that celebrates creativity and imagination.

Greta Gerwig's directorial debut is something special and proves that Gerwig is not only a talent in front of the camera but behind one as well. In a sea of coming of age movies, Lady Bird stands out as a truly fantastic film.
Lean on Pete is a dramatic coming of age story that stands out mainly due to the performance by Charlie Plummer.
Gary Oldman has never been better and he can consider himself the winner of that Oscar because I highly doubt there will be a better performance this year.
Kevin Hart and Bryan Cranston are the perfect oddball duo and are irresistible together.
I, Tonya is a fascinatingly funny look into the life of Tonya Harding. Margot Robbie delivers the best performance of her career while Allison Janney steals every scene.
The Shape of Water is a must-see mesmerizing fairy tale for adults.
While this might be a bold statement to make, I do believe that Blade Runner 2049 is better than the original.
The story is thought-provoking and isn't afraid to ask big questions that will certainly spark conversation among those who see the film.
Only the Brave is without question the best firefighter film since Backdraft and one that pays tribute to the brave men that sacrificed their own lives to protect thousands of others.
Unfortunately, this sequel is a mixed bag at best.

Molly's Game is engaging, exciting, and entertaining from beginning to end. It is an award-worthy directorial debut from Aaron Sorkin and I wouldn't be surprised if Chastain received a nomination for her jaw-dropping performance as Molly Bloom.
a dark and comedic jab at suburban life and the secrets of those who live there.
The story has a lot of mystery to keep the viewer interested while film aficionados will surely appreciate Haynes' superb direction and Edward Lachman's remarkable visuals.
The bigger issues with I Saw the Light are the lack of narrative drive and the question of why someone would want to make such a joyless movie about such a beloved musical icon.

It Follows is more than just a terrifying horror movie - it's a heady and heartbreaking exploration of both sexually transmitted disease and sexual abuse, and an unexpectedly poignant riff on the classic coming-of-age narrative.

Here's the first thing you should know about Suicide Squad: It is definitely worse than Batman v Superman. If you didn't like that, there's no reason to see this. If you did... well, there's still not really a reason to see this.

War Dogs comes with heaping spoonfuls of sugar to help all that medicine go down -- so many of them that the darker, more political message at the heart of the movie might get swallowed up altogether.

This is a film that successfully balances its pulpier genre trappings with a haunting meditation on the nature of 21st century relationships-with our neighbors, our friends, our spouses, and ourselves-and dares us to interrogate what we find.
Unfortunately-like pretty much every other horror crossover-the idea is promising in concept, but underwhelming in execution.

There are still some things you can always count on in a Fast & Furious movie, and The Fate of the Furious certainly delivers on what this franchise promises.
What Before Midnight understands about relationships - and what virtually no other mainstream film is willing to acknowledge - is that getting together is the easy part. Staying together is hard.
A new Blade Runner can just be a movie, free to forge its own trail in this dark and fascinating universe. And this time, I expect the wait will be a lot shorter than 35 years.
Interstellar is a beautiful, irritating, awe-inspiring mess. It's the kind of movie Hollywood simply doesn't make any more - and that's exactly why you should see it.
Once you've cracked the code, you know where it's going, and the only thing left to do is deepen the protagonist's (and the audience's) misery.
