...every once in a while a true rib-tickler will jam into you and wake you up.
The leads make it watchable (plus it's always a hoot to see Denise Richards onscreen in any form)...
...feels a whole lot like watching three hard-working actors who are feverishly trying to extricate one another from an entire planet made of quicksand.
If it's a drama, it's too silly to be effective - and if it's a comedy, it's alarmingly free of charm.
Similar to the way in which Burger King's food doesn't so much "satisfy your hunger" as it does "fill your stomach with mass".
Often feels more like a perfume commercial than a "horror movie".
movie_title: I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997)

movie_review_blurb: Taken as a disposable sort of cable television flick, this movie could capably fill 90-some uneventful minutes.
Has an energy and enthusiasm that certainly works in fits and starts, but taken as a whole, it's a few explosions (and a lot of yearning) signifying very little.
movie_title: What to Do in Case of Fire (Was tun, wenn's brennt?) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: By the time the narrative starts heading somewhere remotely interesting (i.e. a murder or a revelation or just SOMEthing), you may be too groggy to notice...

movie_title: The Work of Director Chris Cunningham (2003)

movie_review_blurb: ...as scrappy and likable as it is clearly stretched upon a paper-thin budget.
First-time writer/director Daniel Gamburg clearly has a canny ear for the way the 'office folk' communicate.

Powerful and heart-wrenching, gorgeous to look at, and fascinating to contemplate. All issues of religion aside, those components generally result in a film worth seeing.
Gondry has a gift for visual sleight-of-hand that simply boggles one's mind.
movie_title: The Work of Director Michel Gondry (2003)

movie_review_blurb: By the time Young Sherlock Holmes clangs to a close, the assets of the film are buried beneath an avalanche of unnecessary bells and whistles.

Worth watching if only for the half-dozen familiar faces and a few scenes that ratchet up the intensity quite serviceably.
It's always great to see potentially forgotten programs like Gigantor earn a swanky DVD release.
Welcome to Mooseport has no bite, no edge, and no discernable drive when it comes to making with the yuks.
This one's so laughless, so charmless, and so resoundingly amateurish that one wonders why it doesn't carry a "National Lampoon Presents" in front of the title.
Bwooklyn Meg sounds a whole lot like Margot Kidder impersonating Phyllis Diller. The accent comes and goes, but it remains the most entertaining aspect of the entire movie.
Can a movie be fascinating and boring at the same time?
1/3 slob comedy, 1/3 romantic schmaltz and 1/3 Memento / Groundhog Day. The result is as choppy and unformed as one might expect from such a recipe.
A cult classic waiting to happen for those who like their Horror Movies dark, smart, twisted and hard.

...transcends documentary and offers a few lessons on how rewarding it can be to open your heart to someone a bit more...askew...than is generally seen as normal.
movie_title: Big City Dick: Richard Peterson's First Movie (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A silly and wholly enjoyable romp for movie buffs, one that steals inspiration from old-school horror turkeys and 70's-era soap opera fare alike.

A Hot-Button comedy that focuses on 'enlightenment via entertainment'.
I've seen They twice now, once theatrically and once via DVD, and...for the life of me...I can't tell you what it's about.
When you're watching a movie and you really can't tell if it's a straight drama or a broad farce, you're probably dealing with a bad movie.
As Fame begins to unspool and you realize that the movie's a lot more endearingly grimy and profane than you recall...just blame it on that stupid TV knockoff.
Clearly this is a movie made in a world where the "MPAA" holds no sway; the violence is intensely brutal. In a good way, though.
Might prove a worthwhile curiosity to those who enjoy Asian horror/action colloids that are more interested in wacky style than in narrative cohesion.
For those who think 'Deliverance' didn't have enough Poop Humor.
This is what happens when an entire movie is created via reshoot.

It's a confident and well-mounted B-level comedo-horror cocktail, full of witty barbs, gorgeous babes - and just a little bit of brains amidst all the blood.

If you're among those who giggled at the trailer before calling your buds to say Dude. Harold Kumar. Looks funny., you'll probably find a solid case of chuckles here.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: When you find yourself bored and wishing a movie would speed up and get to the TWIST ENDING already...well, that's not a particularly good movie, now is it?

I, Robot is a movie destined for fast-forward buttons the world over.
This one's crazy, silly, funny and whole lotta loony, but as a cohesive movie movie...it's also kind of a mess.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: If you're going to intentionally suck all the good parts out of a great tale, you'd best replace them with something besides dry political intrigue and predictable gimmickry.
Avoiding the safety of the PC blanket, David O. Russell has crafted a canny, crafty and altogether adorable little misfit of a movie.
Danny Boyle's Trainspotting is a blast of ice-cold water across a sweaty brow; it's a lively, vibrant and pulsatingly addictive movie.
It's not just that Seagal makes awful movies; it's that he makes the exact same awful movies over and over. He's that annoying uncle who never stops borrowing money.
As long as movies are not required to play theatrically before hitting the DVD shelves, we'll have plenty of new Van Damme flicks to make fun of.
From top to bottom, from the action parts to the talky bits, The Bourne Supremacy is a movie that absolutely flies by with nary an unnecessary breath.
One of those 'exception to the rule' horror movies in which a little humour and a lot of effort go a very long way.
Feels like a science-fiction concept from 1951 that has been strained through a soap-opera sieve and left to moulder on the counter for six weeks.
The licenses taken with King's original tale only serve to make a more effective movie.
If my neighbourhood pals and I made a horror movie, it'd look a whole lot like Demoness.

There's a current that runs through this movie, one that reeks of a storyteller who's truly fascinated by his research and loves to share it.
movie_title: H.H. Holmes - America's First Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Most High is about the very nature of addiction. It paints an eerily accurate picture of how a Normal Joe can quickly end up in the dankest pits of despair.

Evil bastards encounter angry spirits in a haunted house. You do the math.

movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Spacey clearly has a distinct respect and affection for the memory of old-school crooner Bobby Darin, and that emotion virtually pours from the screen in buckets.

movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's a simple and straightforward little tale, but Boyle brings such a vivid energy and heartfelt attitude to the narrative - this is a very difficult movie to dislike.

movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Gigli is precisely as awful as everyone's been saying, and it's a sad state of affairs when a 2+ hour parade of self-adoration can pass for an actual movie.

movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Probably shouldn't be your first stop into the wonderfully weird world of Fellini, but his fans should absolutely find something to savour in this enjoyable little farce.

Never before have I been so thrilled about being so wrong: despite all my early skepticism, Pirates ends up one of the most entertaining movies of the past few years.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This is lazy, cookie-cutter sequelizing at its most royally obnoxious.

Hulk, quite simply, smash.

If you're the sort who used to enjoy romantic comedies before they became doddering and formulaic chick flicks, take some steps and search this one out.
Two mediocre action scenes spring up to help alleviate the tedium. All they do is remind us how generic and tiresome the non-action bits are.
Seemingly inspired by Pulp Fiction, The Sting and anything presented by the word processor of David Mamet...yet still the flick entertains in its own right. And wait till you see this CAST!
Without Lying Down is the perfect sort of Hollywood History Lesson: it's succinct, fascinating and obviously crafted with a lot of admiration for the woman at hand.
movie_title: Without Lying Down: Frances Marion and the Power of Women in Hollywood (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Considering how many powerful people detested this movie, it's a testament to the film that it still even exists.
movie_title: I Spit on Your Grave (Day of the Woman) (1978)

movie_review_blurb: Also worthwhile as a retro background presentation for the groovier party hosts, Gigantor is old-school pop kitsch at its most weirdly endearing.
Succesfully playing a zombie onstage doesn't take the place of a few basic courses in Film School.
There's something to be said for a cookie-cutter genre flick that delivers its payload with a minimum of obnoxiousness.
If you happen to wake up and see anything onscreen that's NOT taking place inside a log cabin - feel free to fall back asleep.
There's more artistry, heart, talent and wit in the first four minutes of A Mighty Wind than there is in the whole of Adam Sandler's last three comedies combined.
Knowing how to frame a gag effectively is absolutely essential when creating a slapstick sex farce, and American Wedding does just that with alarming accuracy.

The jokes are aimed low and delivered with the intensity of a wet paper towel. By the time Woody Harrelson shows up in drag, you'll be wondering if you just bought a ticket to the first film ever scripted by Mrs. Filarksi's 3rd grade English class.
...tells its distressingly factual history in surprisingly touching fashion.
Old and interesting is often better than new and flashy. If you want to find out how much you really enjoy science fiction, pick any five episodes at random and give 'em a spin.
If Gilliam was intending to create a film that would disgust, disorient and eventually irritate, then this one's a bona-fide masterpiece - but don't expect me to sit through it ever again.
movie_title: Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (1998)

movie_review_blurb: I sincerely doubt that Wes Craven even watches the movies he 'presents' these days. Either that or he's gone insane.
This movie has a charming Eddie Murphy, a slick and grown-up comedian. Most of his movies have no trace of this man.
Just charming enough to avoid being entirely annoying.
I'm half-convinced it's a very poker-faced comedy. Then again, I may be giving the filmmakers way too much credit.
In other words, it's just another sports drama/character study. Yet this one makes up for in heart what it lacks in outright newness. Plus, like I already mentioned...it's Robert Duvall! C'mon!
The Believer is packed to the gills with various speeches and lectures and theological bantering. Much of it ends with someone getting a baseball bat to the head.
Although written in a fairly pedestrain fashion, the movie does a good job of raising the "What would you do?" issues. Me, I'd be chomping blindly, hoping to ingest the dead first.
Worst of all is the fact that the Mystery Science Theater guys aren't still around for this one. They could build an entire season around Barbarian.
Stealing Harvard is a limp and lazy affair, and a flick that positively reeks of contractual obligation.
Glory Daze is yet another of those "post-college angst ridden party boys get semtimental about moving on" kinda things, one that's notable solely because of its eclectic cast and very little else.
Reminiscient of Gorman Bechard's obscure Psychos in Love, Maniacts is one of the more entertaining schlock flicks I've seen in a while...but make no mistake: it's still a pretty bad movie.
There's not a damn thing on display here than well-traveled horror fans haven't seen 300 times before. And less obnoxiously.
It's hardly a revolutionary concept, but it's also clear a little heart went into this Marvel incarnation - and that extra effort goes a long way.
It should be mentioned that the set design and interiors of the haunted vessel are more than effectively creepy and moodily lit. So I just did.
You may predict some of the twists; heck, you may even predict all of 'em. (I didn't.) But even if that's the case, Identity is so much fun to watch that you simply won't care.
Whoever still believes that Hollywood "doesn't make 'em like they used to" is clearly unaware that Roger Corman is still churning out the schlock.
If you're looking for something artistic and brilliantly conceived, I suggest you search elsewhere. But there's something to be said for a straight sitcom flick that delivers the laughs.
Imagine Rear Window with giant humanoid insects in the Raymond Burr role.
A follow-up that pays homage to its lineage while marking a little new territory of its own.
Sure this one may be "so bad it's good" but there's something about the flick's outright plagiarism that prevents me from offering it even a backhand compliment
If it's Kevin Smith's uncanny knack for witty wordplay and memorable dialogue that made you a fan, odds are you'll find a whole lot to enjoy in this unique film.
Those unfamiliar with the endless streams of Z-grade slasher flicks will miss much of what Director's Cut has to offer, but old-school Gorehounds will absolutely appreciate the goods.
Cinema Paradiso is laden with wonderful moments and ideas. It's quite simply one of the most beautifully romantic films ever made.
Easily one of the finest DVDs devoted to the majestic history of America's pastime.
movie_title: Major League Baseball Memorable Moments - The 30 Most Memorable Moments in Baseball History (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Not a soft-core porn flick with a mildly professional storyline, but a winning little indie that sheds some fascinating light onto an industry we rarely see.
The Movie Machine is skewered and lampooned with an impressive accuracy, but it never crosses the line into becoming an outright bash.
That Robert J. Flaherty managed to make a fascinating movie that also subtly chastises the massive oil interests (using their money to do it) is one for the record books.

The film's first hour-plus is not much more than a whole lotta Masterpiece Theater-style chit-chat and when the old ghost story schpiel eventually does show up... it doesn't leave all that much of an impression.
Other than as a time capsule back to a much sillier era - or as something to laugh at incessantly - Invitation to Hell is every bit as torturous as its title implies.
While Re-Animator has wit and audacity and gore and ferocity to spare, Bride of Re-Animator has gore... and the same actors.
As bad as the movie gets (which, to be fair, isn't THAT bad), Rose McGowan holds it together on at least a 'watchability' level. 'Believability' is another story.
A wholly forgettable little TV flick - one that may serve its purpose should it pop up on cable one night - but certainly nothing worthy of actual money.
As a cinematic time capsule to a goofier era, it kinda works.
Certainly not awful and definitely not excellent, Runaway Jury should please fans of the Courtroom Genre and those who admire the varied talents of Cusack, Hoffman and (especially) Hackman.
Heffernan and company have crafted a film both entertaining on its surface - and possessed of a heart and soul underneath.
To those who consider Paul Anderson's Resident Evil some sort of affront to the sensibilities of hardcore videogamers the world over, The House of the Dead will eaily supplant their venom.
A flick so knee-deep in its own genre-worship that it should thrill movie fans the world over while giving the action junkies a few extended sequences that they'll want to watch again and again.
Save for the stately presence of Kenneth Welsh as the long-underappreciated Dr. Watson, there's very little that stands out as noteworthy within these four underbaked adaptations.
A potentially A-B-C generi-comedy concept flick that's salvaged at every turn by the infectiously funny leading man and a collection of kid actors more sincerely personable than seriously precocious.
It's all very socially aware and nature-friendly, and the tale is a worthwhile one indeed; too bad A Man Called Horse moves so slowly for much of its running time.
A fairly compelling movie, but when one realizes that the screenplay was penned by a 14-year-old gal...it adds a whole new perspective to all the angst being tossed around.
Puts similar movies to shame simply by bringing that infectiously goofy FUN back into what's generally known as the Mindless Action Flick.
Despite a handful of worthwhile horror moments, Vampires: Los Muertos is almost entirely dead on arrival.
A bold, boisterous, bloody good time - and any old-school Horror Freak able to get over the "How dare they?!?" attitude should absolutely find a lot to enjoy here.
Watching arrogant idiots as they commit stupid acts while constantly mugging for the camera is entertainment of the lowest conceivable measure.
Too vanilla, too banal and too earnest to do the source material any justice.
This anthology, much like an exhibit of confident and periodically shocking artworks, will speak volumes to viewers.
Having Chinese Granny mumble "fo shizzle mah nozzle" (or whatever) is the surest indication of a screenwriter with more cocaine than talent.
Entertainment of the lowest conceivable measure.
House of Sand and Fog is the diametric opposite of stuff like Enough and Double Jeopardy, and I mean that as a very large compliment.
The Return of the King is one of the finest things I've ever seen. And that includes stuff like sunrises and babies and the original, unaltered Star Wars.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Sincere and respectful to its subject matter while delivering a rousing adventure tale...wrapped up in that comfy old Redemption Movie we all love so much.
Feels like something that was churned out through a machine; Disney Live-Action Cheese By Committee.
If you're sort of a Grinch, or you just need a brief respite from the sugarplums and tree ornaments for 90 minutes, Bad Santa is a nasty and joyously caustic good time.
You'll watch with a sneer and a throb in your head. You'll watch and you'll sit there and wish you were dead.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: So bad that it makes Seagal's other films look like the combined efforts of Frank Capra and Billy Wilder.
Doesn't perfectly capture the manic energy of the old WB cartoons, but it comes pretty ... close, which is fairly impressive in this age of corporate-filmmaking-by-blueprint.
It's quite easy to just sit back and enjoy Master and Commander as the refined spectacle it clearly is.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Sure, it's not much more than a 'sketch after sketch' presentation, but one can forgive an aimless narrative when the gags are this unexpectedly funny.
At least the kills are plentiful and the splatters are fairly generous. That bare minimum of attention will always earn a little respect from me and my fellow GoreHounds.
Even what should be the focal point of a 'Steven Seagal movie' (i.e. the punching of throats) is delivered in a style so shoddy that it boggles the mind.
Action star (and fine dramatic actor) Jean Reno has fallen prey to the Action Comedy conceit and the result is the periodically entertaining, generally tiresome Wasabi.
As low-rent and derivative as a knock-off can possibly be - which is both a good thing and bad. But mostly bad.
The humor ranges from silly-sweet to actively arcane, and the schmaltzy stuff is offset by a hipness that could only come from the guy responsible for Swingers.
A handsome, romantic and altogether engrossing tale that should absolutely please fans of "the old-fashioned tearjerker".
Presents long stretches between the more compelling ideas and the end result is a movie that smells like an enjoyable Genre Stew but ends up tasting like limp noodles.
Everyone LOVED the first one. Then they "kinda tolerated" the second one. Logic dictates that the third one "sucks". I disagree.
Delivered in sobering and dramatic black and white, it's quite possibly one of the most honest and compelling 'bio-pics' ever conceived.
You'd be better off spinning Near Dark or The Lost Boys one more time than you would bringing this one home.
If you somehow remember this one with some fondness, do yourself a favor and never see it again.
Save the stunningly poor FX and the presence of a few vaguely familiar C-list character actors, Infested offers next to nothing of entertainment value.

The new facelift and the truckload of supplementary materials serve to keep the film both timeless and accessible - while affording a true classic of the Silent Era the immortal respect it certainly deserves.
Taken at face-value and with no massive expectations, Dolls isn't a half-bad little indie.
The action bits are few and far between; the non-action bits are omnipresent and interminable. May be a solid flick for 10-year-olds, but even they'll be yawning through the nonsensical narrative.
Sometimes-genius David Zucker directs from a woeful screenplay, jamming photogenic automatons Kutcher and Reid into a parade of limp physical comedy and uninspired gross-out.
Points for trying, but this flick gets its inspirations from movies not all that hot to begin with, and then simply rehashes them point by point.
A two-hour history lesson on the world's most fascinating subject, and it goes without saying that a flick like this is a Movie Animal's fondest wish.
Worthwhile only as a testament to the over-baked and hysterical talents of Shelly Winters, this is just about the weirdest variation on Hansel & Gretel ever conceived.
Looking like a cross between "Mannix" and your grandfather's 8mm 'day at the beach' videos from 1975, Shadows Run Black is absolutely a terrible film.
Wanders and meanders and often threatens to roll to a complete stop - yet Roberts Blossom's inherent creepiness keeps things at least minimally compelling.
An unseemly vibe of failed comedic horror, or - depending on your point of view - successfully bad high camp, with an inordinate number of incongruous dance numbers.
So horrific are the musical sequences in this movie that you'll swear you were having nightmares directed by Satan himself.
Never once feels like more than push-button artifice.
Movies that just create silly fads are destined to linger long after their gimmicks have become jokes.
If ever there were a critic-proof movie, a film effectively ingrained into the pop culture world, it's Grease.
Scream Queen may be low-budget and a bit rough around the edges, but it's easily more amusing and endearing than 85% of what normally passes for "America's #1 Comedy Three Weeks in a Row!"
The last time I saw a movie this boring it turned out I was watching the oven.
Frankly I'm stunned that every American who paid to see it didn't file a class action suit against Tri-Star Pictures for their blatant misrepresentation of the word "comedy".
Costner approaches the project with an earnest nobility that's quite impressive, mainly because Earnest Nobility often becomes Unintentional Hilarity when coaxed too adamantly
For a comedy, it's surprisingly laugh-free and for an oh-so-message-laden tale of spoiled-gal redemption, it's irritatingly sincerity-free.
The best bits do eventually overshadow the interminable slow spots, and I'd certainly never be one to dissuade the faithful from seeing these two immortals duke it out on the big screen.
The plot is an overstuffed and undercooked collection of cop conventions all wrapped around a frankly boring tale of one sneering and villainous Frenchman.
50% homage to the classic science fiction touchstones and 50% damn solid in its own right.
Once the chases kick in and the invisible jet shows up, you'll have already withstood a healthy amount of yawns for your troubles.

The Morals of the Story are presented with a degree of craftiness generally unseen in most modern-day Family Flicks, and there's a refreshing lack of push-button pablum that one normally sees in movies of this sort.
It's not the best animated series you'll ever see, but it kept the X-Men fans happy enough before CGI allowed the cartoons to become live-action.
I can forgive a lot of low-rent banality when I have to, but I've never seen one iota of creativity or storytelling talent spring from the Olsen camp.
A whole lot of familiar pieces, all glued together quite neatly and delivered in a funny, breezy package.
Werewolves and Vampires and Katie ... oh my!
When he's not keening and shucking and jiving and behaving altogether spastically, Cuba kicks into full-on "dramatic mode" and the results are unquestionably more amusing.
Hardcore horror fans tired of the same old hack & slash may find something to enjoy here, though it's tough to imagine Average Joe Movie Renter getting a whole lot out of it.
When you fail at making bare breasts and plump butts somewhat interesting, I shudder to think of what the rest of the film looks like.
To be perfectly honest, Party Girl follows a fairly predictable narrative; the quality lies almost exclusively in the details.
If you don't find yourself giggling at the campy seriousness of it all, wait another five; it gets sillier as it goes.
It's weird and non-traditional, but its also effective and scary and clearly the work of someone who knows their way around a spooky visual nightmare.
The movie feels like a jigsaw puzzle with pieces that have been wedged together with a rubber mallet. Still, large sections of the puzzle mesh quite well and deliver some solid escapist fun.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: With Matchstick Men the destination is pretty clear; it's the travel time that's most entertaining.
You'll see it because you love Bill Murray. But somewhere about halfway through you'll realize that you're watching something much more than a dramatic vehicle for Hollywood's clown prince.
Has more highs than lows and earns some bravery points for having the stones to go 'ugly' once in a while.
The ABC's of the plot are nearly mystifying, and once you have everything figured out you'll realize that the end result was hardly worth all the effort.
The Creeper is quite the compelling little devil; too bad he's realized amidst such familiar trappings and tiresome caricatures.
The Crush would be an entirely worthless and painfully familiar little thriller even without its creepy devotion to the sexiness of youth.

Cold Steel is to movies what "Happy Birthday to You" is to music.
Once you see it, you'll have an enthusiastic new response when people ask you "Hmm, what's a good horror movie I've never seen?"
The flick seems like a long and well-told joke; one that's enjoyable to listen to despite the lack of a truly resounding punchline.
A low-rent shoot-'em-up that may actually be worthy of a 3-dollar rental!
Produced on the cheap and with very little insight into quality kid's entertainment, this one's a turkey that parents should be sure to avoid.
Easily one of the most entertaining (and presently overlooked) Westerns of the early 1970s.
A gruesome and gloriously reverent homage to the flesh-slurpin' subgenre created by good ol' George Romero.
Aside from a strangely eclectic collection of supporting actors, Worth Winning offers nothing you'd want to spend 90 minutes with.
Universal's classic tale of transparent antagonism...and its four unrelated sequels.
A modernized frat-boy version of Chinatown ... and I mean that in a good way.
A ruthless lesson about the power of violence, and the ways in which it's passed down from generation to generation: subtly, insidiously, and quite effectively.
It just might inspire you to think a little bit differently the next time you see a 60-year-old guy holding hands with a 30-year-old cutie.
If you just love the Alien Invasion stories, you could certainly do a whole lot worse. In fact, you probably have within the past year alone.
Unless you spend a lot of time at film festivals (or glued to the Sundance Channel), odds are you don't get to see many short films. And that's kind of a shame.

I think the world of entertainment can always use a few angry, gifted oddballs like Sandra Bernhard.
About as substantial as a puffy French pastry.
An absolute chore to sit through, unless you happen to come from the same block as the filmmakers, in which case you might produce a few charitable chuckles, just to be nice.

A mid-70s curiosity piece with lots of cows, gunfights, and a young Kurt Russell in silly costumes.
While not as aggressively mindless as many of its ilk, flick suffers from simple fatigue, as in: We're tired of seeing the exact same love story over and over.
A warm and witty little road comedy, full of silly side-trips, colorful characters, and just enough heart to keep the adventure afloat.
A perfectly outlandish and tight-knuckled action flick; a mindless piece of well-hewn escapism that delivers several borderline-retarded moments of mayhem.
The fact that you instantly like these spoiled little rich kids is a testament to Amy Heckerling's skills as a screenwriter.
The cast is charming and the presentation is unquestionably slick, but there's only so much talk of "doing it" one can take before you just wish "it" would get "done" already.

It takes a lot more to excite an audience than just a bunch of quote-worthy zingers.
The O.C. is slick, it's silly, and it's all but entirely superficial -- but it's also a good juicy soap-opera that fits like a tacky pair of slippers.
Exceedingly well-directed and periodically quite fascinating, yet almost helplessly lifeless in several spots.
A dreary little button-pusher laden with overbaked dramatics, coloring book plot conventions, and annoyingly simplistic answers to several truly difficult questions.
A multi-layered tale that's as compelling on a surface level as it is laden with food-for-thought underneath.
It's splattery and loud and frantic and laden with wall-to-wall gore of the nastiest kind. And yes, I mean that in the nicest way possible.
Certainly not bound for cineplex glory, but it's an 80-minute indie experiment that goes from mildly compelling to surprisingly engaging in rather subtle fashion.
But even with the Eagles on the losing side of the Super Bowl equation, this season gave the fans a whole LOT to cheer about.
Where you'll find a bunch of raucous and talented kids, you'll find at least one glory-hungry grown-up intent on stealing the spotlight.

...packs the sensation of shards of stained glass being wedged into your brain; Heartbeeps will, with very little effort, burn itself right into your next 15 nightmares
There's four or five episodes here that have real revisit value; the rest are perfectly watchable, but nothing more than that.
Entertaining only in an "OMG is this stupid" sort of way, this is a flimsy little biopic that tells us nothing new about a guy who has had more than enough press by now.
There must be a helluva lot of Mallrats fans out there, and I feel pretty confident in saying that they'll pretty much adore this new DVD edition.
There's just enough slicks and smarts in this movie to make you wish the rest of it weren't so darn stupid.
Cinema this toxic can either kill you with laughter or simply turn your brain into a pool of sex-obsessed pudding.
Justine Bateman keeps on singing throughout this freakishly banal flick, and each time it just gets funnier.
The sort of spooky flick you can watch in the dark with your pre-teen-ish progeny and not have to worry about the sex, smut, or splatter.
Some say this is a better-than-average film that effectively captures the tumultuous sixties and the young folks who were caught up in the craziness of it all. I don't see it.
Fun, stupid stuff with no sense of a narrative arc or plot structure ... but hey, it made me laugh anyway.
Didn't the first few Prophecy movies have Christopher Walken in them? That seems like 400 years ago, doesn't it?
Written, directed, lensed, and edited with all the grace of a drum-set falling down an elevator shaft.
Hardcore horror hounds will appreciate what Crease is attempting here ... even if they're not likely to walk away madly in love with the final result.
There's maybe three or four half-decent chuckles to be found in this otherwise interminable 90-minute mega-chore.
movie_title: Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in The Hood (1996)

movie_review_blurb: Visually gorgeous, stunningly violent, and entirely gripping throughout.
One of the finest actors working today, Christian Bale creates a character who's both hateful and despicable -- but you won't be able to take your eyes off the guy.
Tells the fascinating tale of a world-renowned sex-kitten, and it does so with copious doses of heart, wit, beauty, and a palpable sense of respect.
A grim, gruesome, and gloriously gross horror flick about mutated cows and the poor saps stuck on an isolated farm with the bloody bovines.
Packed with slick surprises, jarring jolts, gruesome gore, and unbearable tension, The Descent is one of the best horror films of the past several years.
Fans of the old show will doubtlessly enjoy adding this third and final DVD set to their "Happening!!" collection.
Everybody loves a good David & Goliath story, often doubly so when the story happens to be entirely factual and quite ironic.
You wanna know what real "movie magic" looks like? Rent yourself the entire Pixar collection and try not to spend the next eight hours grinning from ear to ear.
Personally, I think there's a haunting and fairly poignant story here; too bad it's surrounded by so many damn driving scenes.
The Cosby Show is great, hilarious, a true classic. But these DVDs offer the syndication edits and not the original NBC versions. Fans be warned.
It's not like the world's clamoring for yet another hopelessly arid serial killer procedural. Let alone one that stars John "Don't call me Cougar" Mellencamp.
A crystal-clear example of what happens when actors and filmmakers congregate with too much time on their hands.
Some would call it simplistic and silly; I think it's fairly clever and actually a little bit sweet. But hey, I've always had a soft spot for a good puppet show.
It's basically Scarface with a hip-hop mentality, but it's also a slickly entertaining and consistently engaging crime thriller.
It's boring, it's dreary, it's derivative, and it's kind of a slap in the face to the horror hounds -- because the flick barely runs 65 minutes in length.
It's fish in a barrel. Just trust me when I warn you never to rent, buy, or even discuss this mindless cinematic abomination.
movie_title: Miss Castaway and the Island Girls (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Aside from the 17 episodes, which you (probably) own already, there's an absolute treasure chest of all-new material here.
Frequently over-the-top and aggressively raucous, it's one of my very favorite comedies -- and musicals.

While The Jerk is an extremely episodic little movie, that's a malady easily forgiven -- simply because the episodes are so damn funny.
I had a ball with Sky High, and I suspect that lots of stunned moviegoers are going to walk out of the flick feeling the exact same way.
This movie hated me from the opening scene; two hours later, the feeling was more than mutual.
Curious horror fans will find themselves feeling oddly charitable once the flick draws to a close, even if they didn't exactly adore the thing.
A "What If?" peek at the beasts that might live on a planet six light-years away, Alien Planet is more than cool enough to keep the sci-fi geeks (like me) entertained.

It's a romantic epic, an intense and gripping look at WWI, and a nifty little mystery-quest all rolled into one.

The thing looks like it was written in a week, directed in two, and forgotten about by all involved in less than three.
Movies this bad should never be made -- and if they are, they should never be released. Except perhaps as some sort of Clockwork Orange-style prison experiment.
Hunter and Silver elevate this game into something pleasantly surprising.
Whichever network decided to ashcan this sorry experiment was on the right track; someone should have gone a step further and left it sitting on a shelf somewhere.
Frankly I never would have believed that Terry Gilliam had a movie this bad in him.
Just barely worth exploring. (On DVD, that is.)
Fun stuff indeed, even if you might need the subtitles to help decipher all the Britspeak.
Half a "kids gets lost in the woods" stalker-thriller and half a fairly amorphous "haunted patch of land" concept borrowed from an old Twilight Zone episode.
Needless to say this is a must-own box set for the Sox faithful; but those outside of the New England area might not really need over 38 hours of Red Sox mania.
It's Swamp Thing. It's not Swamp Hamlet or MacBeth Thing.
As formulaic and push-button-y as it is, it still houses some truly enjoyable movie-star chemistry,
Chatty, predictable, and seemingly comprised of three separate flicks jammed into one.
If you dig your cable flicks all but entirely prefabricated and astronomically predictable, feel free to give this one a shot.
I still say Season 1's better, but by this point I'm so invested in the tone, the humor, and the characters -- it would take a lot to knock me off the bandwagon now.
Basically, The Deal looks and sounds a whole lot like a big-budget, feature-length TV commercial for Merrill Lynch.
It's not high art -- but it IS pretty damn funny, and sometimes that's more than good enough.
The 40 Year-Old Virgin is one of the funniest movies I've ever seen. Yeah, I said it.
It's got some action, some romance, a few drips of comedy, and a lot of fascinating insight into a culture we know very little about.
Low-key, unassuming, and crafty in the way it slowly gets under your skin, Memories of Murder is a sly and smart thriller.
It's a quaint and pretty old movie, to be sure, but it's also more than a little boring.
A "grown-ups" sort of comedy, and one that delivers strangely satisfying laughs while always putting character above all else.

A unique and quietly memorable multi-character study.

A very dry and formulaic re-telling of a cautionary tale we know all too well by now.
If Bujalski's goal was to create a "you are there (and eavesdropping)" sort of narrative, he's done a fine job of it.
Feels like something that Hughes slapped together over the course of one weed-filled weekend. It's a novelty flick, but a fairly funny one ... for the most part.
Broad, bubbly, and kind of adorable.
Equal parts funny, smart and sincere, it's a movie that delved a little deeper into the teenage psyche and came back with something more challenging than "nerds want sex."
If I were still 12 years old, "Zathura" would be my new favorite movie, and even at 12, I had very good taste in movies.
Epic wartime storytelling at its most vibrant and satisfying.
movie_title: The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957)

movie_review_blurb: There's no real "action" to speak of, aside from a few fistfights and the third act bombing attack, but From Here to Eternity sure isn't boring.
The Guns of Navarone has long been a big-time favorite of the war-movie aficionados, and the film still holds up resoundingly well today.
Despite what the back of the DVD case says, the flick's not really a "nail-biter," nor is it "throbbing with passion and thrills." (Who writes this stuff anyway?)
Anzio's not exactly considered a "classic" in the war-story genre, but it'll absolutely do for a rainy Saturday matinee.
THE submarine movie. No other sub-flick even comes close.
If the movie suffers from mild aimlessness and editorial confusion, and it does, those are relatively small speed bumps to endure for such a canny and quick-witted affair.
If you're the sort who likes to dig around in the bottoms of barrels, here's a grungy little exploitationer that may wring a few chuckles out of you.
Worthwhile mainly as a historical piece for the old-school Lenny Bruce buffs, the 60-minute Performance Film is infinitely more heartbreaking than it is funny.
You've never heard of it, you'll never rent it, and you certainly won't miss it.
The first movie at least offers the shorts in their original form; the other flick ... terrible stuff across the board.
The brilliant WB shorts are chopped, edited, and otherwise altered to fit this shamelessly inept compilation flick. Stick with the originals, trust me.
The first (and easily the best) of the Looney Tunes compilation flicks.
Boo's not among the best horror flicks I've seen this year, but it's actually better than several that played the multiplexes.
A classic wartime drama / courtroom gripper that I'm ashamed to admit I'd never seen before last week. And now that I have, I'm a big fan.
A brave and well-constructed piece of old-time movie-making, and the thing more than holds up today.
movie_title: The Man With the Golden Arm (1955)

movie_review_blurb: I've re-visited at least a dozen old cartoon characters in the past few years, and aside from the Looney Tunes, none of 'em hold up as well as T & J still do.
Every bit the warm, comfortable, and tragically bittersweet classic that had you sobbing like a infant the first time you saw it.
Human beings did this.
Worthy of attention from only the staunchest of '80s archivists.
Might wring a few chuckles out of you, but certainly not much more than a few.
One of the stupidest, sloppiest, skankiest, and most amazingly unfunny comedies I've ever seen.
Starts out as humorless, graduates into obnoxious, and ends up on just the other side of agony.
Blizzard is the "annual fruitcake" of kid's Christmas movies: sticky, ugly, and entirely confusing ... as in "Who thought I'd actually enjoy this fruitcake?"
A bunch of grown-up kids who break down the fanciest toys under the sun, and then build 'em back up into something outrageously cool.
"Evil Never Tasted So Good! Gary Busey is The Gingerdead Man!" - That's what you'll see if, for some ungodly reason, you happen to be holding the latest Charles Band DVD.
Palance, Pleasance, and Landau ensure that, while it might get a little dry and silly at times, Alone in the Dark sure isn't boring.
Good intentions and multi-culturalism are great and all, but a comedy's first goal is to, y'know, make people laugh.
'Pan & scanning' West Side Story is like peeing on a Picasso.
The shameless way in which the producers treat Mr. Lee's memory will absolutely leave a nasty taste in your mouth.
Aside from a few clumsy insert shots, Bruce Lee doesn't even appear until the final 20 minutes!
Certainly the only movie in history to have Bruce Lee and Chuck Norris do battle in the Roman Colosseum.
movie_title: Return of the Dragon (The Way of the Dragon) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Semi-speed through the "chatty" stuff if you absolutely must, but be sure not to miss any of the mayhem.
It's Bruce vs. a whole army of lowlife thugs after they mess with his cousins, and Mr. Lee pulls off some truly amazing butt-kickery here.
movie_title: The Big Boss (Tang shan da xiong) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: The sort of documentary that informs and educates through sheer passion, excitement, and, yes, downright funkiness.
If you think I'm overpraising the show, just pop two of these discs in your player and email me in the morning.
A sly, sweet, and consistently enlightening documentary about family, love, and religion ... and a couch.
Anyone with a healthy respect for the game of professional basketball should find a lot to enjoy in this globetrottin' documentary.
movie_title: Harlem Globetrotters: The Team that Changed the World (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Still packed with that patented Disney Nature Quaintness, Sam isn't a terrible follow-up, but it lacks the spine that the grown-ups brought to the first film.
I've absolutely no problem recommending this sequel to those who adored the first entry, or anyone just looking for a cold blast of unfiltered horror nastiness.
It sure isn't what you'd call a "good film," but Species 3 has the sense to deliver the goods.
The sequel ups the "silly" ante without bringing any new brains to the table.
As slyly smart as it is silly, and the flick delivers a clever idea that's wedged in between some rather slick action scenes.
A comedic horror sci-fi mixture that manages to be sly, stupid, obvious, and creative -- often all at the same time.
As a parody of the corporate restaurant scene, Waiting has more than enough snarky insight (and laughs) to balance its numerous and often unnecessary trips to the potty
OK, I'll admit it: I've next to no idea what to make of Palindromes, and you know what? I doubt the filmmaker would have a problem with me owning up to it.
Offers some witty banter, a few fine performances from some "no-name" actors, and just enough low-budget goodwill to keep the adventurous movie-watchers entertained.
Even if you find yourself somewhat wrapped up in the minuscule narrative, you'll have little trouble noticing that even the most nominal sequences ... run ... on ... forever.
movie_title: The Bizarre Lust of a Sexual Deviant (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The sound of a flushing toilet became MWC's signature running gag. I don't really think one has to elaborate on that...
A great story told by a master filmmaker; sterling actors playing some truly fascinating characters; and a bunch of cinematic set-pieces that are worthy of repeat viewings.
Evil Dead 2 is a grade-A masterpiece of morbid mayhem. Find me a horror geek who doesn't agree and I'll take a chainsaw to a body part of your choice.
With this box set on your shelf, you'll always have something painfully hilarious to watch. Now surely that's worth 120 measly bucks.
Love it or hate it, there's no denying that the art of "body reconstruction" is pretty darn fascinating.
They don't have to be masterworks, but honestly: a 62-minute movie is not what the genre fans are looking for.
Here's hoping Short's next project is more worthy of the guy's skills, because this Jiminy Glick character grows real old, real fast.
The cleverest, crankiest, wittiest, wildest, and most character-driven sci-fi adventure in 25 years; it's the best outer-space trip I've been on since the empire struck back.
The protagonists are paper-thin caricatures; the villains are ridiculously, stupidly, evil; the plot is dirt-dry and predictable; and the hairstyles are just plain nutty.
Four strong performances from four young actresses aside, there's nothing here that you haven't seen before, better, and with a lot more sincerity.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Arguably one of the best dramatic films ever made, brought home with tons of great features, a sparkling new transfer, and a nifty fold-out case.
It's not high art, but it's a heckuva lot better than what generally passes for your average weeknight sitcom.
Yes, all of our DVD collections can now be complete with the addition of one of the '80s lamest, blandest, and most TV-movie-ish flicks ever made: Pulse.
I seriously doubt there's any fresh blood to be wrung out of the Dr. Jekyll & Mr. Hyde conceit, even IF you're willing to fill your rendition with tons of naked women.
No amount of bells & whistles can salvage a screenplay this half-baked.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Just because a movie is made "campy" and "bad" on purpose, that doesn't automatically earn the flick some sort of Get Out of Jail Free card.
Aside from a few strong performances and some solid period design, Rise to Power is a round, silver sleeping pill.
This movie takes a solid three hours to tell a story that could have (easily) been disseminated in about thirty minutes.
Features seven classic shorts from the Disney vault, three of which were made available on earlier DVD collections, and four that are making their digital debut.
movie_title: Classic Cartoon Favorites: Holiday Celebration With Mickey & Pals (2005)

movie_review_blurb: An offbeat experiment that, while certainly not a brilliant movie, flies far more than it fails.
A welcome return to form from a really talented guy who's been churning out cinematic junk for the past few years.
After seeing and enjoying Lebowksi at least four times over the years, I can plainly see why the movie freaks have embraced this off-kilter comedy so enthusiastically.
Hey, if the Veggie Tales folks can sell religion in this fashion, then I say the environmental lobby deserves their fair shot as well.
If you really dig the newer Zorro exploits, there's very little reason to think you wouldn't enjoy a nostalgic trip back to the guy's earlier screen adventures.
Forget dumb, stupid, loud, and endlessly derivative. I can live with those. But boring? I just didn't see that one coming.
If this collection represents the best of three full seasons, then I imagine watching a normal Saturday night episode must be an amazingly depressing activity.
All I'm saying is that "sitting still in one place" is perhaps not the best showcase for the wonder that is female nakedness.
The thrills, chills, and intermittent gore-spills are way too few and far between to keep the loyal horrorheads from getting restless.
The sort of flick that the lovable old MST3K boys would have dismissed as "way too easy."
movie_title: Blood of Beasts (Beauty and the Beast) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Three parts Child's Play, one part The Omen, and eleventy-million parts of plain old terrible.
A solid body count, some gruesome gore, and a few familiar faces to keep the thing moving along smoothly.
By the time the few cases of carnage are unleashed, you'll most likely be well past REM sleep and dreaming of better horror flicks.
As an early-80s footnote to a sub-genre that spawned some truly disturbing horror movies, you could probably do worse. (Like, say, Mother's Day.)
When it's not ripping off better movies, it's meandering around in a barn and grinding to an endless halt.
Horror remakes like this one paint all the others with a huge and objectionable brush, because this flick absolutely stinks of half-hearted effort and assembly-line cynicism.
A whole lotta sound and fury signifying not only nothing ... but a very raucous, insistent, and gratingly redundant nothing.
Re-packaged into one box-set for those who need both volumes, Best of the Chris Rock Show is 2+ hours of raunchy Rock goodness.
Those who hold this classic sitcom in high regard should absolutely consider this full Season 2 set a must-own.
Cohen is a sly and slick rabble-rouser, and one with a gift for quick-witted comedy schtick, surprisingly subtle insights, and off-the-cuff hilarity. Respeck.
A fine, forgotten sitcom that features some stellar work from one of our great, overlooked character actors: Dabney Coleman.
Did I miss something? In the original Single White Female, did Jennifer Jason Leigh NOT play a psycho?
The Little One is the real find within this three-cartoon collection, but the other pair are more than enjoyable enough -- particularly if you're a hardcore Disneyfan.
movie_title: Walt Disney's Classic Cartoon Favorites - Classic Holiday Stories (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Pretty entertaining for the most part -- even if you'll be laughing at the movie as much as you are with it.

Frankly, I think it's one of the coolest TV series of the past ten years.

Fans of scientific speculation, both practical and/or fantastical, could do a lot worse than giving these discs a spin.
The old flicks were entertaining by accident because they tried to be good. The new ones tried to be awful on purpose ... and they succeeded all too well.
Unquestionably bad, but fans of the genre will have a good time.
movie_title: 2019 - Dopo la caduta di New York (After the Fall of New York) (1983)

movie_review_blurb: Seems like Mr. Schroder's about one step away from the "Casper Van Dien" realm of moviemaking.

2.5 half-watchable action scenes surrounded by the ever-reliable packing materials of aimless dialogue, boring characters, and insipid bouts of rambling exposition.
The sets look like plaster, the actors look like accountants, and the monster looks like the 9th place winner at your local Halloween Ball.

I could name about a half-dozen horror movies that are very similar in story to Reeker, but this one's an improvement over most of those flicks.

,,,bashes right through "unknowingly hilarious" and speeds right down the highway of slack-jawed awfulness. Truly amusing stuff.

...three or four bits of high-end grue surrounded by a whole lot of white noise.

movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: xXx: State of the Union is better than the first entry, which is sort of like saying a mallet to the scalp is better than a hammer.

So predictably beholden to its predecessor that you can practically smell the reek of formula cooling on its hide.

movie_review_blurb: Two solid flicks, two ridiculous sequels and a fistful of extra goodies; you're looking at a deal that can't be beat. Not even with the dreaded crane technique.

movie_title: Ring of Fire: The Emile Griffith Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: ...and here I thought I was going to see an actual raven...dancing!
Please take notes because you will be tested as the end of the movie.
The Mirror Mirror series has reached its moronic conclusion.
The most unintentionally hilarious biblical epic ever to grace the silver screen.
Better than most SNL flotsam, but surely that's not saying much.
A few solid punch lines get lost amid the stupidity.
You'll feel like you're eavesdropping.
Cornball camp classic.
Early Coppola horror tale that suffers from overt silliness.
Eerie, atmospheric ancestor to the slasher flick.
movie_title: Blood and Black Lace (Sei donne per l'assassino) (1964)

movie_review_blurb: Lovable old serial adventures from yesteryear.
Are romantic comedies supposed to give you the willies?
'Are you eating it? Or is it eating you?' I love it!
One of the funniest dramas you'll ever see.
Preachy and loud, yet surprisingly entertaining.
Hmmm. Horror movies and soft-core porn. There's a great idea.
Mistaken identities and double entendres, circa 1948.
Well-structured war tale with star turns by Washington and Ryan.
A trip back to a sillier era.
Underwater slimies eat everyone. A sly sense of humor helps immeasurably.
Money grubbing sequelitis at its most pathetic.
movie_title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Creepy horror classic that's just plain fun to watch.
A wonderfully complex and startlingly visionary epic. I love this movie.
Call it a near-miss.
An epic of human proportions.
Sly, good-natured and fun, despite the presence of Tim Allen.
Every bit THE classic.
Darabont and King go to prison. Heck, it worked the first time!
Someone kick that soapbox out from under Spike already.
The world's most honest sitcom.
This COULD have been that one awesome pro football movie we've been waiting for.
A movie review comprised entirely of sarcasm.
Not to be mistaken for any movie that has a gun in it.
There's a solid 95-minute movie buried somewhere in here.
aka The Jim Carrey Show!
The high-flying fun is limited solely be the poultry running time.
Unjustly lambasted comic insanity.
Wilder and Kidder in a bizarre romantic comedy.
movie_title: Quackser Fortune Has a Cousin in the Bronx (1970)

movie_review_blurb: I stunned myself by really enjoying this one.
You'll never look at a pool cue the same way again.
Preachy and predictable.
Shudderingly awful. You'll need a shower.
Winning performances save it from fading into treacle.
Carpenter's classic concerning killer cars.
Whine. Whine. Have Sex. Whine.
A movie you've never heard of starring a band nobody remembers.
Don't believe the backlash. This is one dark and disturbing horror flick.
Anyone out there buy David Spade as a romantic lead? OK, didn't think so.
A testament to the fine art of screenwriting.
The world's first hockey sitcom movie.
How could these two guys NOT be funny? See the movie and find out.
Teenage girls whine and pout in prison. Not as fun as it sounds.
More yawn-inducing than fifty people yawning.
Some movies are worth seeing just for the actors.
One of the more obnoxious movies of the past 200 years.
A worthy sequel to the classic cartoon.
Quite possibly the worst theatrical release that I've ever seen.
Disturbingly smart and joyously weird. A true original.
Strays from the source material, but still a creepy classic.
Sweet natured, raunchy and fall-down funny.
How can we make an entire motion picture based solely on a woman's rear end?
Hardcore masterpiece.
Is 'Lake Flaccid' too obvious of a pun?
More of a remake than a sequel, but pretty weak either way.
What the hell did I just watch?
More tough-guy stuff inspired by Tarantino.
movie_title: Things to Do in Denver...When You're Dead (1995)

movie_review_blurb: One of the stupidest movies you'll ever see. Bad, bad, bad.
This girl could make millions doing Band-Aid commericals.
Not the sextet's finest effort, but still drop-dead funny.
movie_title: Monty Python's The Meaning of Life (1983)

movie_review_blurb: If this movie doesn't put you to sleep, you're more than human.
It's perhaps ironic that a film about love, truth and reality would be so devoid of true emotion, especially considering the filmmaker behind the camera.
The Royal Tenenbaums is equal parts smart, silly, sardonic and sweet. It's a scathing dark comedy, a twisted sitcom, an arcane farce and even a touching romance.
Although the movie grinds down to a snail's pace on occasion, there's more than enough patriotic gunplay for a WWII buff to get behind.
If you're the sort who can enjoy an old-fashioned ghost story without speeding right to the 'good parts,' The Fog is a highly recommended little shocker.
A ghost story this hypnotically effective is cause for celebration, particularly if you're a horror fan patiently digging through the scrap heaps looking for something worthy of your time.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The creature is about as horrifying as Miss Piggy covered in barbecue sauce.
If you've ever been curious to see what Jason Voorhees would look like if he were played by a supermodel, this one's worth a look
Most importantly of all things, the ORIGINAL unaltered, unblemished, and gloriously widescreen 1982 version is included, so all complaints are tempered with a sense of overall satisfaction.
The bulk of this 50-minute piece focuses on the actual crashes and subsequent collapses, with an analytical eye on specifically what caused the most destruction.
movie_title: World Trade Center: Anatomy of the Collapse (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Think of the Sleepaway Camp trilogy as a live-action version of the "Itchy & Scratchy" cartoons that the Simpson kids love so much.
On a 'normal movie' scale, it'd rate Sleepaway Camp II pretty damn low, but the healthy body count and copious gore rates this a "Must-See" for any self-respecting horror freak.
When Sleepaway Camp focuses on something other than the rapidly growing pile of corpses, the movie nearly grinds to a halt.
If Dangerous Lady is a typical example of British 'made-for-TV' productions, they've got us Yanks beat hands down.
The Razor's Edge may be a truncated and somewhat episodic adaptation, but it's certainly compelling enough to keep you involved for a solid two hours.
Joyride plows through its crime flick checklist of unsavory characters and rote plot divergences with a dreary efficiency.
If there's one saving grace of Comic Book Villains (and it's a big one), it's the eclectic group of cool indie actors populating the farce.
This flick holds the record for 'most bad guys standing in a circle waiting to get kicked'.
By the time the mysteries are solved, you won't only be confused; you simply won't care anymore.
Those looking for a comfortably familiar spin on the old 'double indemnity' device may enjoy Cause of Death one late night on HBO, though it's hardly worthy of a special trip to the DVD store.
Not only does 24 rank among television's most successful experiments, but the viewing experience is improved exponentially now that the show is on DVD.
There are much better 80's horror flicks to spend your money on, but April Fool's Day has enough jolts and twists to warrant a look.
It involves Satan, a possessed woman's tongue and a billy goat's butthole. Again, the distinction between scary and unpleasant becomes revoltingly clear.
Not at all clear what it's trying to say and even if it were - I doubt it would be all that interesting.
Imagine watching Cameron's The Terminator, only all the characters are now naked Asian hookers who use bulbous vibrators instead of machine guns.
A leering, pandering and altogether bizarre jiggle production that's as irrepressibly weird as it obsessed with all things breast- (and panty-) related.
Best described as an ungainly Japanese version of "Red Shoe Diaries", Tokyo Decameron is tiresome, poorly acted and not very sexy at all.
movie_title: Tokyo Decameron: Three Tales of Madness and Sensuality (1996)

movie_review_blurb: Calm down people; the title's the only controversial aspect of this one.
The movie has a handful of cool moments - punctuated by long and familiar bouts of B-movie machinations, to say nothing of the annoyingly stutter-step narration.
It seems clear that writer/ director Don Gronquist is fascinated by the history of the Nazi Party; it's just too bad his enthusiasm for the topic never comes across in his film.
Best described as "Survivor" meets The Running Man by way of your local mall's Halloween Adventure Shop, Slashers represents low-grade horror machinations at their most confoundingly stupid.
Webster's Dictionary doesn't contain enough adjectives to describe how boring this film is.
Sure, calling a film "better than Bloodfist 8" is damning with faint praise, but fans of genre-melding B-grade kickboxing flicks may find a little something to enjoy.
A terminally awful piece of filmmaking, but that's not to say you won't find moments of unintentional hilarity so profound they'll move you to tears.
Fingers works for a handful of reasons - not the least of which is a phenomenal early performance by Harvey Keitel.
Best suited for those who can recall their stifling and intense Catholic School education from back in the day, Altar Boys is certainly a worthwhile way to spend 90-some minutes.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Often regarded as the forgotten stepchild of cult favorite Pretty in Pink, Some Kind of Wonderful is notable in that it's an improvement over its inspiration in every conceivable capacity.
Nine-year-old kids may sit through it and have fun, but nine-year-olds would also eat french fries 23 hours a day if their parents didn't force them to try something more nutritious.
So horrific are the Olsen flicks that their only logical use could be as "bad-behavior deterrents" (As in: "Behave yourself or I'll put on that Olsen twins movie!")
One of the sorriest cartoons I've ever witnessed... and I lived through The Care Bears!
movie_title: Mummy: Quest for the Lost Scrolls (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A movie more earnest and well-meaning than wholly successful, Zebrahead is still worthy of praise - if only for treating its teenagers like actual people.
The Golden Bowl may not be the most exciting movie you'll ever see, but those who pay attention should find themselves pleasantly rewarded.
Ranks among the best crime films of the late 1970s...and that puts the flick among some rather impressive company.

A fellow critic sitting a few seats down leaned over to me and muttered "This has got to be a parody, right?" while dozens of 'normal moviegoers' were content to giggle at the wackily earnest exchanges offered onscreen.
The Last Picture Show is a stark and hypnotic portrait of a West Texas town in its final death throes, a lyrical and touching film about friendship and love and sex. Texasville is about nothing.
Panderingly kid-centric and obnoxious commercialism at its most profitable.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Movie (1990)

movie_review_blurb: Two essentially unrelated tales jammed serviceably into one rather bizarre film.
The Oblong Box is a lot more fun than I expected it to be, and it's certainly worth a look if you're a horror fan grown weary of the same old thing.
Overt societal disillusionment with a healthy dose of violently expressed xenophobia. Understood.
Sets up its mysteries with an admirable tenacity, though the resolution we're ultimately offered is more than a bit forgettable.
Black Point isn't awful enough to incite any enthusiastic irritation, but it's also not a film you'll remember two days later.
Well-crafted adventures have always been the trademark of this superlative sci-fi program; season four is where the characters really started to shine.
According to the cuddly sweet family flick Race to Space, the birth of the United States space program was important only in relation to a silly monkey and his 12-year-old pal.
Sit through this one, and you won't need a magic watch to stop time; your DVD player will do it for you.
Imagine The Three Stooges by way of 'The New Yorker' magazine, and you're getting close.
I guess if you've seen one "Midwest town overtaken by maniacal senior-citizen Satan worshippers" flick, you've seen 'em all.
Getting There is an awful movie by any measure; the Olsen twins' vacuous presence makes it outright torture.
Personal and compelling admissions from a collection of creators who've more than earned their stripes.
If you like your movies described as "quirky" and "kinda weird", here's a not-awful dark comedy that at the very least, offers one enjoyably bizarre cast.
Perhaps it's only because I see five movies a week that are even stupider than Federal Protection that I can give it a mild recommendation.
If the plot structure of UHF leaves something to be desired, that's okay because we're offered a mostly hilarious series of Saturday Night Live-style television parodies.
A damn good movie, one that looks at this infamous war through the eyes of one gradually enlightened aristocrat.
It's not deep, and it's far from original, but Hughes' word processor apparently still had a little magic left in it.
A rousing adventure epic, one that combines big-budget thrills with a welcome sense of historical accuracy.
If an atrocious movie were intentionally atrocious, does that make it any less painful to sit through?
movie_title: Mari-Cookie and the Killer Tarantula in 8 Legs to Love You (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Proof positive that the 'muddled crime drama/mystery/thriller' is not a uniquely American concept.
No Contest is proof positive that not only is it completely fine to blatantly rip off a movie, but the copycats need not even TRY to hide their plagiarism.
If the idea of a rock star and a supermodel spending a week together in one room sounds sort of intriguing, this is a scrappy little indie you might want to search out.
The trio of actors keep things moving along nicely, and you'll find yourself wanting to see how it all ends. If a movie can accomplish that one simple task, it's probably a fairly good movie.
Another fondly remembered Disney flick absolutely flushed down the toilet by a pathetic full frame transfer. Sad news indeed.
Old people will love this movie, and I mean that in the nicest possible way: Last Orders will touch the heart of anyone old enough to have earned a 50-year friendship.
Most stunning is how abruptly the film ends, but I suppose that's to be expected when a production simply runs out of money.
Sure it's a good movie...if you've never seen one mystery flick in your entire life!
Who knew cannibalism could be so damn boring?
movie_title: Welcome to Arrow Beach (Tender Flesh) (Cold Storage) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Will appeal most to those with a passion for jazz music, but I'm living proof that even the uninitiated will appreciate what Botti has to offer.
movie_title: Chris Botti & Friends - Night Sessions: Live in Concert (2001)

movie_review_blurb: What may have seemed horrific in 1973 comes off today as more than a little ridiculous.
The plot-heavy narrative throws a half dozen characters into the mix, all of whom are either A) vampire lesbians, B) a werewolf, or C) soon to be dead.
movie_title: La noche de Walpurgis (The Werewolf Versus the Vampire Woman) (1971)

movie_review_blurb: Hats off to Newvideo and Docurama for giving the Marley fans a DVD package worth treasuring.
Whoever said 'blondes have more fun' may have been right, but that doesn't mean we have to PAY to watch it happen in such trivial fashion.
Fans of non-traditional 'mini-cinema' should find something to enjoy in this eclectic compilation of Nick Lyon's work.
movie_title: Hellchild - The World of Nick Lyon (2002)

movie_review_blurb: This superlative 2-disc set ranks among my favorite DVDs of 2002, and I absolutely recommend it as a purchase.
movie_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975)

movie_review_blurb: An altogether hilarious concoction that features Dan Aykroyd at his strongest, Eddie Murphy at his freewheeling funniest, and director John Landis at the absolute top of his game.
I'm not saying that fans should avoid this DVD (as if I could even talk you out of it), but considering the movie - this DVD should be a hell of a lot better.
Tokyo Olympiad is a stunning testament - both to the Olympic athletes it focuses on, and the craft of artistic documentary filmmaking.
If you're judging a piece of entertainment based solely on the number of nude lesbians it contains, the Seduction Cinema flicks come out on top.
To classify this movie as gory would be to describe Anna Nicole Smith as 'slightly obnoxious'. There are sequences in Premutos that would put a seasoned coroner off his lunch.
The Initiation is the worst kind of bad movie in that it often seems like two entirely different bad movies mashed together into one ungainly chore.
The first indication that you're watching a film impossible to be taken seriously is that William Baldwin gets top billing.
The film opens with some intriguing and old-fashioned credits set to an ominous score. That's the high point.
Recorded in January 2001 before over 250,000 (!) fans, this is a concert that should thrill fans of this celebrated Heavy Metal band, be they old-school headbangers or neophyte rockers.
Catch it on cable late one night, enjoy the performances of Sutherland and Mitchell, and then move on to something a bit better.
It's the mood, atmosphere, and attitude that make the Zatoichi movies so damn cool.
movie_title: The Tale of Zatoichi Continues (Zoku Zatôichi monogatari) (1962)

movie_review_blurb: Though The Tale of Zatoichi features a few exciting action sequences, this is more of a moody character study than an outright karate flick.
Literally nothing in The Pool is new, but if you grew up on the stalker flicks of the 1980's this one should appease you for 90 minutes.
Woe is any parent who's forced to sit through this ridiculously plotted and criminally overlong spectacle.
A solid hour-long documentary, and one that offers a few surprises between the fascinating conversations.
movie_title: Picture This: The Times of Peter Bogdanovich (1991)

movie_review_blurb: Those with an affinity for 1960's kitsch will most definitely want to give this 32-episode set a spin.
If it's up to me, my kids are watching nothing but The Princess Bride and The Simpsons.
Perhaps best described as "The Simpsons meets Monty Python by way of Wallace & Gromit," Rex the Runt is a decidedly loopy production from the fine and clever folks over at Aardman studios.
The only thing wrong with this 11-hour cinematic mammoth is that it's not longer.
Enjoyable thanks to three fantastic performances, a handful of fairly amusing moments, and an interesting glimpse behind the scenes of the stand-up comedy industry.
Hardihood has the feel of a well-edited and polished home movie, one that spends a lot of time celebrating its subjects - without giving the audience much reason to do the same.
Much of the film's entertainment value lies in watching two familiar guys (Cusack and Spader) playing switcheroo with their stock roles, but the movie is more than just effective 'gimmick casting'.
Does anyone working for Seduction Cinema know what the word "erotic" even means?
Your kids should have a ball watching this wacky seal behaving like a family dog, and any movie that can make your kids giggle is probably worthy of a look.
High praise is due to the filmmakers for simply presenting the visual facts of this tragedy. This is not some garish depiction of mangled bodies and massive explosions.
Strictly Sinatra is certainly better than mediocre and it's often quite entertaining, but it's not precisely cause for a stampede to the video store.
The two leads make Best Seller easy to sit through, but the wandering script by Larry Cohen and the dreary pacing offered by director John Flynn sink what could have been a can't-miss b-movie hoot.

I've long since given up looking for quality entertainment in the wares of Seduction Cinema, and now I judge the films based solely on the quality of the 'nude content' and the sexiness of the non-stop lesbian activity.
What does it take for a movie to be destined to an eternity in a vault somewhere? Lots of things.

This movie's gotta be the result of some pot-induced wager between Adam Sandler and his nattering cronies: "Hey guys, I'm like a $20 million movie star! How freakin' FUNNY is that? I bet I can make ANY movie I want!"
You could film the cast of this movie in a LIBRARY for 90 minutes and I guarantee it'd be funnier than what's on display here.
The gloom of Batman! The wiriness of Spider-Man! The croaking irritability of Charles Bronson! Daredevil provides all three! (And considerably less...)

One of the biggest joys here is the conversion of Adam Goldberg from 'colorful backup' to 'comic action hero', and while The Hebrew Hammer may not vault the actor into leading man status, he easily carries the entire movie.
I'm all for the mentally challenged getting their fair shot in the movie business, but surely it doesn't have to be as a collection of keening and self-mutilating sideshow geeks.
Rarely do you see a film that combines graphic sex and cannibal gore to such grisly effect, and that may be a good thing, but it's important to praise a movie for what it gets right.
Kinda sad that this endearingly strange flick will be remembered as one of the "worst ever", yet XXX is considered a good movie because it was profitable.

Laden with decidedly harsh and bizarre humor, clever and colorful visual touches, and a loving devotion to the foibles of the modern American family, Malcolm in the Middle is a lot more than a solid TV comedy.

What a novel conceit: take exactly what's wrong with modern horror movies (i.e. boredom and predictability) and flip the proverbial script on 'em. The beauty of the Final Destination flicks is that anyone can die at any time - and often do.
A movie sort of paints itself into a corner when characters repeatedly look directly at the camera and yell None of this is real! It's all just a test!
It was only a matter of time before some savvy producer saw the potential success inherent in the mixture of Bullock Bubble and Hugh Goo.
My mouth slowly widened, until I realized that I was indeed illustrating what "jaw-droppingly bad" truly means.

A Foreign Affair is an altogether enjoyable diversion, a light and clever comedy that offers some great performances in a unique setting. Plus it's about ten times more sincere and entertaining than what passes for romantic comedy these days.
Although the movie does manage to retain a small amount of the original show's innocent camp charm, this meandering production offers as many yawns as it does giggles.
Due specific praise is the simple look of the movie, as if a meagre budget and disrespected genre were no impediment to making a visually arresting movie.
movie_title: The Masque of the Red Death (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Sure, this one's got gore galore and a boatload of atrocious acting performances to giggle at, but without Jason doing the stalking - it's just not a Friday the 13th movie.
movie_title: Jason Goes to Hell - The Final Friday (1993)

movie_review_blurb: The main problem with Stargate is not with set-up, but with execution. After a while you feel like you're just watching weird people staggering around a desert.

Seeing as I'm a 31-year-old Jewish cynic from Philadelphia, it's plainly obvious that I am not the intended audience for Jonah: A VeggieTales Movie. But I know a feature-length advertisement when I see one.

There's no denying that May is simply NOT a film for all tastes, but if you like your genres stewed together and cooked into a film so sinfully wonderful that it defies description, I absolutely recommend you search this one out as soon as possible
Given that the current state of American Horror is usually so watered-down and generic, even a 'pretty good' horror import is reason to rejoice.
Easily one of the most vile experiences I've ever had in a movie theater.

If Duvall's presence in films that are clearly beneath him are necessary in order for him to produce flicks like The Apostle and Assassination Tango, I certainly hope Jerry Bruckheimer never loses his phone number.

The direction by first-timer Eli Roth belies a lifetime spent adoring the finest horror flicks under the sun, and the screenplay is laden with homages and references guaranteed to tickle even the most jaded horror aficionado.

It irritates and saddens me that Martin Lawrence's latest vehicle can explode obnoxiously into 2,500 screens while something of Bubba Ho-Tep's clearly evident quality may end up languishing on a shelf somewhere.

Equally insulting to both races, Bringing Down the House is one of the most hateful and low-minded comedies I've ever seen - and it absolutely earns a spot right next to the justifiably loathed Amos & Andrew.
I suppose if a movie has entirely vanished from memory not 24 hours after it's been viewed, that's its own review right there.
A lot more entertaining than first looks would indicate. Plus it's always fun to laugh at the 1980s.
Like many of its immediate ilk, this one's stagy and outdated and kinda silly - in other words, good stuff.
If Wrath of Khan is the 'action' entry and Voyage Home is the 'comedy' installment, then Search for Spock is the 'drama' - and it's a damn good entry overall.
movie_title: Star Trek III - The Search for Spock (1984)

movie_review_blurb: A handful of truly inspired moments and performances - ensconsed in a painfully languid pace and surrounded by more than a few jarringly schizophrenic mood swings.
Calling this a Pinhead flick is like calling The Muppet Movie a Steve Martin vehicle. The end credits of Hellseeker have more screen time than does the prickly villain.
After about 55 minutes of biblically awful dialogue and paint-by-numbers plot points, the plane crash-lands in a giant swamp. Yes, the Death Swamp!
