A bloated and outdated pastiche of tired slapstick, obvious misogyny and painfully unfunny smarm.
Dreary suburban drama with a goopy horror finale, Society seems to be about a whole lot of ideas - when in truth it presents one or two pedestrian concepts and then repeats them ad nauseum.

So we got Ten Little Indians meets Friday the 13th by way of Clean and Sober, filmed on the set of Carpenter's The Thing and loaded with actors you're most likely to find on the next inevitable incarnation of The Love Boat.
Blood Work is a lot like a well-made PB & J sandwich: familiar, fairly uneventful and boasting no real surprises - but still quite tasty and inviting all the same.
Recommended solely to those who aspire for a career in blood-packets and explosions of green bile, Legion of the Dead is just a mess - in every sense of the word.
movie_title: Legion of the Dead (Le6ion of the Dead) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Simply put, Darkness Falls is like that snake that eats itself: by the time minute 80 hits the screen, you'll have completely forgotten about minutes 1 through 10.
Interested in watching a documentary about a dozen guys who grew up in 1950's Brighton Beach? Yeah, neither was I... for the first five minutes.

One of those undemanding pieces of entertainment that somehow creep up on you and force you to like them. This one's doubly recommended to those familiar with the joys and sorrows affiliated with sports betting.
Best described as Ordinary People meets Breaking Away (minus the bicycles).
Who ever knew graphic lesbianism could be some damn tedious?
Not nearly as extreme as its title and reputation suggest, Cannibal Apocalypse is a whole lotta chit-chat and very little people-chomping - though the gory moments are gruesome indeed.

June 1967 saw thousands of mellow music fans travel to a small California town to enjoy three days of music. Fortunately for those of us who weren't there, filmmaker D.A. Pennebaker was (and he brought cameras).
Some movies are like dieting - you gotta stretch some muscles if you want the most satisfying results.
Intent on offending virtually any viewer out there, though those with open minds and strong constitutions may find themselves guiltily enjoying themselves.
If you adored The Full Monty so resoundingly that you're dying to see the same old thing in a tired old setting, then this should keep you reasonably entertained.
Those looking for a light and decidedly untraditional comedy will find some smart and witty exchanges within; those who consider Adam Sandler an underrated genius may be bored stiff.
Those looking for a tight thriller will be bored; those looking for effective horror will be annoyed.
Kids who devour all things beast-related will surely be entertained, while parents who stay put will most likely find themselves fascinated as well.
Yeah, these flicks are just that damn good. Isn't it great?
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The Batman & Robin of the Bond series.
Stunningly bad franchise droppings.
This movie not only has literally no cause for existence, but it's a testament to how faceless, lazy, and pathetic movies can be.
Taken as a tool to help retain public awareness for the various Star Trek books, video games, toys, and TV shows, Nemesis does its job relatively well.
Ignore for a minute that Death Factory is one of the most unoriginal and amateurish 'filmed on video' horror movies ever conceived are released on an unwitting public. There's no factory!
If Stakes looks a whole lot like something slapped together by a bunch of barbecue buddies and cubicle co-workers, that's because it probably is.
Those looking for an earnest depiction (and one that doesn't wallow in the seemingly inherent 'leering' of similar films), it's probably worthy of a look.
Two solid actors save a movie from its own pretense.
It's tough to knock a movie entitled The Night Evelyn Came Out of the Grave - but the dreary pacing, unconvincing performances and meandering narrative help make things a bit easier.
movie_title: The Night Evelyn Came Out of the Grave (2003)

movie_review_blurb: You've never heard of it. You'll never see it. To you this movie doesn't even exist. Lucky you.
Though not among Larry Cohen's most wholly satisfying productions, God Told Me To should prove a worthwhile curiosity to fans of 70's era horror movies told with a decidedly 'cop flick' feel.
The future of humanity depends on whether or not a guy has sex with Diane Franklin? I like our odds.
Those looking for a trip back to the swingin' sixties, Spanish style, may enjoy Fathom quite a bit, and those who adore the lovely Ms. Welch will have a ball.
Stunningly drab, particularly considering the word 'mania' is in the title.
Perhaps otherwise destined to be remembered as a talented footnote in musical history, Richie Valens is immortalized for the masses in this well-conceived and involving movie.
There's not a whole lot that can be said about an 80-minute scare-free horror film that was clearly inspired by the execrable Mirror Mirror trilogy, so I'll try to keep this brief.
By the time the genetically mutated killer cockroaches get wise and morph into this giant rhino-lookin' thing, you'll be fast asleep.
Even those who delight in the lowest-rent beastie buffets will find very little to sustain their horror freak cravings.
Only in a genre that includes Private School and Joy Sticks could Secret Admirer be considered a good movie, but this one's actually got some laughs!
Not nearly as cool as Creepshow, but a lot better than...Campfire Tales? Deadtime stories? Tales from the Hood? Creepshow 2? See, there just aren't enough cool horror anthologies out there.
movie_title: Tales from the Darkside: The Movie (1990)

movie_review_blurb: Is it even praise to call a film 'one of Van Damme's better efforts'? Try calling your wife's meatloaf 'the least nauseating thing I've even all week' and see what she thinks.
One of the most desperately uncomfortable and uncomfortably hilarious dark comedies ever conceived, After Hours is unlike any comedy you've ever seen - and one you won't soon forget.
If you often find yourself defending the types of movies offered by Jerry Bruckheimer and Joel Silver, here's an affably dumb little action/comedy that should easily hold your attention.
Love the late, great John Candy? Me too. Let's honor the funnyman by never seeing this movie again.
48 Hrs. may seem panfully dated and more than a little familiar, but keep in mind that this one hit the screns in 1982 - back when a buddy/cop flick was actually a novel proposition.
Her Alibi is a trifling confection, a near-invisible farce, cinematic pocket lint. That's not to say that it's a terrible movie; cake icing certainly isn't a terrible food.
Once in a while, the massive desert that is Modern American Comedy yields an oasis so sweet it simply demands to be appreciated.
There are certainly worse ways to spend 100 minutes - particularly if you're a bicycling enthusiast.
A well-photographed and handsome litany of cliche and stereotype.
This is one biblically awful piece of cinema, yet it gets two stars because it's just so damn funny.
Only in the movies can you come across selfish bastards that you actually like. Of course it helps when your bastard is played by the likes of Richard Dreyfuss.
Nothing new on the narrative front, but Damski's approach to the mid-50's feel (and the extensive usage of popular songs from the era) helps to keep this amiable comedy afloat.
Karen Black's been in a whole lot of obscure flicks, and Killing Heat is yet another one you're rather unlikely to come across.
movie_title: Gräset sjunger (Killing Heat) (The Grass Is Singing) (1981)

movie_review_blurb: With lesser actors on display, I shudder to think at how shrieky and pandering this production could have become. Fortunately, this one stars Laura Linney and Gena Rowlands.
A perfect pick if you've got a flick-addicted 14-year-old boy at home, and a fun genre flick for the whole family, Dreamscape is a little bit scary, a little bit smart, and a whole lotta B-movie fun.
Tuvalu is like watching a Dali painting brought to life...and who wouldn't want to see that?
Worthwhile in an archival sort of way, in that it's fascinating to see what passed for comedy in the horrifically tacky era of the late 1970's.
Dogtown and Z-Boys does precisely what a documentary movie should do: it makes its subject fascinating whether you actually give a damn or not.
It's often a sloppy and muddled tale - but there are much worse ways to spend a random 90 minutes.
If you're sitting through this flick searching for the two or three mild chuckles, you're in for an experience akin to that old "needle in a haystack" scenario.
I don't know if Frailty will turn Bill Paxton into an A-list director, but he can rest contentedly with the knowledge that he's made at least one damn fine horror movie.
Rare is the 'urban comedy' that even attempts the insight and honesty of this disarming indie.
Toss in a superlative performance by underrated movie star Dennis Quaid, and you've got the guy's equivalent to Steel Magnolias.
Despite its patchwork construction, Big Trouble is a satisfyingly funny little flick and nothing more.
Although DeVito occasionally bites off more than he can chew, this is one of those movies where "going too far" proves to be infinitely more entertaining than the alternative.
If the plot seems a bit on the skinny side, that's because Panic Room is interested in nothing more than sucking you in...and making you sweat.
The film has a laundry list of minor shortcomings, but the numerous scenes of gory mayhem are worth the price of admission...if "gory mayhem" is your idea of a good time.
It's apparent in every scene that this is a highly personal film for screenwriter Raucher, and the nostalgia is so palpable that it nearly slides off the screen.
It's ironic that such a generic title could still prove guilty of false advertising, as this one is neither romantic nor funny. Heck, it's hardly a movie.
Changing Lanes is an anomaly for a Hollywood movie; it's a well-written and occasionally challenging social drama that actually has something interesting to say.
Though it may damage my credibility as a respectable movie critic, I'll proudly list Resident Evil on my list of this year's guilty pleasures.
Those looking for a movie about restless young adults that doesn't focus on rampant raunchiness and insipid sex jokes should most definitely search this one out.
How this meandering and desperate sex farce ever got nominated for Best Picture is something that will boggle my mind for all eternity.
Despite a few entertaining moments and some strong performances, there's very little about this urban thriller that's worthy of mention.
It's rare to see a movie that takes such a speedy swan dive from "promising" to "interesting" to "familiar" before landing squarely on "stupid".
Fans of Penn and Cruise should enjoy this very early glimpse at their heroes, and Hutton (one of Hollywood's all-time most underrated actors) holds the movie together.
It may not be the most realistic portrayal of drug addiction ever produced, but it's certainly worth seeing - if for nothing else than Downey's superlative performance.
All the Right Moves is a low-key, well-acted and beautifully photographed slice-of-life "people" story.
While lesser sports comedies have tried to mimic the humour and sloppy charm of The Bad News Bears, none have even come close.
There's certainly a place for lightweight-yet-entertaining romantic piffle, and 40 Days and 40 Nights most assuredly qualifies as that.
Chalk it up to my adoration for both De Niro and Murphy, but I had a pretty good time with this movie - despite its myriad flaws.
Pep Squad rockets from shock to jolt to outright assault, never once pausing to apologize, and the result is a solid little "sick joke" of a comedy.
It's a sophomoric and predictable little farce - but fans of the old-fashioned Chevy Chase (you know, the funny one) will find much to enjoy.
The most impressive thing about this unoriginal, amateurish, and entirely unfunny movie is that the producers somehow talked people into paying for its creation.
A sloppy and intermittently goofy flick, but it still holds enough charm, excitement and good humor to please quest fans.
Proof that the 40's and 50's were a lot more risqué than Ward Cleaver and Andy Griffith would have you believe.
To see a comedy with such warmth and tenderness offered up by the directors of American Pie is surely a welcome bit of news.
Simply put, the 'good stuff' in Attack of the Clones so outweighs the bad...that the bad is hardly worth mentioning.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Risk may not be the most unique crime drama to come down the pike, but it's certainly intriguing and polished enough to earn a look.
With a tighter pace and a few more 'kicks' this one would be a true cult favourite.
Parents will thrill to see a childhood hero in a full live-action adventure, while a whole new generation gets their first taste of a hero too cool to ever go out of style.
You'll have a ball with Deuces Wild. Not because it's a well-made and intelligent movie, but because it plays like the world's most straight-faced spoof.
To call All in the Family one of American television's finest hours may be damning this program with faint praise, so I'll also call it 'purely brilliant'.
Starts out as a deliriously original "odd couple" comedy, and then hangs a quick left turn into shameless tear jerking.
Stumbles a bit with a muddled final act, but it's not enough to mar this generally fine film.
While Spirits of the Dead doesn't do much justice to Poe's source material, fans of bizarre French cinema should have a pretty good time.
What kid wouldn't want to grow up to be a multi-millionaire, one who's earned their fame and fortune through the creation of comic books, movies, video games, and toys?
movie_title: Todd McFarlane: The Devil You Know (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This low-budget yawnfest offers very little aside from several interminable scenes of seemingly endless blathering.
This movie wants to be harsh and unflinching; it comes off as whiny and dull.
Thoroughly noxious offspring of 'There's Something About Mary' and 'Sex & the City'.
What The Beastmaster lacks in lustre and expense, it more than makes up for in sheer "guilty pleasure" enjoyment.
Much like the raucous party it depicts, this movie is fun while it lasts, but you'll be hard-pressed to remember anything about it once it's over.
This prequel to a sequel to a remake is a fitfully entertaining affair, one that will enthrall its target audience...and their parents too.
Considerably more entertaining than most of what passes for a 'mindless horror flick' these days.
The kind of movie that you'll catch one night on cable at 1:45 AM and be stunned when you actually like it.
Perhaps a better celebration of these unfairly dismissed heroes would be a film that isn't this painfully forced, false and fabricated.
The Mark is a well-made and well-acted film that suffers from a bloated length, dreary pacing and essentially unpleasant subject matter.
The authenticity of Brain Drain is its strongest asset, as the mean streets of Buenos Aires are depicted in a harrowingly unfriendly style.
Hardcore fans will devour this fascinating doc, while those unfamiliar with the resounding impact made by Ali are in for an informative lesson.
movie_title: Muhammad Ali: Through the Eyes of the World (2001)

movie_review_blurb: While Dominick and Eugene certainly is not a terrible movie, there's very little that will stay with you once the end credits start to roll.
Director Ridley Scott clearly wants this film to do one thing: drop the audience in the center of a massive, confusing and ultimately meaningless battlefield.
Jim Kouf has managed to create a low-budget cop story that not only features a sterling cast, but also manages to entertain for two hours straight.
Aside from a few random smatterings of chop-socky daring-do, there's not one single thing about this movie worth sitting through.
I suspect that the only reason I survived this one is that I'm a film critic and therefore subjected to more crap than 25 cow farmers combined.
Based on a story by Philip K. Dick, the new idiot-fest known as Impostor is about as entertaining as the second of two bologna sandwiches.
I shudder at the thought of a 14-year old girl watching this film.
Any sci-fi movie that features cameos by Kenneth Tobey and June Lockhart (both from television's Lost in Space) obviously has its heart in the right place.
I Bury the Living proves to be a dark little horror morsel, a creepy, compact and crisp little tale that's half Alfred Hitchcock and half Rod Serling.
While most carbon-copy rip-offs try to hide their plagiarized roots, Deep Water wallows gleefully in its own stolen plot threads and unoriginal contrivances.
If the "classic" holiday movies have all been played to death and you're still pining for more, then you could do a lot worse than giving Prancer Returns a spin.
Here's a film that simply reeks of contractual obligations and a screenplay yanked out of someone's attic.
movie_title: The Curse of the Jade Scorpion (2001)

movie_review_blurb: It may seem a somewhat trite and corny affair when compared with today's definition of 'horror movies,' but this one has the market cornered on atmosphere.
Jane White is Sick and Twisted is never going to be mistaken for an Oscar Winner or Merchant-Ivory production. I mean that as a compliment.
movie_title: Jane White is Sick and Twisted (2002)

movie_review_blurb: More like "The Lame and Laborious".
Scene after ponderous scene is presented in a nausea-inspiring conflagration of pointless close-ups, out-of-focus expositions and handheld "wobble" shots
It manages to go from cornball Capra wanna-be to overbaked courtroom grandstand without missing a beat, to say nothing of the ever-present 'insert emotion here' musical score.
Fascinating, clever and surprisingly heartfelt, A Beautiful Mind is easily one of this year's best films.
The copious action sequences are kinetic and thrilling while the exposition scenes and 'character moments' are wonderfully free of anything resembling 'camp'.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: If you have a high tolerance for unblinking gross-out gags and you love making fun of Freddie Prinze Jr. flicks, odds are you'll have a good time with this one.
The overall effect of Waking Life is that of finally escaping a cocktail party full of ecstasy-laden philosophy students.
Proof positive that Hollywood doesn't own exclusive rights to the "Enjoyable B-Movie".
One of the most satisfying crime thrillers in years. See it. And then give the original a rent. It's only fair.
If well-made escapist entertainment is what you're after and the nonstop CGI orgies have grown wearisome, give this one a shot.
If I told you that your children DESERVED this movie, you'd slap my face.
It plods along methodically, somehow under the assumption that its "dead wife communicating from beyond the grave" framework is even remotely new or interesting.
The only entertainment you'll derive from this choppy and sloppy affair will be from unintentional giggles -- several of them.
You'd have to search far and wide for a movie as gleefully stupid as Kung Pow: Enter the Fist, but you'd never find one so bereft of laughs.
There's a lot of good humour here and you're left feeling as if you've been eavesdropping on some particularly fascinating (and very pleasant) next-door neighbours.
Obviously made on a limited budget, Burnzy's Last Call is not an awful flick, but it is no better than consistently mediocre.
Though it's billed as a comedy, Amazing Grace contains very little in the way of laughs - I counted approximately zero.
For those who consider Police Academy too highbrow.
If you've ever heard the word "schizophrenic" used to describe a movie and you weren't exactly sure what that meant, the wartime drama Hart's War is a picture-perfect example.
If you've seen Major League and The Bad News Bears at least five times apiece, this is a relatively forgotten little comedy that is definitely worth a look.
movie_title: The Bingo Long Traveling All-Stars & Motor Kings (1976)

movie_review_blurb: A touching and absorbing movie that (thankfully) doesn't wrap everything up with a big, dumb, happy ending.
I can't help but think I'd enjoy The Vigil a lot more if I considered Kurt Cobain to be my generation's John Lennon. Unlike the devoted characters in this film, I do not.
Mannequin's not even good enough to be a "guilty pleasure". I'm mortified to admit that I ever liked it.
All Over the Guy, while by no means a groundbreaking piece of cinema, is a breezy and fun romantic comedy.
The Man Who Loved Women is not merely a film that hasn't aged well; it was stale six months after it was released.
Best recommended to those with a deep appreciation for Kung-Fu, Shaolin: Wheel of Life will also prove quite entertaining to fans of unique theatrical presentations.
While Birthday Girl isn't likely to rank among 2002's most memorable films, there's more than enough entertainment here to warrant a visit.
Slackers is particularly disappointing because there seems to be a dark and subversive streak to the film that sadly got buried in the slipshod editing.
It's hard to imagine that a movie with this cast could come up with so few solid laughs.
movie_title: What's the Worst That Could Happen? (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A well paced and satisfying little drama that deserved better than a 'direct-to-video' release.
You've got to respect any movie that jumps into an action scene every fifteen minutes, regardless of what that pesky "plot" has to say.
If Mummy Raider looks like it was filmed in one afternoon in the stockroom of a Best Buy, that's because it probably was.
While it's certainly not an AWFUL film, The Mothman Prophecies could have been greatly improved by a more heartless editor and a lot more intensity.

Sure, it's vital for a documentarian to present their subject with a minimum of subjectivity, but the overall sense I got from the ponderous Cinemania is simply that "boy these people sure are weird and fun to laugh at".
As it stands, a movie like How High does nothing more than perpetuate the belief that marijuana is enjoyed solely by idiots.
Breaking In is a charming, warm and completely entertaining movie - the kind you'll enjoy best after sitting through something particularly mindless and loud.
One of the cooler things about being required to watch lots of movies "sight unseen" is that occasionally something unexpectedly entertaining pops up.
Storytelling is a witty, dark, and strangely satisfying experiment. It's a little bit sad, a little bit sick, and a whole lot honest.
Laced with liberal doses of dark humor, gorgeous exterior photography, and a stable-full of solid performances, No Such Thing is a fascinating little tale.
If this movie is any evidence of Alma's true persona, I'd contend that the miserable gal never deserved her own bio-pic in the first place.
Style over substance all the way, but at least it's not boring.
If you're looking for a movie about two unmarried lovers contending with their first child together, there are plenty out there...just make sure it doesn't star Chuck Norris.
When a hardcore Friday the 13th fan tells you that a particular entry is a piece of junk, you should probably listen.
movie_title: Friday the 13th Part VII - The New Blood (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Hiding Out never once approaches funny. Were it not for the parade of cliches and stereotypes stolen from various high-school comedies, I'd have assumed that this movie was a straight drama.
Clash of the Titans will still hold a place in the heart of anyone who's old enough to have seen it in the theaters. Yes, I'm that old.
Exploitation flicks like Satan was a Lady do have their 'niche audience', but based on what this movie has to offer - it's clear that I'm not a member of that niche.
Dismiss Caveman as low-minded stupidity if you like, but I may be giggling too loudly to hear your complaints.
Monkeys: they make any movie funnier just by being included.
Featuring the most evil ***** you'll ever love.
If the poster for New Port South had any truth to it, it would read "A little knowledge is a dangerous thing".
Even the finest Friday the 13th flicks barely qualify as actual movies, so it's fairly clear where the lesser entries lie on the scale of quality.
movie_title: Friday the 13th Part VIII - Jason Takes Manhattan (1989)

movie_review_blurb: High Spirits most clearly resembles a disturbingly hollow combination of Ghostbusters, Police Academy, and every loud noise you've ever heard.
If you're looking for a movie that may inspire your children to read, ignore this one and lay your money down for The Princess Bride or The NeverEnding Story.
Firmly among the ranks of Condorman and The Return of Captain Invincible in both quality and in how fondly it will be remembered.
Surely contains some quality components, but the movie as a whole may leave an unpleasant taste in your mouth.
Fans of old-fashioned, atmospheric ghost tales will forgive the film's obvious faults, but even they will have a hard time generating much enthusiasm for the movie.
Portrays the golden age of television in a warmly affectionate light, while delivering the criminally entertaining Peter O'Toole at his most devilishly charming.
I don't know precisely what to make of Steven Soderbergh's Full Frontal, though that didn't stop me from enjoying much of it.
Shyamalan takes a potentially trite and overused concept (aliens come to Earth) and infuses it into a rustic, realistic, and altogether creepy tale of hidden invasion.
The Temp is a wholly ridiculous little thriller, yet it repeatedly goes above and beyond the 'so bad it's good' realm.
I don't know what YOU generally look for in a horror flick, but unless it's "talking and lots of it" I'd stay far away from this one.
Nothing more than four or five mild chuckles surrounded by 86 minutes of overly-familiar and poorly-constructed comedy.
Fans of Japanese cult horror flicks should certainly give it a look, but A Lamb in Despair isn't nearly as shocking as its garish DVD cover would imply.
"Your honor! I didn't mean to have adulterous sex with my secretary! Tetris BRAINWASHED me into doing it!"
Note to filmmakers: if your audience can see five inches of oxygen between your hero's foot and your villain's face...you're not very good at directing action sequences.
An experience from a gifted writer telling a story from personal experience, as opposed to some hack culling together a melodrama about how sad it is to be crippled.
I'm not exactly complaining, but I can't recall the last movie I saw that turned from 'adventure story' to 'softcore bondage flick' with such knocker-obsessed resolve.
movie_title: The Perils Of Gwendoline In The Land Of The Yik Yak (1985)

movie_review_blurb: An incomprehensible low-budget French/Turkish/British mess featuring two American B-movie actors, which makes it kind of odd that most characters speak with an Italian accent.
A fairly entertaining chase flick, with a few artistic touches included to keep the thinking viewers happy.
Crime and Passion may not make a whole lot of sense, but it sure does work well as an advertisement for the Silicone industry.
This 60-some-minute Japanese comedy (?) opens with a softcore hump scene and ends with a softball game. It's that middle hour I'm a bit fuzzy on.
Often more exasperating than it is entertaining.
As the massive battle scenes and convoluted political machinations paraded across the screen, I thought, "This was the Braveheart of the 1950s!" and I was right.
Call me a cold-hearted curmudgeon for not being able to enjoy a mindless action movie, but I believe a movie can be mindless without being the peak of all things insipid.
With her raunchy mouth, joyously bitchy disposition, and sinfully beautiful body, Kimberley Kates' presence alone makes this one a look...maybe.
An amateur moviemaker certainly doesn't need to be Hitchcock to make a fun movie, but they should certainly aim higher than being the next Bert I. Gordon.
Rare is the film that fails so resoundingly in two separate genres at the exact same time.
There are several boobies in this movie. I'd venture a guess that there are twice as many knockers in this flick than there are women.
At times, Viva Erotica seems precisely like the soft-core sex flicks it's trying to skewer, but overall it's not a bad little import.
This is one bizarre comedy from Hong Kong, a leering sex farce that makes the worst of American comedy (Weekend at Bernies 2) look like high art by comparison.
There's more charm and craftsmanship in the first 30 minutes of Disney's Princess of Thieves than there is in the whole of Disney's Snow Dogs.
Combines a few lovable Hollywood icons, an admittedly goofball plot, some sweet-natured romance, and brilliant rapid-fire exchanges of breathless comedic dialogue.
Innerspace is high-concept all the way, but if all such 'high-concept' movies were crafted with this much affection and good humour, then lots of movie critics would be out of jobs/
I can easily recommend Graveyard Shift...but only to adolescent boys who are just now discovering the joys of gooey, sloppy, gore flicks.
Far from the worst sequel ever made, but surely you have better things to spend 9 bucks on than 'far from the worst sequel ever made'.
A dark and convoluted low-budget thriller...and by 'dark' I don't mean 'densely plotted' or 'downbeat'; I mean 'poorly lit'.
Spielberg should have sued for 'breach of earth-shattering stupidity'.
This is a vapid and uninhabited wasteland of a film, a vacuum in which only a handful of product placements, shoddy CGI effects, and smug actors were ever meant to survive.
D-Day: The Sixth of June is a sappy old love-story wrapped up as a macho guy flick, and the movie barely works as either.
Strikes that magical balance between a phenomenal cast, a director with a gift for shadow and mood, and a near-perfect screenplay.
Directed with the panache that only the creator of The Mighty Ducks can bring to your project, Mr. Deeds is a poorly made and charmless affair.
Perhaps if I had experienced this movie when I was twelve years old, I'd have come away with something more than a lot of yawns and the desire to plant a tree.
It's not an award-winner or cult classic, but The Last Starfighter is certainly one of the coolest "cable flicks" you're likely to come across.
As far as mindless cookie-cutter action movies go, you could certainly do much worse than Rapid Fire, though that's hardly a ringing endorsement.
If self-pitying man-children spewing venom about the 'bitches' who ruined their lives sounds like 100 minutes of fun, here's the movie for you.
When a film is created SOLELY because it's a marketable product, soulless and ugly movies like this are the result. Let your silly childhood nostalgia slumber unmolested.
It's rare to find a film that dazzles the eye, challenges the brain, AND satisfies our lust for fast-paced action, but Minority Report delivers all that and a whole lot more.
Not every animated film from Disney will become a classic, but forgive me if I've come to expect more from this studio than some 79-minute after-school "cartoon".
Everything bad in Temple of Doom is the fault of the insipid script, and everything good belongs to Spielberg, Ford, and that funny little Asian kid.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (1984)

movie_review_blurb: That the Chuck Norris "grenade gag" occurs about 7 times during Windtalkers is a good indication of how serious-minded the film is.
Part dark comedy, part sex farce, part sloppy mess, Daniel Waters' HAPPY CAMPERS is a cult classic waiting to happen.
An impressive balance of well-executed slapstick and insightful (albeit silly) social commentary.
Taken outside the context of the current political climate (see: terrorists are more evil than ever!), The Sum of All Fears is simply a well-made and satisfying thriller.
Roman Coppola may never become the filmmaker his Dad was, but heck - few filmmakers will. But based on CQ, I'll certainly be keeping an eye out for his next project.
Taking its cue from the classics of the genre, Peter Gunn follows the ultra-cool exploits of the titular gumshoe and a handful of colourful sidekicks.
Though it's not surprisingly a terrible piece of filmmaking, the movie earns points for simply delivering the sweaty goods.
A bizarre and downcast road flick best described as Thelma and Louise meets Natural Born Killers, only with a lot less flash and a lot more lesbianism.
Could have been a genre classic if it had benefited from a meatier screenplay and a studio that didn't butcher the final product.
Leave this one as history has intended: unknown, forgotten, and detested by the unfortunate few who've actually seen it.
Those who can't get enough of television's Law and Order or The Practice should rediscover this minor classic, one of the best films of the early 80s.
Not only is this flick a taut and wonderfully-crafted thriller, but Speed has some of the highest 'rewatchability factor' I've ever witnessed in an action flick.
Much like how South Park: BL & U proved a brilliant expansion from its source material, Brain Candy captures the Canadian Kids at their most cleverly unglued.
If you're a big fan of porn stars Houston, Raylene, or Teri Weigel and you've been itching to see these gals cooking food, here's the video for you.
It's more of a visual 'conversation piece' than a cohesive story, but it's most assuredly for adults only!
I watched this movie from beginning to end without getting up once...and I still couldn't tell you what it's about.
This DVD is a compilation of Colin's 'sleaziest hits' and while it's a decidedly amateurish affair, some of it is quite amusing...in a Jerry Springer kind of way.
Aside from a few sloppy gore scenes, I was pretty bored with this one...but if you find yourself attracted to all movies Vampiric in nature, you could do a lot worse.
Looking for an Echo is full of satisfying moments, yet it's not an altogether satisfying movie.
This is a dreary, dull and altogether grating film, one that's as derivative and simple as it is just plain boring.
Forgotten by most yet seemingly adored by those who choose to remember it, The Best of Times stands in my book as one of the truly great sports comedies.
This gleefully giddy giant spider invasion may never win any Oscars, but it delivered one of the most entertaining 90-minute spectacles I've witnessed in a long time.
Sure, calling any flick "better than Van Wilder" is damning it with faint praise...but did I mention that this one's got Kirsten Dunst in it?
Private School is one of the most reviled movies in a monumentally despised genre. Hardcore porn has a better reputation than does Private School.
Aside from some bizarre casting, a few gorgeous young women, and a plot amazingly comprised of ever cable flick ever made, Pendulum is an outright chore to sit through.
Destination Nightmare is just plain old boring. Were the stories a bit edgier or the performances a bit less ponderous, I'd probably have something nicer to say.
Road to Perdition is a movie that's simply a joy to look at, as well as a poignant, engrossing and altogether enjoyable old-fashioned gangster saga.
Director Rob Bowman obviously realizes that he's working on a simple popcorn flick, yet still does everything he can to make Reign of Fire a quality popcorn flick.
There's a lot here that the kiddies will like, and it's delivered with a minimum of the outright schmaltz that's become so prevalent in Disney's more recent efforts.
Mannequin 2 is so bad that you'd easily accept my supposition that the film was in fact directed by three spiders, a goat, and a dedicated gust of wind.
Those looking for an intelligent and bittersweet western should search out Hombre, a somewhat overlooked (yet still fondly remembered) mini-classic of the genre.
Let's Make Love doesn't come close to Marilyn Monroe's best moments, but those who like corny old romances could certainly do worse.
The problem that low-budget filmmakers usually overlook when centering an entire movie around one soft-core sex scene: soft-core sex scenes generally run about 4 minutes.
Weirdly endearing and free-spirited characters wandering through the lovely, wide-open expanse of the Australian outback.
As a die-hard fan of the horror anthology film, I take no pleasure in stating that Locker 13's few stray glimmers of quality are not worth the slog it takes to find them.
An entirely wholesome and worthwhile family program, given that you currently own a small child who will sit still for a story about a young girl's adventures in Canada circa 1900.
It's no Martyrs or Inside, but that's a pretty unfair standard when you think about it.
The minute it's over you'll need a nap. And then you'll want to watch it again.
For all its surface-level vulgarity and gleeful violence, Goon is actually a sweet, insightful, and powerfully effective little sports movie.
You know precisely what you're getting from Camel Spiders. Which means you'll probably watch it some time soon.
A well-earned and affectionate spotlight on a man who, let's face it, is one of the most impressive film producers who ever lived.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's nothing in Beneath the Darkness you haven't seen before, better, and recently.
Should be required viewing of anyone who is committed to becoming a teen athlete -- or a coach of one.
The title refers to your 12 bucks. This movie is as amateurish as Amanda Seyfried is pretty.
Bad news for fans of the character, admirers of quality filmmaking, and anyone who forgot to bring some Tylenol to the screening.
A gimmick horror movie, but the gimmick works pretty well.
It takes a special kind of ignorance to make Tom Hardy boring, to make Chris Pine unlikable, and to make Reese Witherspoon unattractive.
A suspenseful and well-performed "home invasion" thriller with a nasty biological twist.
...at least it's gory!
A sloppy, messy, frankly dumb action/horror hybrid, but at least it moves quickly and delivers the goods.
...at its best when it's being sillier; you just have to wait a little while for the good stuff.
This Criterion edition is the textbook definition of "must-own," provided you're a serious horror fan.
The world needs horror flicks that can be shown at family nights and slumber parties, and now we have a new one.
A slight improvement over the nearly unwatchable third chapter, if that means anything at all to you.
Probably the finest collaboration ever between SyFy Channel and The Asylum.
Combines enough that's genre-friendly and accessible with the trademark style of a truly unique and "artsy" filmmaker.
Seems poised to kick-start a big fat franchise, but it's a great little movie that stands perfectly well on its own.
An eternal morass of dreary conversations, paper-thin character development, and plot convolutions that were old hat by the time Jaws 2 showed up.
On the bright side, the movie gets less irritating with each passing murder.
A melancholy tale of loss that's only peripherally a horror flick, but a good one all the same.
Takes a while to get where it's going, but the final destination is satisfying enough.
Precisely what the title implies, but it does get pretty rough.
Almost aggressively slow to begin with, but be patient.
Sleeping Pill: The Movie
Almost as terrible as The Wicker Man (1973) is excellent. (Almost.)
We are knee-deep in the lazy side of the found footage pool.
Bottom of the found footage barrel.
Honest and loyal enough for the hardcore fans; smooth and accessible for the newcomer. Stunning action, great character, really funny.
Despite a handful of narrative missteps and a few errant accents, it's actually a pretty compelling "what if?" story.
A migraine-inducing endurance test.
For a film that barely engages the brain at all, it works pretty damn well for the ears and eyeballs.
Goes to a dark, weird, disturbing place -- if you're willing to wait for it.
Sci-fi fans will definitely notice its various inspirations, and probably have some fun while doing it.
Watchable only if you're at home, on the couch, with a strong cup of coffee in hand.
Ferrell hasn't lost his knack for earnest weirdness, legitimately funny self-deprecation, and a dedication to taking some chances once in a while.
I went from ignorant to informed to impressed when presented with this tight and enjoyable compendium of all the major hacking incidents of the past several years.
movie_title: We Are Legion: The Story of the Hacktivists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A sly, strange and subtly engaging horror story that will no doubt leave several viewers angry, confused, or arguing on twitter.
One of the funniest movies about selfish, vulgar, horny 14-year-olds in quite some time.
A fascinating, modern-ish spin on one of the coolest old horror tricks: the anthology film.
A bump-in-the-night haunted house tale that brings something new (and creepy) to the table.
Sort of like The Strangers meets Home Alone. Only dead serious and painfully violent.
Dark but serious old-school fun, something we might have once received from a director like Walter Hill or Don Siegel.
No amount of plucked-off fingernails are going to fill this empty vessel with any semblance of a point.
Nowhere near good, not remotely interesting enough to be worthy of mockery, and a miserable time-waste for all involved.
I'm fiercely protective of these old friends -- and I believe that the great Jim Henson would be very pleased with this movie.
There are still good vampire movies being made. Like this one.
Three dark horror tales that deal with human sexuality in some deeply unpleasant ways.
A throwback monster movie made by people who clearly adore the films they're referencing.
The plot is nothing new; the presentation sort of is.
"Dead Calm meets Donkey Punch" (if that means anything to you)
If the idea of watching Adrien Brody wiggle and whine his way through a forest sounds thrilling, meet your new favorite film.
Worthless, contractually-mandated greed on film.
As lazy, obvious, and tiresome as retreads get. Also witless.
Considering what most low-budget shark flicks look like, The Reef is a welcome sight indeed.
Most assuredly a farce first and a monster movie second.
movie_title: The Last Lovecraft: Relic of Cthulhu (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The good will of the solid original and its amusing sequel has been squandered by laziness.
Not a bad effort for a mini-budgeted fan-funded horror project.
A slick, stylish (sometimes silly) vampire import. (Avoid the English dub version!)
A stalker kicks off an ever-escalating carnival of carnage. (Cleverer than it sounds.)
A low-budget but well-made horror flick that earns points due to two strong leads and some slick visual effects.
Movies like this are why genre fans will always give yet another "forest stalker survival" movie a fair shake.
A wonderfully strange concoction of dry comedy, weird horror, and Christmas-related craziness.
A killer stalks a reality show. You fall asleep.
OK, the shrieking banshee head is pretty freaky.
Not all "five guys in a cabin" thrillers are created equally.
A quick, fluid, scary tale that makes up for in quiet chills what it lacks in slam-bang craziness.
Generic plot, familiar faces, a few jolts. Period.
Every once in a while, After Dark Films delivers something solid. Like this one.
About as basic a horror flick could ever be without debuting on The Lifetime Channel.
Half "300" and half "Clash of the Titans," although duller and sillier than both combined.
An editorial mess, an atonal wreck, and a huge waste of cash from inception to release.
85% material that's been lifted from Hostage, Panic Room, whatever, and 15% plain old stupid.
All of the blanks that your mind filled in 25 years ago are now fleshed out, made literal, and kinda dull.
60% Lost Boys, 30% Twilight, and 10% guaranteed to evoke huge peals of derisive giggles at slumber parties across the country.
Proof positive that not all "home invasion" horror movies have to be bleak and miserable.
The directors of 'Inside' go in a completely different direction, and the result is (again) a damn good horror film.
Where the original film was an assault, the remake is content to be a crowd-pleaser.
A potentially silly movie that wins its legitimacy through sheer force of confident, mellow attitude. And Gosling is simply great.
A forgotten little treasure for old-school horror fans.
Any childhood favorite that is still a good deal of fun today is a movie worthy of some note.
One tiresome slog through one familiar swamp.
Three great actors and a smart script -- combined with the rah-rah sports movie we all know and love.
As conventional as you can get without needing an epilogue that says "...next week on Blitz."
I'd read about this one for three years. Then I saw it and forgot it immediately.
Yet another piece of "found footage," but it's a pretty cool one.
Not terrible, but the 27-minute version was better.
Better than its predecessor, which (fine), isn't saying a whole lot.
If you think the title is ridiculous, get this: Urkel is the hero.
A merciless chore of a movie.
A mash-up of the "isolation stalker" concept and a "night of the hungry vampires" pitch. Not half bad.
One of the best horror films of the year. By far.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While I wish I liked this movie a lot more, it simply has too many interesting assets to dismiss outright.
Epic and personal, challenging and strange.
Might not be a Lethal Weapon-style comeback for Mel the Action Star, but it works well enough as a double feature with Gibson's underrated Payback.
A quick, dry, acidic comedy that will appeal to anyone who likes horror movies or pitch-black humor.
The UK version is 15 minutes longer and makes this bizarre but lovable movie a bit more interesting.
One of the darkest, weirdest, and funniest cinematic armageddons you'll ever experience.
A sick and twisted horror farce made for a very specific sort of movie geek. I'm one of them.
Plainly dated and a bit slow, but there are also some solid chills and it makes a respectable attempt at historical accuracy.
Smart, suspenseful, and fascinating. Maybe the best indie sci-fi film since Moon.
Exists for the producers, the studio, and nobody else. Insulting, amateurish garbage.
A decent homage to Dario Argento that's gradually undone by some plainly sloppy storytelling.
Quiet but interesting, clever enough to make horror fans happy, and sexy in a way that only a good indie vampire movie can be.
It's the pointed focus on science fiction that elevates Man of Steel beyond that of "just another Superman movie."
Feels like a distant cousin to the new Maniac remake: horror stories told from inside the mind of a calm, cool lunatic.
Sequel or not, this is a fantastic foursome of horror shorts -- and yes, the wrap-around stuff is better this time.
Composed of seven or eight other films you've already seen before. And not composed especially well.
There's more going on beneath the surface here than just another "angry women act out" horror story.
I've seen a lot worse "crocs run wild" movies than Lake Placid 4. (Best praise I got. Sorry.)
Only slightly better than a SyFy Channel monster movie, but you watch those too, I bet.
Feels like a late-arriving film class homework assignment that the students didn't really care about.
A novel little combination of a few horror sub-genres that generally don't hook up very often.
An oddball romantic farce that takes place in a horror movie world. Weird, earnest, and rather affable.
For those who care to look past the obvious silliness of the whole affair, there's actually some weird but quality craftsmanship at work.
Fortunately for all involved, Anderson manages to bring a lot of class and energy to the material.
Quiet, cool, and simply gorgeous to look at, Stoker is easily one of the most accomplished chillers of the year.
You've read all the bad news. Now here's some good news: it's a fun movie.
Frankly speaking, this flick capably represents almost everything I admire about indie Aussie genre films. I expect to see more from these filmmakers soon.
"Phone Booth in a concert hall" -- except that it's quite a bit better than that.
Further evidence that seasoned directors enjoy the found footage gimmick as much as the first-timers seem to.
A frank and powerful horror film about the disastrous and irrevocable effects of child abuse.
Icky and violent and shocking, but Contracted is also smart, insightful, and sort of tragic.
A quiet, confident, and surprisingly excellent revenge thriller.
If you can get past the fact that the flick is composed of 75% recycled ideas and 25% new ones, you may find that something to like.
Feels like a "throwback" that's not a rip-off, and a mild satire that clearly loves the stuff it's poking fun at.
Cool, creepy stuff that should please horror nuts and relative scaredy-cats in equal measure.
Visually amazing, wonderfully suspenseful, and rooted in a place of humanity. A stellar popcorn movie.
Mostly stuff you've seen before, only here it's been re-heated and reconfigured into a crafty little creeper that actually works.
Sweaty, swaggering, sci-fi / action / horror with a bad attitude and a dirty mouth. I liked it.
Not an original bone in its body -- but there's always something to be said for a great cast.
A slight but amusing combination of the subversive and the conventional.
Funnier by accident than Adam Sandler is on purpose.
A fantastic ensemble farce that shows why nobody does comedy like the Brits.
Familiar, predictable, unoriginal... but not entirely unwatchable.
A WWII found footage horror movie? Yep. And it's good? Yep!
The worst sort of "slap it together because some geeks recognize the title" film production. Truly awful.
An endlessly raucous and wonderfully entertaining piece of grade-A eye candy from one of the few filmmakers I trust implicitly.
Not a very good movie, but a weirdly interesting one for the serious horror fans.
Sea World's worst nightmare -- and for good reason.
When it sticks to the fights, the thugs, and the attitude, it's a pretty good time.
Feels like the unkempt offspring of Lock Up, Mad Max, and The Cannonball Run. Only not as good as those movies.
The headache you'll get from the first half of the flick is not worth the meager thrills you'll get from the second.
If you like your Leatherface deeply, darkly, distressingly scary -- this is not the movie for you.
"Sharks in a Supermarket!" is a pretty silly idea, but there's no reason it has to be this sloppy and stupid.
The horror sequel equivalent of a "clip show" episode of Friends.
Sick and twisted in the most interesting ways.
A suspenseful, intense, and surprisingly touching ode to America's inner-city peacekeepers.
It's not every day you see an ostensible satire that's never funny on purpose but is frequently hilarious by accident.
A creepy box, a new religious angle, and just enough visceral energy to fill a two-minute trailer.
Hey, we weren't all that demanding of our low-budget monster movies in 1981.
Never manages to sustain any energy for more than three or four minutes at a time.
Five sequences in which indistinguishable soldiers fire endless rounds of bullets into a ceaseless deluge of angry green aliens.
A very broad and exceedingly splattery mash-up of horror, comedy, and mild social commentary.
I do mean "broad, pulpy, trashy" as a compliment.
A short, sharp shock of downbeat but compelling apocalypse fiction.
At one point a guy gets his arm chopped off and everyone gets sprayed with blood, and that does prove a welcome respite from the spittle-laden diatribes.
A rumination on how long humans will actually last, if left entirely to their own devices. And it isn't pretty.
A chilly, compelling, and quietly engrossing little sci-fi/horror thriller from Germany.
Goes from stark, sober horror to expeditious revenge thriller without missing a beat
A bit of a mess, but it's a consistently fun one, and that's more than most horror/comedies can say.
Just about the most basic and generic haunted house retread in several years. Aggressively dull stuff.
Funnier than both Hangover flicks jammed together, and I hope that doesn't read like a DVD blurb. I mean it.
Not as smart as the previous Total Recall, but slicker, sexier, and a lot more energetic.
One of the best marriages we've ever seen between the art of superhero storytelling and the "evil" of large-scale commerce.
Required viewing for parents of children who play "hard-contact" sports, to say nothing of those kids themselves.
Slight, dark, and weird, but what a cast.
High marks for starting out stark, staying aggressive, and displaying a very dark but rather welcome sense of humor.
"Works on so many levels" is sort of an inside joke among film critics. No joke here; Looper really does.
It's always so much fun to see something familiar turned into something fresh right before your eyes. Few can do it like Tarantino.
Precisely what an adventure epic should be: huge, long, and lots of fun.
The movie earns high grades for allowing four strong actors to work their way through some basic but interesting obstacles that must of us can relate to in one way or another.
An appealing piece of fluff for movie buffs, and sometimes that's just good enough.
This scrappy little remake is somehow more entertaining than half of what passes for "wide release" horror movies.
An espionage thriller mixed with a revenge story wrapped in a character study about the world's favorite secret agent.
It's Russell Crowe's unhinged performance that's the crown jewel of weirdness in this joyously bizarre little action movie.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: One of the best animated movies of a year full of them. Sweet, silly, nostalgic, and very geeky fun.
Stick with the games. At least in the games you can press "skip" when confronted with nine goofball dialogue scenes in a row.
Cheap, dumb, and not even remotely scary -- but it has lots of crazy kills and nasty splatter, which is why it exists.
Offers a slightly more socially relevant motive than simply "crazy guy wants to kill family," and it works.
Basically, Grave Encounters 2 is so far up its own ass it almost disappears.
A fast-paced, slam-bang-ish, and tightly-coiled neo-noir.
Avoids being a complete b-movie misfire, but you'll have to slog through some tiresome stuff to find the few morsels of amusing weirdness.
Provides only one small fragment of the Lutz story, and is only fascinating for a fraction of its running time.
Not your typical "maniacal female" horror film.
It almost feels like an occult thriller that has slowly transformed into a comedy -- and you didn't even notice.
While it pains me to say unkind things about an actor I admire, I don't think Michael Biehn is destined to be a director.
Equally as stupid as the original, but it runs about 30 minutes shorter, which is nice.
aka "Bizarre and Fascinating Crackpot Theories Regarding Stanley Kubrick's The Shining."
Demands a little patience but also delivers some nasty chills in return.
The creators of The Collector go with an Aliens framework for Part 2, and it's not like they're coy about it.
Really runs out of steam near the end, but there's still a nice batch of raunchy laughs here.
Has a cockeyed charm, some truly clever ideas, and more than enough energy to pull it all off. And it's really gory.
Too wacky to be sincerely scary, and a bit too grim to be a whole lot of fun.
Most of the anecdotes (and there are many) are as juicy and compelling as they are plain-old horrifying.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Further proof that the Brits nail "topical" comedy earlier and better than anyone. A true original -- and FUNNY.
Coasts over its missteps and succeeds on equal parts quick humor, likable characters, and pure energy. Oh, and weed.
May not change your world view, but it's pretty interesting to see what happens after a middle-class family wins $314 million.
It's important for a doco to find the human equation amidst a sea of stats, facts, and figures. '12th & Delaware' does that remarkably well.
Like most brave thrillers that delve into very dark places, '7 Days' is not so much "fun" as it is fascinating.
There's nothing wrong with a one-joke horror/comedy -- provided you keep the joke spinning for 90 minutes. This flick (somehow) does.
An after-the-fact faux-documentary about the death of a young girl -- and the creepy little hints she may have left behind.
Certainly not on the scale of a Romero, but at least these filmmakers paid some attention in zombie class.
Works well enough as a basic primer on how our education system got so damn broken, but also offers some hope for the future of American education.
A crisp and refined little mind-bender that gets pretty contorted, but makes just enough sense to deliver a strong finalé.
A fast-paced and action-heavy period piece that focuses on what matters most in a Saturday afternoon matinee: the good stuff.
A weeknight rental for those who can appreciate material both broadly goofy and amusingly gory.
An impressively restrained and quietly disturbing little psycho-thriller.
Wants to be "Saw meets Heathers," I suspect. It doesn't succeed.
It's a SyFy Channel flick about a murderous carnival barker and a bloodthirsty gargoyle. You do the math.
Capably delivers a half-dozen sub-genres in less than 88 minutes. That's just plain old fun, regardless of how much the flick cost to produce.
A slick, witty, and unexpectedly effective little genre throwback.
There's nothing wrong with the new Clash of the Titans that wasn't wrong with the first one. It's a loud, fun, colorful adventure flick. (Avoid the 3-D version!)
Pure and palpable evidence of a master filmmaker who's having some real fun with some very old-fashioned genre material.
It may be a second-tier Romero film, but hell, it's still a Romero film.
I call 'em "gimmick thrillers," which isn't a knock -- unless you can't pull the gimmick off. For the most part, 'Buried' definitely can.
A powerfully brazen re-telling of an oft-told tale, but in this case ... it still works alarmingly well.
A weird, talky, fairly sloppy mess of a low-budget genre flick ... but at least it gets good towards the end.
movie_title: The Black Waters of Echo's Pond (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Even on the Corman scale of quality, Humanoids is a decidedly lesser effort -- but that's not to say you won't have some fun.
Benefits from a bit of dark humor, some critically important editing tricks, and a mystery that's actually sort of ... interesting.
There's some real creativity and energy to some of The Horde's best moments; one can't help but wish they existed inside of a less irritating movie.
Even at its slower moments, Julia's Eyes is a classy and lovely horror film to look at.
Wonderfully shot in deep, bleak shadows, set to an aggressively moody musical score, and quick enough to get through the apocalypse in less than 90 minutes.
This might not be the epic sort of effort that the Carpenter fans have been waiting for, but it's still a damn good ghost story that knows how to mess with an audience.
Brutally violent yet beautiful to look at, I Saw the Devil is one of the truest examples of "cat and mouse" storytelling I've ever seen.
A horror flick by way of a "gimmick thriller," with a few dashes of Irwin Allen and Agatha Christie thrown in for flavor.
Same as the others; watchable if you like mindless, gory, zombie exploits. Others need not apply.
Needless to say, Machete would make for an excellent triple feature alongside Planet Terror and Death Proof.
Anyone who dismisses this film as youth-pandering video game ephemera simply isn't looking closely enough.
It's amazing how just a little extra effort can make an action film's "talky parts" almost as much fun as the mayhem.
It's still impressive enough for a flick to be called "a worthwhile sequel to a superior film," and Iron Man 2 is certainly that.
You can practically see the film trying to "color between the lines" laid down in the first film, but there's just enough freshness to keep Part 2 chugging along.
This rather fine documentary reminds us that, yep, even those "old" celebrities we don't have much use for anymore are actual people.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A virtual love letter to the best of "pulp fiction" storytelling and, as such, the film is most assuredly for grown-ups only.
Good enough for the kiddies, but grown-ups may find Part 4 little more than a hollow echo of the original Shrek.
Jordan approaches his latest project as if it's a modern-day fairy tale -- while probably hoping that his audience is not too cynical to play along.
A fantastic horror film that still holds up resoundingly well today.
The "everyman" superhero strikes again, this time with strangely compelling results.
Slightly creepy and very well-shot, but essentially it's a Twilight Zone concept that's been (unkindly) stretched to feature length.
Not scary, hardly compelling, and ultimately pretty silly. Lovely to look at, though.
There's something about an ugly presence in a beautiful setting that's just sort of ... interesting.
The best satanic nazi vampire zombie-master flick that Schumacher's ever made.
Overstays its welcome, but offers some broad fun and some fun broads.
There are legitimate nitpicks, to be sure, but this flick is too enthusiastically over-caffeinated to warrant much anger.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A clever balancing act between basic scares, a creepy concept, and something a little more (dare I say) cerebral.
A simple, basic, fast-paced horror thriller that wastes nary a frame on unnecessary set-up, languid exposition, or pointless subplots.
Hell, you could know nothing about the words "Star Trek" and still find a lot to enjoy here.
Too "safe" to be a provocative thriller or an incendiary drama, and it's way too flat and sedate to qualify as a movie bad enough to mock.
Once you open Pandora's Box, there's simply no stopping the beasts that pour out.
For all of the convention and familiarity that Hush exhibits in the early going, it does a fine job of throwing a few wrenches into a generally predictable premise.
Actually one of the best Asia-to-America adaptations since way back when The Ring (or was it The Grudge?) first got the ball rolling.
Oh, lighten up! It's a pulpy combo of Starship Troopers, The Dirty Dozen and Sky Captain. Perfect for a rainy Saturday afternoon.
Not just an excellent time for what it has to say, but also for the effortlessly exciting way in which it delivers the cargo.
Earns a comfortable spot next to Hatchet, Cold Prey, and Behind the Mask as a basic but sincere "love letter" to the best of the '80s horror flicks
Don't laugh TOO hard at those YouTube 'fools.' That's you and me, don't forget.
The 'scary stuff' ranges from sexual tension and psychological torture to theological threats and simple fear of death by dehydration...
A dry set-up and a familiar setting, but its got an admirable devotion to old-fashioned, over-the-top, Fango-friendly gore-gasms.
Not an original bone in its body, but it still works (and works well) by force of style, splat, and intensity.
Hill and Rogen made precisely the strange little comedy that they wanted to. Trust me when I say that this is NOT your typical studio farce, and that's a wonderful freakin' thing.
Works as a basic, satisfying "revenge thriller," in that it presents a simple story full of rage, retribution, and catharsis -- but it's so much better than that, really.
A loud, rushed, choppy, silly, colorful Nintendo game of a movie. And it could have been DreamWorks' version of "The Incredibles."
An undeniably odd mixture of 80% noir, 15% action, and 5% random homage. I dug it.
A powerfully good film, one that takes a bunch of familiar ingredients, and whips them up into a stew you've never tasted before.
No snark, no irony, just a whip-nasty, well-shot, tightly-cut slasher sequel with a bad attitude. (And yes, it feels like a remake of Halloween 2.)
One of the coolest Aussie offerings of the past several years. Horror-wise, anyway.
A well-shot, competently realized, and surprisingly entertaining mash-up of 16th century "wizards and warriors" and devil-may-care monster mayhem.
A perfect companion piece to the powerfully well-regarded [REC].
Feels a bit like a made-for-cable thriller that borrows liberally from similar flicks, but is still perfectly watchable on a dull Wednesday night.
Scattered across the whole of Night of the Creeps is horror-nerd nirvana.
Emmerich wavers between shocking, silly, and maudlin like a toddler would fingerpaint with red, yellow, and blue.
Where Saw 6 earns a few points over its predecessors is in its devotion to simple but effective gallows humor.
I don't know what could make this movie seem dumber. Oh, and it's also a remake of What You Did Last Summer
Dylan Walsh's demeanor is more compelling than the small handful of perfunctory kill scenes, all of which you'll see from six miles away.
Makes most pitch black comedies look like kids' cartoons ... and I mean that as a rather enthusiastic compliment.
Certainly does infuse its own distinct brand of emotional horror into a story that generally only works on a physical level.
There's a lot more to like about Get Low than just another fantastic Robert Duvall performance.
Raises more questions than it's prepared to answer, but still works as a spotlight shined on a weird part of the movie world.
A compelling and low-key documentary about the American Dream ... and how we often have to go overseas to find it.
Seems intent on delivering a science-fiction / monster movie / adventure tale that's suitable for (mostly) all ages.
Evidence of a veteran horror guy who still has a few colorful stories left to tell. With zombies.
A crisp, efficient, and entirely crafty little kidnapping thriller with three great performances and several nifty twists.
If you can think of a better American horror anthology than this one, I owe you some Halloween candy. (OK, the first Creepshow, but that's about it.)
Almost guaranteed to please the horror fans and comedy kooks in equal measure, Zombieland is a pitch-perfect example of how tasty the "horror/comedy" combo can be.
More of a worthwhile curiosity than anything resembling one of Fulci's best films.
Suffice to say that we won't be seeing an American remake of this one any time soon.
If you've seen how imaginative Terry Gilliam can be with "practical" effects, then you'll probably be dazzled by Imaginarium's finest moments.
A "happy medium" between Soderbergh's "star-laden" flicks and his smaller, yes slightly brainier, movies. Obviously that's a good thing.
A one-timer all the way, and even then I'd only recommend it to the most ravenous and thorough of horror aficionados.
It's clearly low-budget and frequently low-minded, but there's certainly some fun to be found.
Good, dumb, gory fun. And the blu-ray is pretty amazing.
movie_title: Galaxy of Terror (Mindwarp: An Infinity of Terror) (Planet of Horrors) (Quest) (1981)

movie_review_blurb: A nastier, sillier, cheaper version of Alien -- but the blu-ray is great!
Best left for the festival circuit -- which is where we suffer through the indie-style artifice so you don't have to.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A painfully silly movie, one with more heroic intentions than actual assets.
The coolest monster movie import since The Host.
There are dozens of ways a Thor movie could go wrong, but I guess it pays to trust in a talented director and keep your fingers crossed.
Anne Rice meets R.L. Stine. No, that's not a compliment.
Actual effort on a "part 5" is not too common; results as unexpectedly entertaining as Fast Five are rarer still.
Scream was snarky, insightful, and sorta cool. Scream 4 is a aging hypocrite with delusions of insight.
What should have been chaotic, childish, raunchy FUN is instead a shining, shrieking example of Hollywood wastefulness at its most obvious.
Does in 15 minutes what Sucker Punch couldn't do in 110.
Like watching someone channel-surf through five video game boss battles at the same time.
Diverting, loud, occasionally amusing, instantly forgettable, and less than what we expect from this series.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Fans of well-regarded gavel-pounders like Jagged Edge and Primal Fear will enjoy this one as well.
A whole lot sillier, raunchier, and sweeter than its advertising suggests.
It's fresh. It's novel. It's original, challenging, fun, and "deep" all at the same time.
Aims to be a mystery, a "twist ending" psycho-thriller, a gory horror flick, and a fractured character study at once. The parts rarely mesh.
Predictable, obvious, and often corny -- but Battle L.A. is also exciting, kinetic, and six kinds of loud, crazy fun.
A venal, mindless, and aggressively chintzy movie.
Science fiction with half a brain, a lot of weird, quick wit, and a surprisingly full heart.
Very funny, packed with solid action, animated with a remarkable degree of care and creativity, and delivered with a breathless sense of energy.
A dull, unpleasant thriller with no pulse, no thrills, and no soul. Staring into an empty movie theater with a black screen would be more appealing.
"Remedies the familiarity by challenging the very basis of the sub-genre: what happens if an exorcist doesn't believe in the devil?"
A neo-noir sci-fi chase thriller with pharmaceutical tendencies. Fun stuff.
Clever comedy, gorgeous animation, and a huge batch of action craziness. Impressive across the board.
A grade-A popcorn machine that revs on all cylinders: action, character, wit, even a welcome degree of warmth and intelligence.
For all its obvious touches of Spielbergia, Super 8 feels a whole lot like The Iron Giant meets Stand By Me. In a good way.
A surprisingly high-end slasher exploit, but there's a big batch of interesting ideas tucked inside this flick.
Drearily familiar, lazily constructed, and simply not very interesting. No spiders, either.
Even with its familiar trappings and some occasional bumps in the road, The Shrine is an enjoyable little throwback.
"Found footage horror" is here to stay, so let's concentrate on simply separating the good ones from the bad.
Cheap, lazy, uninspired filmmaking that hopes to coast by on a slick DVD cover and a brand name. Don't fall for it.
An improvement over most of the "Maneater Series" entries. Relatively speaking.
Cavayé and co-writer Guillaume Lemans approach their potentially outlandish thriller with a good deal of logic and sense, and that's always a nice switch.
Call it junk if you like, but at least Shark Night is junk that delivers on its promises. Well, most of them, anyway.
There's little to no care paid to anything outside of three or four action sequences -- and those will look just as good on home video. In five weeks.
Moves like a shot, tosses a lot of hardcore lunacy at the screen, and shows a decent amount of respect for basic matinee action-fests.
The "Apes" version of the Star Trek reboot. Yes, it's that good.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Feels like a flick that was poked, tweaked, reformatted and re-edited at least a dozen times.
This is a movie like frozen beef is a burger.
In a year filled with superhero flicks, this one feels a little bit special.
Energy, chemistry, timing, and a palpable sense of raunchy fun.
Actual dialogue: "Emotions run high! And it should!"
An endless slog of flat platitudes, generic cliches, and clumsily on-the-nose saccharine sweetness that feels about as sincere as a Hallmark card.
It's just a bunch of screen-saver bulls---.
A beautiful little jewel of a movie, and I'm thrilled to realize that Woody Allen still has films this good inside of him.
Sony may not give a crap about Quarantine 2, but I wouldn't be surprised if the horror fans dig it well enough.
A lot of eye candy worth savoring, but next to nothing in the departments of wit, depth, heart, or insight.
A certifiably silly film that takes itself and its wackily pedestrian subtext way more seriously than it should.
A road movie, a romantic drama, a post-apocalyptic monster thriller, and more.
A ferocious and fascinating piece of independent filmmaking.
An Irish / Scottish / Celtic-inspired horror mash-up that's equal parts intelligent, engaging, and unexpectedly creepy.
Takes its good, sweet time in getting to the ostensibly scary stuff. But you won't be bored.
Clearly this is the sort of horror movie one could happily "debate" for an hour or two.
It's like Deliverance turns into Hostel halfway through -- only not nearly as good as either of those films.
There's little denying that Cronenberg was way ahead of his time with much of Videodrome.
Pretty leads, pretty camera work, and pretty darn boring.
A B- import that reminds us that "basic" French horror flicks are still generally more interesting than the American ones.
I'd bet good money that Black Death is still finding new fans five or ten years from now.
Not even a few third act plot contortions can salvage the flick from its fairly shameless intent to color within the established lines.
Dull: the last thing a freakin' period-piece action-adventure occult thriller should be.
Hey, action films like Inception only come around every once in a while. We have to watch something!
Fails to do anything memorable with its alleged "last chapter" status. Rather disappointing.
From a newcomer, the ineptitude of this film could be understood; from a man like Wes Craven, it feels like a big fat cheat.
Low-budget vampire apocalypse flick that makes up for in mood and ideas what it lacks in flash and pizazz.
A plot cobbled together from six other horror films -- and yet it's still a fun ride.
Barely a remake of the 1980 sleaze-fest at all. That's a good thing. This is more a horror take on 'Desperate Hours,' actually.
A smart, low-budget 'road thriller' that goes to some very dark places.
A clever vampire concept devolves into another chintzy 'Blade' knock-off.
A film of staggering insight and beauty. Virtually flawless.
A fine and often fascinating documentary from a master storyteller. (Lose the 3-D.)
'Casino Jack' does an impressive job of displaying Abramoff's good and bad in an enjoyably matter-of-fact fashion.
Fun and funny, dark and twisted, semi-schizophrenic and certifiably insane.
My favorite film of all time is one of the finest blu-rays in my collection.
When it's not focused on a biological car-beast that kills people in a variety of un-car-like ways, it's basic across the board
I think there should be a lot more movies like Tremors out there, and no I don't mean more sequels.
At least the DVD is a worthwhile package, even if the flick is better left to the annals of your vague memory.
Very broad, way too talky, and sometimes too damn goofy for its own good.
One of the better offerings from After Dark Batch #4.
Broad and goofy without ever becoming head-slappingly stupid.
Witless, ugly, leering, and unnecessary.
Possessed is no sort of slam-bang horror flick -- but it is a rather smoothly satisfying occult thriller all the same.
It's almost like something Ken Burns would make if he were a huge horror geek.
movie_title: Never Sleep Again: The Elm Street Legacy (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A low-budget, well-paced, impressively performed and quietly engaging indie horror flick.
A goofy piece of over-the-top mayhem with half a brain.
Does a great job of sustaining tension by distracting you with (get this) interesting characters and a novel approach.
A more-than-passable 80-minute expenditure for the serious horror fans.
As a clever combination between truth and fiction, it's a rather impressive little film. Creepy too.
Essentially, Piranha is the best example of how to do a B-movie knockoff.
Everyone tries to make a horror flick this way. Few succeed like Raimi did.
As unexpectedly entertaining as it is plainly beholden to several other suspense thrillers and horror flicks.
Takes the zombie apocalypse and uses it as a backdrop for a story about love, loss, loyalty and betrayal.
What starts out as slight and fairly obvious turns into a frequently colorful horror tale.
Mr. Hartley has proven himself to be quite the excellent curator of globally tacky cinema.
The directors do a very fine job of keeping things creepy and consistently unsettling while trying to make their larger points.
Looks it was prepped, shot, and cut in one drunken weekend.
It just never gets un-scary. That's the best part.
Earns points for combining two sub-genres (revenge and occult) into one surprisingly original tale of violence and redemption.
It's got awesome giant spaceships and massive lumbering monsters and epic explosions and gory kills and it's ... a dumb-fun matinee flick for sure.
Sloppy, choppy, and weird but there's a lot of lowbrow energy and goofy charm too.
A dark and thoughtful film with a legitimately challenging and worthwhile message.
Welcome to the bottom of the barrel. Population: this movie.
Not likely to give anyone outside of toddler range any nightmares, but it's still a smooth, smart, and eminently likable "rainy night" family film.
You won't find a much bigger fan of the original film than yours truly -- and still I was very impressed by this crafty remake.
More of the same, which means you probably already know if you like it. (I mostly did.)
Earns some really nice chills, especially once we hit the big finale.
I admire and detest this film at the same time. And I will never watch it again.
Feels like an affectionate remake of an obscure 1978 Roger Corman production that might have been called "Hot Pants and the Devil Driver."
An entirely accessible mini-budget comedy that coasts on by through sheer force of wit, energy, and "let's put on a show!" creativity.
Finds a pitch-perfect balance between homage and originality.
It's nice to find a wacky movie that knows how to employ "shock value" violence with some degree of timing and cleverness.
Unapologetically gleeful about doling out the cinematic junk food that you're looking for when you sit down to devour something called, well, Piranha.
An "all in one night" crime thriller that's equal parts old-school western and grimly intelligent horror film.
The opening credits sequence is a work of mad genius. And then, unfortunately, the movie starts.
A potentially cool "found footage" flick that is desperately in need of a lot more brains ... or a lot more silliness.
When you consider how many wretched horror remakes we have to suffer through, doesn't a B+ effort like this one deserve a nice pat on the back?
Progresses from uncomfortable character study to subtly intense crime thriller, and ultimately to deep, dark horror.
The final wheeze of the J-horror-inspired domestic thrillers that ran rampant a few years back.
There's a simple sense of old-fashioned restraint that makes Sally's dark journey a little bit quiet, but also subtly satisfying.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A few surprisingly effective set pieces that earn some legitimate scares, regardless of how familiar it's all starting to feel.
