As a thriller that threatens a quick and gruesome demise behind every expended breath, Contagion does a workmanlike job.
Most children give up their poop obsession by age four. Tom Six still hasn't.
Another broad yet eclectic little genre-blender to (maybe) toss into your rental queue.
A horror import that actually has the confidence and audacity to deliver something disturbingly different.
So generic, so lazy, and so forgettable they may as well have "we're not even trying" plastered across the bottom of the screen.
You'll definitely recall this freezing flick the next time you go skiing. For the next 15 years or so.
Works exceedingly well, and will probably stick in your gut for a little while.
A solid balance between set-up, conflict, and horrific execution. Just a well-made horror film all around.
No pretense, no delusions, just slick, basic stalk & shock mayhem with a 3-D coating that works unexpectedly well.
I'd say they did a solid enough job of resurrecting a simple scary tale for a new generation.
A fascinating and confrontational horror film that deals with terrors a lot more chilling than some dude swinging a machete.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If you're a big fan of creaking floorboards, sudden jolts, and abandoned funeral homes, go nuts.
A bit gross, a bit silly, and entirely entertaining.
A Mad Magazine-style zombie-fest that chomps on PC sensibilities like they're made out of obnoxious male flesh.
Earns points for enthusiasm, creativity, and a powerful devotion to all things ultra-splattery.
A confrontational film that dances between the sublime, the mundane, and the shocking with little to no regard for audience expectations.
There's always something to be said for a psycho-thriller that delivers interesting characters in a cool setting.
Directed crisply and with a palpable air of mid-'70s paranoia thriller.
An absolute slap in the face to the fans who made the franchise a hit in the first place.
There's not a pained expression, a confused sneer, or a filthy grimace that Zombie won't linger on for 10 seconds longer than he needs to.
A fantastic deconstruction of how a bad film actually earn its "cult fave" status.
Made for those who have fond memories of low-key '70s devil chillers that focused on mood and atmosphere
The integral problem with Jennifer's Body is that of tone. Or lack thereof.
A fresh coat of paint applied to an impressively old-fashioned ghost story.
As a dark, strange and enjoyably paranoid little sci-fi thriller, I'd say the good points outweigh the bad by a long shot.
It's not a film about the gradual extinction of humankind -- it's actually about the horrible demise of humanity.
A rock-solid afternoon matinee sort of movie, packed as it is with so many disparate genre influences. Confidently crafted and legitimately clever.
Despite a good lead performance and a few cool ideas, 11-11-11 is also packed with a lot of airy chit-chat that either repeats established ideas or simply goes nowhere.
One of the better films of the infamous J-horror remake onslaught. Relatively speaking.
A concise little old-school British ghost story, and I say there's always room for a few more of those.
Knows how to deliver some familiar goods, sprinkled with just enough "new stuff" to keep the horror hounds from feeling insulted.
Rare is the flick that wedges this many genres into one frame, and so well.
A tough, almost willfully difficult movie, but it's fascinating more often than it is dramatically off-putting.
Deserves credit for trying to mine some relatively intelligent chills out of something different, topical, and primally disturbing.
Clearly suffers from post-production tinkering but offers some decent chills at its best moments.
An earnest and well-made character-based horror flick that's simply not all that interesting.
A '50s premise, a '70s theme, and a new-fangled presentation. Fun stuff. Also it gets really gross and disturbing, which is meant as a compliment.
Another quietly effective horror story from the Emerald Isle.
Does a fine job of balancing some legitimately smart ideas with its requisite moments of pain, suffering, and horror.
Dark, disturbing, confrontational stuff. Also a damn good film.
One of the strangest, darkest, and most confident "female-centric" horror flicks in quite some time.
Works perfectly well as a turn-off-the-lights (and be-willing-to-play-along) piece of sci-fi-sprinkled horror amusement.
An hour of miscellaneous visions that will make more sense once Act II lurches to a close and we finally get to the good stuff.
movie_title: The Haunting in Connecticut 2: Ghosts of Georgia (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A schizophrenic but effective little combo of Hostel and Irwin Allen.
Some "vampire stuff" you've seen before, a few new ideas that work, two great performances, and a lot of skilled veterans behind the camera.
Standard "stalk, attack, revenge" home invasion material, but it's also laced with an appreciable sense of pointed social commentary.
A tight-fisted little piece of gender-centric survival horror.
An old-fashioned haunted house horror story made by people who love them. Classy, creepy, fun.
Home invasion/slasher stuff that has a nasty attitude and a speedy demeanor.
Not much that's new (hey, it's a sequel) but there's still an old-fashioned respect for the pleasures of simple creepiness.
Old fashioned, straightforward, entertaining sci-fi horror.
It's gross and creepy and precisely the sort of horror movie your mother would probably hate.
Hits its stride in Act II, and once that moment has passed, you're stuck with one irritating slog toward a rather disappointing climax.
This 91-minute mash-up of Halloween creatures and non-stop silliness hits the ground running and virtually never slows down.
There's some fun to be had, but we've officially reached the "for fans only" stage of this particular horror franchise.
One shudders to think of how many worthwhile horror films Paramount passed up to acquire this terribly drab junkpile.
The indie king of the slow-burn horror flick is back, and this time Ti West is bringing along an unexpected dose of wit, warmth, and weirdly effective character-based comedy.
Lots of silliness, a few nasty kills, and a cool third act.
Clever enough to make you reconsider how you look at horror films. And a ton of fun, too.
Not just a bad film; it's evidence of people who are barely even trying.
This movie looks like it was shot in 1989 and cobbled together randomly.
Manages to deliver a decent combination of supernatural and practical horrors.
Rare is a film this silly that's also this quietly clever.
For all its familiar ideas, characters, and scares, Chernobyl Diaries earns points on restraint, mood, and location.
Not much more than "28 Weeks Later in a hospital," but surely that sounds like fun.
Doles out its best ideas and moments with a strong sense of restraint, timing, and impact.
Sweet, morbid, funny, clever, and occasionally brilliant.
A group of Irish villagers have to stay drunk to keep alcohol-fearing alien monsters at bay. Yup.
If splattery Japanese weirdness is what you're into, there's no denying that this flick delivers the goods, and then some.
Poses some compelling questions about the emotional and mental impact of making dark, violent, disturbing films.
This frantic lark is a bit more clever and a lot more amiable than most of what passes for "zom-com" these days.
An intermittently fascinating character study about a plain man who does evil things for selfish reasons.
A welcome return to form for the brilliant, inconsistent Tim Burton.
A "sleepover night" horror movie made for young people who haven't seen many good horror movies.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A sweet, simple, satisfying documentary about a bunch of people who really love the Halloween season.
It's the take-no-prisoners enthusiasm with which Bates leaps into his suburban nightmare that makes Excision so interesting.
Evidence of a group of filmmakers who take their horror seriously.
You've got enough ideas for an entire geek-friendly trilogy in this one crazy movie.
Takes a B-minus import and turns it into a D-minus retread.
What we might actually call a "thinking man's slasher flick."
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The result is a strange but surprisingly effective pair of fractured characters who have the audacity to buck indie flick convention and head off into some dark, weird, and sobering places.
We're still not sure when Before I Wake will get a release, but I can tell you at least this much: it hasn't been delayed for reasons of quality. It's actually pretty fantastic, truth be told.
While The Fantastic Four '94 may never (officially) see the light of day, it's still pretty satisfying that Doomed exists to give these filmmakers a brief moment in the spotlight.
movie_title: Doomed: The Untold Story Of Roger Corman's The Fantastic Four (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Not only one of the most novel "home invasion" movies you'll ever see, but easily one of the best horror flicks of the year.

How much you enjoy the flick will depend on your ability to accept its disregard for logic, reality, technology, and the laws of physics, but if you're willing to dig its lunacy, there's definitely some fun to be had here.

Lights Out may be a quick, simple, and slightly familiar piece of PG-13-level horror, but it's also a well-made and unexpectedly engaging thriller as well -- with an ending that's sure to generate at least a small amount of debate among horror fans.

We all want to watch what happens when crime is made legal, but deep down we all want to root for the heroes. That this series allows a viewer to have its cake and eat it too is only one of its cleverer aspects.

If you're in the mood for a smart, mellow, handsomely shot, and quietly engaging espionage story, Our Kind of Traitor should easily fit the bill -- especially if you're a fan of all those other John le Carré adaptations.

To its credit, The Trust is considerably more interested in character quirks and offbeat conversations filled with basic tropes and cliches, and the chemistry between the two leads is really quite entertaining.
Bite is one of the best indie horror films I've seen all year.

Rogen and Byrne, in particular, have grown into quite the complementary comedic duo in both Neighbors flicks, and it's that pairing that will earn my ten bucks once again whenever the inevitable Neighbors 3 shows up at my local multiplex.

As is (almost) always the case with anthology films, Holidays is best described as a "mixed bag." And yet it's the wildly different collection of tones, attitudes, and storytelling styles that makes the collection so interesting.
The Invitation equires a bit of patience but it rewards the attentive viewer with a remarkably intense and disturbing series of scares.
A fast-paced, impressively efficient, and wildly suspenseful cat & mouse thriller.
Great to see Reubens dive back into the Pee-wee Herman character with such sweet, silly, and satisfying results.

While we'll always have the epic Apollo stories like the ones found in The Right Stuff, Apollo 13, and From the Earth to the Moon, it's refreshing to come across a documentary that illustrates how special the explorers actually were.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A rock-solid horror anthology that boasts numerous nasty surprises.
It's sure to make you feel just a little bit better about your own family issues.
[If] Sam Peckinpah, John Boorman, or Arthur Penn ever opted to direct a low-budget 1978 horror flick, it might look a little like Carnage Park.
Not without its own minor merits, but if it's a horror flick you're looking for, I'd just stick with the French film.
Almost painfully conventional, but the cast is solid and Act III delivers some decent chills.
Given how silly most of the films in the "killer dog" canon are, this one feels like a breath of fresh air.
The whole thing is a big mess, but sometimes it is an amusing mess -- and doubly so once Cage shows up. Bless his heart.

Rupert Grint earns a few chuckles throughout, as do a handful of the supporting players, but ultimately Moonwalkers feels a whole lot like a funny idea that never got fleshed out beyond its second act.
An old-school piece of network TV escapism, it's fun for nostalgia value, the cuteness of Powers, and the jazzy theme song.
The result is a colorful, crazy, and occasionally tasteless movie. One suspects that Doug Kenney would have approved.

Best of all, it's the sort of untraditional, original, personal indie flicks that seems to reward repeat viewings - and seems likely to pick up lots of fans over the next several years, albeit in almost exclusively word-of-mouth fashion.

So while this one might not feel quite as exciting as discovering a new sports comedy classic, there's always something to be said for a sequel that captures the spirit of the original and forges some new ground of its own.
For plain old movie geeks, however, Score: A Film Music Documentary is nothing short of an absolute delight.

It may make you feel happy, sad, excited, dejected, angry, and hopeful... all at the same time, and that's a pretty rare feat for one movie to pull off. To me it feels like 1/3 Spielberg, 1/3 Gilliam, and 1/3 completely novel, exciting originality.

Trey Edward Shults' stark, sobering, and quietly fascinating It Comes at Night is for genre fans who are in the market for something more cerebral and personal than the average "end of the world" story.
Hounds of Love is so quietly engrossing and flatly terrifying, it may inspire you to read up on some of the tragic events that inspired the film. I know I did.
There's a lot of light, heart, and compassion to be found in this lovely little documentary, and I hope it finds a warm, sunny place in the hearts of cat lovers everywhere.

Once A Dark Song starts delving into issues like love, loss, faith, and the natural human reaction to sudden tragedy, that's when it blossoms from a novel concept to a truly powerful piece of genre filmmaking.
The House on Willow Street works unexpectedly well as a pulpy, unpretentious, horror comic book of a movie.
I think it's one of the most interesting, captivating movies I've seen in years, and I look forward to dissecting its lovely, twisted, romantic genius in future viewings.
Mayhem boasts a pair of leads that not only get the tone of the piece, but jump into its lunacy quite enthusiastically.
Prevenge turns out to be one of the best movies of its kind in quite some time.
If you dug the first flick enough to consider a second chapter a welcome diversion, then odds are you'll find something to like here.

While a substantial early portion of Don't Knock Twice may feel a bit familiar, it quickly finds its feet and settles into a nice spooky groove that fans of indie/import horror will be sure to appreciate.

Emotionally unstable kids can do some terrible things, especially when provoked by terrifying ideas, but hopefully frank, honest films like Beware the Slenderman will help make us all a little more attentive to these things in the future.

Death Race... delivers the goods on tongue-in-cheek action, simplistic yet effective social commentary, and a bunch of actors who clearly get the tone of the piece, and are willing to go way over the top in silly, campy, and sometimes ultra-violent fun.
If the Underworld series has finally run out of steam in its fifth chapter, at least it goes out with a decent enough bang.

Spectral probably won't win many awards for originality, but if you're down for a "ghosts vs. soldiers" action flick that doesn't take itself all that seriously [and] moves at a nice pace... then Spectral will probably fit the bill.

[As a] horror fan who tolerated and then promptly forgot all about Ouija '14, I found myself more than reasonably engaged by what Flanagan and company cooked up for this offbeat, soft-spoken, and subtly spooky prequel.
A well-made, thought-provoking, and quietly satisfying science fiction film.
Nicely shot and scored but there's not a whole lot of meat, style, or substance here.

Given that most killer bear movies are either intentionally cheesy or unwittingly inept, it's nice to see a new one that takes the concept seriously and forgoes easy splatter in favor of some strong, simple, sustained suspense.
Well-paced, nicely shot, and smart enough to give each member of the ensemble a few moments to shine.
Coasts along at such an energetic clip that it's hard to not have a little fun with all the crazy witch madness.
A full-bore psychological gut punch of a horror film.
You may never trust trick-or-treaters again after this movie.
A horror movie every bully should see.
A blissfully mean-spirited and aggressively creepy terror tale, and one that's not content to simply rest on its one good concept.
The guy's about as intimidating as a mildly irritated kitten, and that certainly doesn't up the creep factor.
Pretty funny, surprisingly smart, pleasant to look at, and often quite sick.
As far as stuff like mood, atmosphere, tone, and intensity is concerned, this sequel is a completely empty vessel.
A big-budget psycho-thriller that lets two of our more "sedate" leading men cut loose with some entertainingly juicy performances.
A tight-fisted slow burn that whacks you in face with two or three really horrifying sequences.
Little more than a grungy-looking TV movie of the week with some pointless gore tossed in.
If you can't improve upon your original in some small way, then you're simply churning out assembly-line product for a gradually more disinterested fan-base.
If you're in the mood for a Saturday afternoon-ish throwback thriller, you could certainly do a hell of a lot worse than this one.
It's a dark, harsh, and sometimes powerfully unpleasant film, but it's also very well made.
movie_title: Jack Ketchum's The Girl Next Door (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Definitely one of the best King adaptations in years ... and I've seen 'em all.
Pick the lamest Halloween sequel out there and you've just found a better horror movie than this one.
Feels like an old-school slasher flick that's been hidden on a dusty shelf for the past twenty years. And yes, I mean that as a compliment.
If there was a list of movies about killer mutated sheep, this would undoubtedly be the best of the bunch.
This "smaller" experiment turns out to be William Friedkin's best film in over 20 years.
A damn worthy follow-up to an unexpectedly excellent chiller.
It's not even remotely scary, which leaves the horror fans out. But it's also way too boring to even poke fun at.
A passable sequel that earns points for trying to expand upon its predecessor, even if it takes a little while to get to the new stuff.
A quick, cheap, churn-it-out product that offers nothing you haven't seen before.
For such a small film, The Visit represents a big win for M. Night Shyamalan.
Barely scary but frequently funny.
Wild Tales is not just a film you'll enjoy. It's one you'll want to talk about when it's over, either to debate the morals of the film - or to convince someone else to watch it.
It's all very quaint, nostalgic, and comfortable.
Dougherty is going for a mid-'80s/Robert Zemeckis/Joe Dante/Tales from the Crypt type of presentation, and he did a damn good job of it.
At its core it's just another sports movie - and hell, a Part 7, no less - but there's a strong and sincere foundation that works resoundingly well.
There's a whole lot of arid downtime in between the ostensibly colorful set pieces, and on the whole the movie seems like it was edited with a blender.
Sloppy, obvious, and highly immature, but it does manage to shine in one or two sequences.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Often feels like a tongue-in-cheek episode of Red Shoe Diaries.
Perhaps one day I'll come across a Guillermo del Toro film I dislike, but it sure as hell won't be today.
A big bowl of bite-sized treats.
One of the most captivating and thought-provoking horror films in years.
A mixed bag of missteps and mild successes, but it does feature some fun work from Mr. Gross.
A mean-spirited and creepy, but oddly amusing, Old West tale that feels like an homage to Robert E. Howard's wildest western chillers.
A meticulously morbid and deviously entertaining piece of low-budget/high-quality action filmmaking.
An impressively on-point homage to the early horror films of Brian De Palma and David Cronenberg. Also it's fun.
One the smartest, sweetest, and most satisfyingly suspenseful sci-fi films in years.
Offers everything from basic "jump scares" to high-end suspense to darkly disturbing thematic dread.
Offers a great oral history of the publication's rise and fall, as told by dozens of people who were actually there.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Does a remarkable job of bringing a fascinating, difficult novel to the big screen.
A low-budget, high-energy, quick-witted homage to the best in 1980s matinee movies.
For the most part, the western is a particularly male-oriented genre. And that's sort of what makes Daniel Barber's The Keeping Room such a cool, satisfying surprise.
There's no way a studio would throw any money at gory, Goth-y musicals that toss horror, comedy, and religion into a blender - which makes these odd little movies all the more admirable.
Feels a lot like a Christmas version of Michael Dougherty's seasonal favorite Trick 'r Treat, and that's meant as a compliment.
Whether Mr. Argento meant this to be A) serious, B) silly, or C) a combination of both, the end result is, I'm sorry to say, almost completely unwatchable.
As a conversation piece for hardcore film buffs and Disney fans, it's a fascinating little curiosity -- but that's about it.
Judged solely on the scale of Giant Spider Cinema, the slick and silly Big Ass Spider ranks surprisingly high.
Suffice to say there's a whole lot to like about Turbo Kid, particularly if you're old enough to remember (or at least appreciate) the lower-end genre films of the 1980s.

The filmmakers are well aware of how silly this franchise has become. They're more than happy to keep the good times rolling, just so long as they can keep finding new and amusing ways in which to drive cars irresponsibly and destroy buildings at will.
One wild, wacky mess of a movie.
An unexpectedly solid little horror flick that gets a lot more interesting the longer you give it.
Does a fine job of balancing dark humor, creepy vibes, and outright melodrama -- and what a cool cast, right?
Sue me, I give it a mild "fresh." Call me a sucker for found footage, Egyptian mythology, overripe dialogue, and mutant cats.
The cast generates some laughs, and the leading lady is adorable, but the musical sequences range from clunky to painful. And there are lots of them.
Not the most consistently amusing film of the Rogen / Franco collection, but certainly the most politically audacious. Also: still pretty funny.
As a war movie, it's pretty solid. As a character study, it's virtually generic. Cooper's strong performance salvages the rough spots.
Might not be the first film about the dangers inherent in giving robots free will, but it's certainly one of the most accomplished.
A bit too icy, distant, and austere to qualify as a movie one would "love," Foxcatcher is still a remarkably engrossing film.
The beauty of the film is in its simple, honest analysis of the human condition -- and in Ms. Cotillard's powerfully good performance.
So blatantly lazy and outrageously stupid it somehow makes me like the first Taken a little bit less. End this merciless tedium.
A cerebral and sensitive sci-fi time-travel mind-bender you'll want to watch twice in a row. (Like I did.)
Sweet, charming, amusing, and classy. The sort of movie kids will still love when they're old and cynical.
Wavers between absurd and predictable while appropriating themes and ideas from a half-dozen better sci-fi flicks.
Either you want to see Salma Hayek destroying waves of underworld scumbags, or you do not.
It's a found footage war movie about soldiers vs. aliens. Basic stuff, but it's not boring.

While one can plainly see why an actor/producer of Reese Witherspoon's stature would snatch this story up and cast herself in the lead role, the plain truth is that she also delivers some of the best work of her career in Wild.

If you're a patient film buff who relishes the idea of a low-key yet consistently compelling cinematic biography that's in no real hurry to get anywhere, there's a whole lot to admire about Mr. Turner.
A crime story, a character study, and a really kick-ass pressure cooker.
Illustrates how honest enthusiasm can gradually transform itself into ego, arrogance, and borderline obsession.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Funny, vulgar, wildly gory, and (whaaat?) actually kinda sweet.
Night Owls is "The Pally & Salazar Show" all the way, which is great news because these two actors have a natural chemistry together.
Smarter, cleverer, and subtly creepier than what one might expect from its premise.
Suffers from standard biopic formatting, but there's still a whole lot to appreciate here.
Simplistic and obvious, but it also does a fine job of emulating the late-'80s monster movies we all know and love.
The giallo satire we've all been waiting for. All 19 of us.
So constantly and oppressively gross that it starts to feel like more of endurance test than a light comedy.

He Never Died is a cool, confident, frequently sarcastic, and unexpectedly accomplished piece of work that'd probably still work pretty well with a different actor in the lead role, but then we'd be missing out on the best work of Henry Rollins' career.
Illustrates the difference between good and evil in a remarkably clear, honest, and subtle fashion.
So wacky I almost fell asleep.
Delivers a generous dose of bee movie madness.
Fast-paced, character-based, and appreciably energetic.
Provides a whole lot of interesting tidbits about the project's long and convoluted development process, and it does so in a thorough, upbeat, and amiable fashion.
movie_title: The Death of Superman Lives: What Happened? (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Precisely as good as it sounds.
Not only does Ms. Field seem to bring out the best in her co-stars, but she still brightens the screen with every smile.
You've seen it all before, true, but at least it's not boring.
Pretty weak stuff -- and I actually (really) liked Part 1.
movie_title: The Man with the Iron Fists 2 (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A mixture of very broad and very sly that's quite simply a whole lot of fun.
A Joe Dante movie I didn't like?!? Oh, well. It was bound to happen at least once.
It's hard to tell if there's anywhere left for this series to go, but at least they pulled off Chapter 3 with some class.
An amazing piece of genre filmmaking, and, frankly speaking, 90% of the Hollywood action film community just got schooled by a 70-year-old veteran.
A lazy cover of a great song.
A fascinating and frequently brutal tale of loyalty, revenge, and ancient tribal warfare.
Once Extraterrestrial gets gruesome and starts delivering the mayhem, there's certainly some fun to be found here.
A feature-length sitcom, plus profanity, minus commercials. Several chuckles throughout, but almost painfully conventional.
An excellent documentary about a great man, certainly, but it's also a reminder of why we all love movies. Thumbs eternally up.
"The filmmakers admire what they're emulating here, and it's hard to not play along with the grim, gritty fun."
The kind of awful movie that gives awful movies a bad name.
Endlessly fascinating and frequently sublime. Smart, insightful, funny, etc.
Decent payoffs for those who are interested in playing along -- and willing to contend with a few slow spots in the mid-section.
The scary stuff works, the characters are actually pretty likable, and the franchise mythology is given its fair due ...without overdoing it.
Credit the script and the editing as well, but American Hustle is quite simply an actor's movie, and the entire ensemble is just fun to watch.
Expands on the best stuff from movie #1 and fixes some things that didn't work so well. That's a good way to make a sequel.
A fun cast and a decent presentation but man is this a story we've heard 1,000 times.
A hodge-podge of horror tropes that frequently congeals into something fun.
Church-set found-footage slow-burner with some solid payoffs.
Slick, breezy, amusing, a little sloppy, and rather fun. Saturday matinee stuff.
When it comes to combining zombies and comedy, the British simply know what they're doing.
A well-made but generally predictable next-gen Fatal Attraction.
Rough stuff.
Cool Korean horror anthology.
Decent enough found footage fare that deals with a small town's creepy secret.
Kids vs. monsters tale that take a while to warm up, but picks up nicely.
A collection of disparate genre parts that are presented with a noted lack of snark or irony.
A decent, uneven, well-made spin on a very standard horror story.
Takes the coolest parts of the original Aussie thriller and adds some more goofy fun.
A frank, unpredictable, and sometimes devastating thriller.
Works as not only a compliment to the original, but also as an impressive complement.
Lucky Bastard is a frank, fascinating, and decidedly "adult" piece of horror filmmaking.
Tailor-made for Benson's loyal fan-base - and those who love all things related to marijuana and/or Comic-Con, of course.
Moves really quick, offers a generous amount of shocks, and displays a slyly dark sense of humor.
This is a smart, intense, and frequently tragic horror story.
Not just a solid indie flick or a strong adaptation of a well-regarded novel. It's one of the most impressive films of the year.
A smart, calm horror flick that borrows from a few classics but also marks some territory of its own.
A fantastic achievement: a novel, passionate, and energized sci-fi with wild action and strange humor.
"Before Sunset with Vampires" may be simplistic, but it's meant as high praise.
Takes a little while to warm up, but this is a cool and classy piece of epic monster movie-making.
A respectably old-school chiller that feels sort of refreshing, even if it doesn't leave much of an impression.
Do you have to fully "understand" a film to enjoy it? No. Case in point: this movie.
Doesn't always work as a cohesive whole, but it does have more than a few good moments.
For a "pointless" and "unnecessary" remake, there's actually some really solid stuff in this one.
Takes a little while to get cooking, but once you-know-who pops up, there's some solid fun to be had.
More deadpan, clever, and silly than it is simple, "schticky," or mean-spirited.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Frequently sloppy and pretty piecemeal, but also rather funny and oddly likable. Strange flick.
Some of Bob Kurtzman's third act make-up effects are a small silver lining, but unfortunately Jinn is a pretty laughable affair.
Today's lesson is "How not to make a found footage film."
A clever indie noir/horror that feels like someone really loves Angel Heart. So at least they have good taste.
The Last Days may not represent the flashiest apocalypse story you'll ever see, but there's always something to be said for clever storytelling, good acting, and novel apocalypse tales.
The result is a low-key mind-bender that feels half-scripted, half improvised, and -- for the most part -- rather surprisingly compelling.
A dark, slick, and appealing thriller that pulls suspense from some very cool places.
Wow!
A nasty demeanor, an excellent lead performance, plenty of strong support work, and a thoroughly expeditious pace. Dark fun.
The Den has some pretty compelling things to say about the alleged safety of the internet. Also it's creepy.
All I know is one or two moments really creeped me out, and I never get creeped out. If that's not a compliment, I don't know any.
It's hardly among the best of the Dimension Extreme acquisitions, but it works well enough for a 90-minute time-waster.
movie_title: Dead in Three Days (In 3 Tagen bist du tot) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You'll notice all sorts of horror movie DNA floating through We Are Still Here, but it's also sort of novel and even a little bit unique in its own right.
A very funny comedy of errors material that's delivered in a broad and very bloody fashion.
Seems to be shooting for an earnest homage to Steven Spielberg's Duel. Not half bad.
A funny, smart, and subversive satire about the way women are often objectified in horror films. Only not boring, like that description is.
Taken as a two-person character study/reluctant buddy movie/legitimately novel slant on a very oft-told tale, there's certainly a lot to like here.
A lovely homage to haunted house cinema -- and a very crafty ghost story in its own right.
Virtually a found footage remake of Rosemary's Baby, but it's a pretty fun version of that.
Picks up steam as characters die horribly and some surprisingly solid special effects start making their way through all the low-tech security cameras.
The creepy, insightful and effectively melancholy Marianne is a quiet little winner.
A refreshingly novel take on a rather oft-told apocalypse tale.
A mellow and contemplative character drama that also happens to be a ghost story.
Probably the best Bigfoot horror flick out there.
There are definitely some worthwhile ideas and components here. They're just trapped in a film that can't afford them.
As a low-budget disaster thriller, the film works well enough - but it's the commitment the supernatural "question" that makes Beneath worth checking out.
Starts out as the epitome of predictable and gradually grows more novel as we move on.
Smart, devious, audacious filmmaking from a man who's quickly becoming a master at this sort of stuff.
May not be the flashiest or most intense thriller you'll see this month, but it does have a gloomy vibe, a quietly compelling story, and a few unexpected bits you may not see coming.
Well-shot, well-acted and, well, kinda boring.
A confident, rough, and confrontational horror film.
Covers a lot of emotional and intellectual terrain for such an unassuming and modest indie horror film, and that's only part of what makes it so impressive.
A big batch of energetic silliness made for people who love zombie movies, but don't mind a little comedy mixed in once in a while. OK, a lot of comedy.
movie_title: Dead Snow 2: Red vs. Dead (Død snø 2) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Covers an admirable amount of genre-friendly ground before winding up with a funny, suspenseful, and kinetic third act.
Expands the "crime is temporarily legal" concept in all sorts of juicy ways.
A standard haunted house set-up, only with strong acting, handsome cinematography, and an old-fashioned sense of crafty restraint.
Starts out strong and unpredictable -- and then slowly (very slowly) runs out of steam.
A virtual remake of The Evil Dead, but it does showcase some pretty impressive gore.
There's something to be said for going back to old-school scares once the self-mocking silliness dries up.
If you've ever been lost at night on a road you've never seen before, you'll probably get a kick out of In Fear.
A patchwork, conventional, and oft-told story that's a whole lot sillier than was probably intended.
What the new Carrie lacks in original ideas, it makes up for in many other departments.
A dark, captivating, and thoroughly fascinating piece of genre filmmaking.
It all gets very artsy and weird in Act III (and I watched it twice) but hey, I'll take a bit of cerebral effort over just a bunch of door-slamming and bloodletting.
The trilogy ends with a bang. And blood. A bit clumsy in the plot department but still pretty good fun.
Works as both a gut-punch horror film and a distressingly downbeat adventure story.
A fast-paced and very informative primer on all things cinematic and zombified.
Clear evidence of filmmakers who love musical theater and slasher flicks in equal measure.
Adequately creepy, flashy, and/or exciting when the story calls for it, but considerably more interesting for its quieter, craftier moments.
Wants you to laugh AT the ridiculousness of their concept, but (to the film's credit) it also gets us to start laughing WITH the movie.
A great location, a typically strong performance from Ms. McIntosh, and an admirably expeditious pace keeps this thriller moving.
What some may see as "slow and uneventful storytelling" I see as "subtle and masterfully sustained suspense."
Strikes an astute balance between a simply engaging dark thriller and a trenchant piece of social commentary. Also it's a lot of fun.
It's actually got a novel idea, a handful of legitimately creepy moments, and an admirable sense of Twilight Zone-style madness
Stands as a firm and very convincing argument that Night of the Living Dead (1968) is among the most important and influential films of all time.
Compared to Cabin Fever 2 or simply taken on its own merits, Cabin Fever 3 is a surprisingly amusing piece of sci-fi splatter cinema.
A well-shot, multi-dimensional, and unexpectedly cerebral little horror story.
A bizarre but consistently creepy tale of bad religion, bad spirits, and very bad behavior.
A nifty, twisty screenplay that starts out very simple and gradually tightens into a surprisingly suspenseful affair.
Feels like a 1988 New World Pictures production that somehow got locked in a vault and forgotten for 25 years.
Full of great little touches that add up to a whole lot, and a wonderful reminder that one need not re-invent the wheel to create a quality horror movie.
Manages to work as its own distinct film, even if certain portions will remind you of everything from Steven Spielberg to Clive Barker.
movie_title: Among the Living (Aux yeux des vivants) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Not nearly as consistent as its predecessors, but at least two of the segments are quite solid.
Comes to life during the action scenes, if only slightly.
At its best moments it seems to be channeling something co-written by Neil Simon and Eli Roth.
Horror fans will have no problem appreciating this unexpectedly novel exploration into why we hate those damn clowns so much.
Even accepting that Red Trail 90 was made by (virtually) one guy on a very limited budget, the film still suffers from a variety of problems.
Call it a rape/revenge movie with an occult twist, or a simple slasher flick with something to say about the hidden power of certain minorities.
An affectionate and consistently amusing homage to a whole bunch of movies that probably shouldn't go together.
movie_title: The Ghastly Love of Johnny X (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A funny, creative, fast-paced, and well-shot horror satire. They do exist.
A dark, smart, sobering, anti-romantic horror story
Not even remotely original, but still a surprisingly decent little psychological chiller.
Recommended solely to open-minded Lovecraft nuts who can overlook some rough spots and focus on an earnest attempt at adapting a notoriously difficult author.
A scrappy, strange, and inconsistent little "gimmick" flick, but it's also a testament to what a small group of filmmakers can pull off with very little money
Manages to touch on some compelling points before committing to its familiar but satisfying finale
Wraps a simple, scary story inside of a decidedly contemporary package.
A wonderfully shot, cleverly written, and subtly effective horror movie.
The most depressing thing about this feckless, ugly, and pointless film is how edgy and insightful it aims to be.
It's the gradual tightening of the narrative noose that makes Carmi's debut feature such an unexpected treat.
Starts out a bit slowly, but gets pretty bloody, creepy, and even a little bit shocking by the end.
Some of these shorts are pretty silly, but Zombieworld boasts at least two segments are borderline brilliant.
When it's focused on chases, scrapes, escapes, and all-out dino-frenzy ACTION, there's a good deal of fun to be had.
A familiar but creepy little shocker that boasts an exotic locale and some unpredictable moments.
Proof positive that you don't need a whole lot of money, glitz, or gore to make a cool horror film.
A smart, clever, and diverting little mash-up of numerous sci-fi and horror tropes.
Twisted, uneven, and sorta sweet.
The filmmakers cared about every moody shadow, every slightly stodgy performance, and (of course) the dark, disturbing imagination of H.P. Lovecraft.
A rough, smart, homemade horror movie that has some stark, challenging subtext and that gradually progresses from a genre-mash-up to a certifiable mind-bender.
Feels a bit like 15 slasher movies you've already seen, but also ends up being a rather novel, unpredictable, and insane little horror flick.
Truth be told, there were only three or four shorts that just didn't work for me. No, I'm not singling them out.
Anyone who makes horror films should be inspired by movies like It Follows.
Good script, strong cast, several quality scares... yeah, it's actually a decent haunted mirror movie!
A rough, gritty indie combo of Faust and Black Swan -- set in the cutthroat world of young Hollywood.
It's an odd yet oddly engaging combination of horror, romance, and dark comedy, and it's certainly one of the most original genre films you'll see all year.
Half an homage to horror stories you already know, and half a collection of themes, ideas, moments, and shocks you might not see coming.
Most most assuredly a "niche" horror flick, but if you like Lucio Fulci you'll like this.
No gimmicks, no gore, just a nice feature-length Twilight Zone episode with a few cool ideas and some strong payoffs.
Has enough assets to make one wish the screenplay was a bit more novel than just another "people trekking through the forest" set-up.
Features some great performances, a worthwhile sense of strange humanity, and, ultimately, a handful of truly cool werewolf sequences.
A refreshingly unpredictable film. Call it a "film noir horror romance," if you like.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A crisp 80-minute horror movie that may take a few scenes to get rolling, but also showcases some very interesting ideas and a great lead performance.
Doesn't come close to eclipsing the first two entries, but is certainly an improvement over Part 3.
Not as strong as the first outing, but it still works as a classy and refined example of how to revisit the "vintage" horror vibe.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It actually feels like a "Discovery Channel"-style documentary that just happens to wander into some very supernatural places.
A dry, wise-assed, and slyly appealing comedy/horror mix.
A straightforward, sincere, and solid effort that doesn't do anything "new" with found footage, but still works a lot better than many of its ilk.
Might be worth seeing solely for the moment when Dracula says, "I'm worth 1,000 boys and you know it."
Works as a dry comedy, a slow-burn campfire story, and as a clever look at our frustratingly one-sided relationship with the paranormal.
A fantasy adventure film needs more than "cool creatures," a rousing score, and two certifiably over-the-top performances to make a lasting impression.
Feels like three horror comic books jammed together and then re-written by a pair of clever wise-asses.
I've seen hundreds of horror movies in my time, and I've never seen anything quite as disturbing as the final sequences of The Cove.
This is a grim, gory, and unapologetically grungy piece of "survival horror." I dug it.
The subject matter would still be fairly interesting without Rock's involvement, but the comedian brings a accessibility to the material that no amount of facts and figures can replace.
A dry, ponderous, and virtually intrigue-free combination of Frailty and Misery.
It'd take a considerably more charming pair of leads to salvage a concept this lame and a screenplay this witless.
Sadly, and this annoys me to no end, 94% of the Disney sequels are just rotten. But that won't stop the studio from re-releasing the things.
movie_title: Lady and the Tramp II: Scamp's Adventure (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Non-sensical dub-fest in which a bunch of dry international dolts head out to Venus -- slowly.
I could say it's laughable, embarrassing, woefully inept, and absolutely Ed Woodsian in style and presentation, but why bother?
Whose idea was it to give out Peter Pan hats and short-shorts to Earth's first guy/girl astro-squad?
Taken as sort of a pre-pre-pre-historic Apollo 13, I suspect the die-hard sci-fi fans might enjoy this one.
Brief snippets of eye-candy aside, this flick's as dumb as a box of rocks and twice as pointless.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Film Jack Black doing anything for 80 minutes and you're bound to wring a few yuks from the footage, but the chuckles delivered here are distressingly few and far between.

If Only this weren't one of the sappiest, stupidest, silliest, and most vacuously meaningless romantic comedies I've ever had the misfortune to waste 96 minutes of my life upon ... I'd have some nicer things to say.
Basically, The Missing is Ron Howard's John Ford impersonation, and the end result is as strangely schizophrenic as it sounds.
It unfolds like a particularly cool episode of The Twilight Zone and it keeps the apocalypse interesting up to and including the deliciously ambiguous finale.
If you're brand new to Sandler's particular style of slob-com, and you're finding yourself enamored with the guy's work, this 3-in-1 DVD deal isn't half bad.
It's certainly not the slickest or most exciting cop show you'll ever see, but it comes with a cool enough gimmick to keep you entertained.
The "white man as noble savage and isn't it ironic?" material runs out of steam well before the inexhaustible Nick Nolte does.
While I don't think the flick really has much of a brain in its head ... it sure isn't boring.
Cars is the first Pixar flick I'd describe as "cynical," and that, frankly, breaks my heart just a little bit.
The kind of spoof that doesn't so much "poke fun" at its targets as it does "lazily reference" them.
The revelations are rare, the insights are jumbled and dry, and the UFO footage, while interesting at first, is mercilessly re-used in an effort to pad out the Unplugged running time.
In the hands of lesser actors and producers, Entourage could have been a stunningly obnoxious experience. Happily for all involved, it is not.
...about as scary as a soap commercial.
If all you're after is 90 minutes of bare boobage, you can certainly find better ways to acquire them.
Just goes to show you that you can be rich, smart, beautiful, and accomplished ... and still be as miserable as us middle-class drones.
A sly, personal, and low-key indie comedy that manages to become more accessible and likable the longer it goes on.
I doubt even the hardcore Ludlum enthusiasts will find much to love here; I'm told this mini-series deviates pretty wildly from the source material -- and not in a particularly good way.
movie_title: Robert Ludlum's Covert One: The Hades Factor (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Brainless, silly, and sometimes pretty ridiculous, Fear Factor might be a lot of unflattering things -- but it sure isn't boring.
It's mostly just a bunch of talk and then a freaky finalé, but that doesn't make it a bad movie.
The main problem with Delivery is that it's not even remotely scary.
Delivers more satisfying jolts than most of the big-budget horror movies I've seen this year.
I suppose there's a great comedy to be made on the subject of door-to-door meat salesmen... Actually, there probably isn't.
A short, sweet, and rather illuminating look at a comedy tour that went into harm's way, just to bring some smiles to a few soldiers' faces.
movie_title: Patriot Act: A Jeffrey Ross Home Movie (2005)

movie_review_blurb: One is tempted to wonder aloud if drugs and booze didn't actually direct this relatively woeful flick.
I'll Always Know What You Did Last Summer is entirely worthy of the dismissive derision that you felt when you first read the title.
movie_title: I'll Always Know What You Did Last Summer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: By the time it's all over, POTC2 has delivered more toe-tappin' eye-candy than the last three summer movies combined. (So get Kraken!)
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The production design is rather impressive, the thing (despite being too long) moves fairly quickly, and on the whole Blackbeard feels like a perfectly entertaining Saturday afternoon matinee.
So yeah, it's a mindless, silly mess. But hell, it's also called Road House 2, so you probably knew that going in.
The innumerable "saw it coming" plot contrivances begin to stack up like so much cinematic cord wood.
A case of "good, sometimes very good, but definitely not great," which is kind of a small-yet-nagging disappointment, considering the talent and passion that went into the thing.

Frankly, if you can sit through the whole of Crash Landing without chuckling at the flick's bald-faced ineptitude, then you're a kinder movie-watcher than I am. (Either that or the movie put you to sleep.)
Take it from a former skeptic turned ardent fan: This is a damn good season of TV right here.
It's a fluffy little concoction that'll capably fill 90 minutes, but it's not destined to become anybody's newest favorite.
Aside from the frequent visits from components that are either painfully stupid or unwittingly hilarious, Guardian of the Realm is kind of a chore to sit through.
Slapped together very quickly and with very little in the quality control department -- because war is a profitable business, even where movies are concerned.
movie_title: The Hunt for Eagle One: Crash Point (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Speeds through its scant 80-minute running time with no muss, no fuss, and a surprisingly watchable demeanor.
It's a movie that shoots lazily for Capraesque and settles happily for Crapesque.
It's the end of the world as we know it, and I feel bored.
If you remember David Steinberg with any degree of fondness, yet you're hesitant to plunk down cash for the full 21-episode set, this 6-episode sampler should tell you all you need to know.
Short and sweet and packed with a real affection for classic sci-fi movie-makers, The Sci-Fi Boys should be a treat to anyone who adores the genre.
Not entirely bereft of entertainment value, even if most of it comes in the "unintentional" variety.
It's not deep or particularly brilliant, but it moves like a bullet, and it's the very best of the series so far.
As a drive-in-level guilty pleasure of the most obvious and brainless variety, Grizzly is quite a bit of good, campy fun.
It's just painful from stem to stern, and even the glassiest-eyeballed stoners will be hard pressed to sit through the whole interminable thing.
A mellow-yet-effective character study that exhibits some real poignancy and delivers a stunningly good performance by Friends star David Schwimmer.
Spacek and Sutherland could do work like this in their sleep ... and now we have the proof.
Those who enjoy Seagal's stuff will probably dig this one a little more than, say, OUT OF REACH FOR A SUBMERGED SUNBEAST'S BLACK BELLY FOREIGN DAWN KILL.
A justifiably forgotten mid-'70s semi-horror flick that makes one wonder how a movie can actually get made while so much rampant drug usage is so plainly afoot.
The flick itself gets a B-, but the DVD is grade-A impressive all the way.
Guys who direct snuff flicks in the slums of Khazakstan probably look at Big Momma's House 2 and think "Hey, I'm not such a terrible filmmaker after all!"
A strong visual style and a violent streak only partially undone by the PG-13 rating.
Aside from a suitably intimidating performance from Richard Lynch (and a handful of semi-creative kill scenes), there's not a whole lot to recommend the thing.
For pure disaster-time spectacle, the short list begins (and basically ends) with Poseidon and Inferno. They're time-capsule genre classics that just never get old.
Clumsily directed, painfully paced, and all but entirely lacking in anything even remotely resembling atmosphere, dread, or simple ol' scariness.
Call it an arthouse guilty pleasure if you like, but Casanova is a visually stunning, slyly amusing, and sweetly enjoyable little period-piece of a comedy.
Even with Erma Bombeck-style domestic humor like Mr. Mom's got in spades, Keaton consistently rises above the mawkish material.
With the ever-charming Keaton in the lead, the flick turns out to be as harmlessly entertaining as it is outlandishly unrealistic.
Not much more than a "haunted town" thrill-ride, with only a few plot points tossed in to keep things moving, Silent Hill truly is a feast for the eyes -- provided your eyeballs aren't too squeamish.
C'mon, how seriously are we supposed to take a film in which the President of the United States is played by Sledge Hammer! ???
Wesley Snipes, the new King of Romania.

The original, the four sequels, the TV series, the cartoon series, the remake, and two full discs of simian supplements. Plus it comes with a giant freaky ape head that'll sicken your wife and terrify your kids!
If we're making picks for the most entertaining disaster flicks ever made -- my enthusiastic vote goes to The Poseidon Adventure. Easily.
Essentially a goofy little matinee flick for the FX geeks and the schlock-obsessed sequel-lovers, HM2 isn't nearly as bad as it could have been ... but it's pretty darn disposable all the same.
The flick never really comes close to being scary, but it has a kitschy old-school charm that helps one forgive the slow stretches.
movie_title: The Comeback (Encore) (The Day the Screaming Stopped) (1978)

movie_review_blurb: What it lacks in every imaginable component of professional filmmaking, it kinda makes up for in enthusiasm and gore. For about 40-some minutes, anyway.
C'mon: The Dirty Dozen meets The Breakfast Club? That's just awesome.

The flick's about killer nurses, and the DVD cover says "They're running out of patients." This obvious little pun is cleverer than anything hidden within Candy Stripers' 80-some minutes of running time.
The movie shoots for light-hearted adventure but sinks like a lead anchor.
If you really dig the mega-sleazy stuff, Bare Behind Bars should be right up your alley. Just don't let any women know you watch this stuff.
Fans of bad television might enjoy the half-dozen episodes, but this is pretty lame-duck material all around.
An aggressively obnoxious and laugh-free stupid-fest that Mr. Depp will probably cringe at the next time he's walking through his favorite DVD shop.
Takes itself way too seriously and relies way too heavily on its "multi-generational gothic soap opera" exposition volleys that crop up whenever someone's *** is not being kicked.
It's harmless eye candy with a fast pace and lots of color, which is fine, but based on what came before it, X3 really should have been a little more than just "harmless eye candy."
I doubt that Live in New York represent the very best of Billy Connolly's stand-up material, but the guy's still a whole lot funnier than most of the comics we're introduced to these days.
movie_title: Billy Connolly - Live in New York (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Anyone who finds something new in Something New is obviously looking a whole lot closer than the movie deserves.

Chock full of bad acting, ridiculously pulpy dialogue, and tons of sloppily satisfying gore, Vampire Wars is by all conceivable measures a pretty awful movie. But that doesn't mean I didn't have some fun with it!
movie_title: Vampire Wars: Battle for the Universe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: If you're a hardcore horror completist, I'd say it might be worth a Netflix rental, but that's about it.
Normally I have next to no patience for sitcom material, but there's just enough wit, character, and creativity to make Wings worthy of a visit. Well, the first three or four seasons, anyway.
The fact that See No Evil's serial stalker is only slightly more horrifying than, say, Sloth from The Goonies is not exactly a good thing.
A strangely moving experience.
You won't find a much bigger Keitel fan than me, but not even the actor's patented brand of wide-eyed lunacy can save this one.
Considerably more intelligent than most of Jerry Bruckheimer's productions -- and Hackman's just awesome.
It's got some great action moments, just enough energy to jolt you through the exposition deliveries, and a ridiculously colorful cast to keep your eyeballs busy.
It's not exactly a spoof of action flicks, but everyone involved clearly has tongue wedged firmly within cheek.
For all its narrative road-blocks, pot-holes, and speed-bumps, when Poseidon sticks to its checklist of tightly-conjoined action scenes, it's a pretty enjoyable affair.
A semi-interesting yet seriously familiar crime drama that'll capably fill 90 bored minutes without actively impressing you in any real way.

Most romantic comedies are content to wade completely into the Moronic Fantasy pool, but The Break-Up earns some extra credit for actually mining a topic that "normal Joe & Jane" might actually be able to recognize.
Simple, mindless, silly sci-fi hoo-hah, but, y'know, not entirely unwatchable.
Compared to the average direct-to-video Disney sequel, the first Choose Your Own Adventure DVD looks like even more of a winner.
movie_title: Choose Your Own Adventure: The Abominable Snowman (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A big fat value meal stuffed with profane ravings, in-joke movie geekery, and virtually non-stop raunch -- but somewhere in Act III, Clerks 2 also gets a little ... sweet. And it actually works.
Real porn is better is better than this stuff. And that includes the writing, the acting, and the cinematography, too.
Coming from a guy who just won an Oscar for screenwriting? One has the right to expect something a little less rote, redundant, and oppressively familiar as 10th & Wolf.
Feels like it was cobbled together from stray moments of the original Glass House and just a few random threads stolen from whatever was on The Lifetime Channel at any given moment.
The second Addams flick is actually funny, too. And obviously that goes a long way.
The plot is a threadbare thing indeed.
Disney may have gone off the rails for a few years after The Fox and the Hound, but this one still feels like a classic. Or at very least, a mini-classic.
It's not deep and it's not unique, but HellBent approaches an oft-abused sub-genre with just enough originality and creativity to warrant some praise.
45 seconds of half-decent gore mired in a movie so lifeless it's almost scary. Almost.
You have to sit through a whole lot of migraine material to get to the goods.
A flick that talks a whole lot and shows very little.
While I wouldn't call it a terrible entry in the series, The Beginning is just a bit too dry, obvious and familiar to generate much enthusiasm.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's fun to be had, but there's also a few chapters worth skipping through.
Frankly I think this is one of my very favorite DVD releases of the year.
A confident and compelling little ghost story.
An old-school slasher flick with a really quick sense of broad British wit, a whole lot of energy, and a seriously strong cast.
Macy, Arkin, Huffman, and Cromwell are clearly having a good time with this amiable little farce noir. Fortunately they're able to transfer much of that fun over to the viewer.
Will offer a mild diversion to the action aficionadoes, but even those who like the flick will probably erase it from their memory banks in less than a week.
movie_title: Behind Enemy Lines II: Axis of Evil (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Jason Mewes woos Paris Hilton. Everything else is just roadkill.
It's all done in fun, of course, but hey -- if you're going to tease a bunch of geeks, you may as well do it aggressively and with much enthusiasm.
Standard cable fodder all the way, with only a few solid action scenes and maybe one colorful performance in the whole thing.
Arguably the weakest of the trilogy, but still packing just enough brains and red meat to keep the Pinfans sated.
We're basically left with a wild-eyed group of actors who probably had a lot more fun shooting When Do We Eat? than they did watching it.
There's a reason that this series has exploded at the box office while other sequels wither on the vine -- and it's not just because of the perpetually rusty torture devices.
It's a mystery, a romance, a horror flick, and a straight-faced parody all rolled into one unique little movie.
Rent it if you're that curious; all others can safely avoid it and still lead a perfectly happy life.
Even when it (finally) gets down to some horror-style nitty-gritty, the flick's just too aimless and boring to warrant much charity from the viewer.
I'm not even sure if the movie has a basement in it, but it's a real stinker to be sure.
A starchy little combination between Carrie and any ol' "spiders run wild!" critter flick.
Before it's all over, I Drink Your Blood has turned into a decidedly stupider version of Romero's Night of the Living Dead, but the thing whizzes along like a really bad hit of acid.
Some of it is unintentionally amusing; some if it's pretty smart and shocking.
Capably held my interest for its scant running time, I'd be hard-pressed to tell what I think the thing is about.
I doubt even very slow kids would be able to sit through the whole thing.
A horror flick for young fans who aren't quite prepared for the really scary stuff.
A true-blue bruise of a horror flick, packed with unsettling images, shocking demises, and a wonderfully apt sense of macabre humor.
A thing of dark, twisted, ironic beauty.
Four public-domain pieces of justifiably forgotten genre crap.
Even if you happen to like the three movies that were cannibalized here, I doubt pretty highly that you'd enjoy these miniature versions.
Points to the Henson team for trying to broaden the scope of their creatures -- and there's little denying that this particular flick still seems to hold up pretty darn well.
A long and colorful quest filled with crazy critters and creative set design.
While N&D certainly does have its rough spots, I'm thinking it's just good enough to warrant the three-disc Netflix rental, provided you're a big fan of Stephen King.
It's not exactly a "happy" movie, but it sure is a fascinating one.
Oh yeah, the sexy psychologist is played by Famke Janssen, so there's a little kitsch value that Relentless 4 has over Relentless 3.
Sunk by spotty pacing and an overall lack of forward momentum.
For all its woefully generic trappings, outlandishly ineffectual music, and cardboard-flavored dialogue, Quiet Cool does offer an appreciable amount of mayhem for your rental dollar.
It's only six episodes, but it's got as many laughs as Naked Gun 2 and 3. More, probably.
Pretty impressive work from a first-time filmmaker who aimed for equal portions of broad humor and gore galore -- and nailed both genres right on the mutton.
One of the funniest movies ever made. Yes, ever.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The special effects used to bring the creature to cinematic life are really quite excellent, and the frequent beastie bites should tickle even the most jaded horror freak.
Those expecting a shock-a-minute gore-fest will most likely walk away scratching their head, but as a semi-homage to Dario Argento's Suspiria, The Woods is a creepy little winner.
Barely even a "home movie" sort of movie.
Someone over at Universal figured that "cheerleaders = money," and that's basically how sequels get made these days.
movie_title: Bring It On: All or Nothing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Animation buffs will no doubt enjoy the Maniacs' first season, but it's the movie geeks who'll probably get the biggest kick out of the cartoon.
It's a spoof, a satire, and an homage all rolled into one, and its affection for the old-style drive-in flicks is tempered with just enough of the new-style "gore & hooters" approach.
A whole lot better than most direct-to-video crime thrillers; it's just that this particular story's been done to death by this point.
If watching a guy go slowly insane for 88 minutes sounds interesting to you, Fabled might be right up your alley.
Imagine a feature-length episode of Scrubs, only take out the laughs and slap in a bunch of gross-out garbage, and that's White Coats.
An unapologetically geeky love-fest for one of the newest and most ardent fanbases on the planet: The Browncoats.
movie_title: Done the Impossible: The Fans' Tale of 'Firefly' and 'Serenity' (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A smoothly, bizarrely entertaining comedy that mixes your traditional underdog farce with Ferrell's unique sense of ... strangeness.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The set, crew and cast members of 'Room and Bored' feel like a spoof of a hundred mindless sitcoms, and the backstage double-dealings provide some of The Comeback's best moments.
My opinion of this unique and exciting concert flick may be influenced by the fact that I simply L-O-V-E the band, but really; who else was this movie made for except the old-school Beastie faithful?
Bachelor Party has energy to spare, plus there are some really funny supporting performances hidden within, should you care enough to dig that deeply.
Take Piven out of the equation and it'd be a whole lot uglier.
Still, the shower scene is pretty damn funny.
A well-meaning and good-hearted urban melodrama -- that doesn't really seem to have anything new to say.
Another 'urban racer' flick that employs only the oldest, hairiest, and most reliable cliches, plot points, and stereotypes.
The thing's a freakin' migraine waiting to happen, trust me. And that's not even taking the dialogue into account.
Why you'd choose to watch the 4,224th lame-*** version of Alien over the real deal is simply beyond me.
A clever concept brought to colorful life thanks to a witty script, a quick pace, and a pretty darn excellent ensemble of comedic performers.
The flick feels like the pilot episode for a sitcom that never even came close to getting picked up for a full season.
I can see how the hardcore Halloween-heads can find some small nuggets of fun in this particular sequel, but in my eyes the series ended with the explosion in Halloween 2.
movie_title: Halloween 5: The Revenge of Michael Myers (1989)

movie_review_blurb: If you're game for a strange and beautiful-looking new version of the (very) old legend, you can safely give this one a rental.
4 or 5 mild chuckles hidden within 85 minutes of crotch & dildo schtick.
The CG recreations add a slick little touch, and each episode crams a lot of historical data into a pretty tight package.
This is an ugly, desperate, witless little movie that, even if you happen to like it, will evaporate from your memory in the time it takes to flip the channel.
A half-compelling, half-goofy and half-redundant piece of remake revisionism. (Yes, that's three halves, but it's that weird a movie.)
For moviegoers who found Running Scared a little too sedate.
It's by no means a flawless film, but it's a meaty one, and if you're a big fan of Andy Garcia, I'd definitely recommend it. (Plus, Bill Murray's in there.)
Although best-known for its infamous "Is it safe?" sequence, Marathon Man is a whole lot better than just one horrific scene.
I don't care if the thing was originally made for cable, theatrical, network, or Quicktime. This is one of the very best films I've seen all year.
Even if you think Moore's an obnoxious, manipulative, self-adoring schlub, you'll probably find a few things in The Awful Truth you can get behind.
Genre fans will appreciate the naked hooters and the frequent gore-geysers, but you'll have to lean pretty heavily on the FF button if you want to get through the whole thing.
A stupid, loud, and convoluted mess of a genre salad -- but that's not to say there's not some fun to be had.
movie_title: Sars Wars: Bangkok Zombie Crisis (Khun krabii hiiroh) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: I've always had a soft spot for B-level disaster movies, but Absolute Zero is so silly, so wooden, and so stunningly inert -- I'm kinda surprised it didn't launch a new TV series.
Palau might not have been one of the very best of Survivor seasons, but it still rates a solid B in my book.
Helen Keller could have made a better movie using only a Polaroid camera and some paper dolls.
Sure, the main characters are pretty selfish and obnoxious folks, but that doesn't mean their story's not worth telling.
A fairly intelligent, creepy, and well-crafted piece of indie moviemaking.
Fun concept, clever execution, unique animation, and tons of gooey gore.
While Snakes on a Plane isn't nearly as tight and twisted as it could have been, it'll no doubt tickle its intended audience endlessly.
It's a mildly diverting concept that's been brought to the screen with a notable lack of style and effort.
The chick's in a white bikini, you see, and her breasts are really large. Yeah, now you're getting it.
While it's definitely not an awful little adventure flick, Jewel of the Nile stands as a pretty good indication as to why the guys never reunited for a third adventure.
A surprisingly witty script, some really excellent chemistry between Douglas & Turner, and a large (and very welcome) portion of comic relief by Danny DeVito. Fun stuff.
Still one of the most exciting and insightful pieces of television out there ... especially now that Six Feet Under has gone out of business.
The Plague certainly isn't an awful little chiller flick, but given its crafty opening premise (and the attached name of Clive Barker), I was hoping for a little more from the follow-through.
Minus the opening & closing credits, 7 Mummies runs about 70 minutes, 64 of which are almost unbearably terrible.
It's good mindless fun, and a flick that no doubt holds a lot of Nostalgia Value for several members of my generation's sci-fi geeks.
Aside from being overlong by about an hour and dabbling far too often in a "preachifying" style of storytelling, Human Trafficking isn't half bad.
The fact that this thing never played on U.S. television might make it a bona-fide pop culture curiosity, but it'll take only about 1.3 episodes before you'll catch a good dose of buyer's remorse.
Pacino's performance is only a few degrees shy of full-bore scenery-chewing, but the veteran actor stomps through this movie like a small Italian Godzilla.
If you haven't seen this one in a while, definitely consider picking it up again. I think it's a better film today than it was 18 years ago.
For all its formula, it sure does feel like Dead Poets Society comes from a sincere place.
Aside from leading lady Lindy Booth and a directorial style that screams for a smarter screenplay, there's very little here that'll thrill the horror hounds and/or the gore gourmets.
A volleyball "comedy" that has just as many laughs as a gall bladder operation.

I won't even bore you with the horrendous way this project was shot, cut, or scrawled with crayon onto a roll of toilet paper. This thing makes the Police Academy movies look like the collected works of Billy Wilder.
Should it pop up on cable one insomniatic evening and you can watch it without dropping any money, sure, give Beeper a spin and see if it works for you.
Since not much of the movie is very insightful or substantial, the "dramatic kick" is missing from a finalé that feels like it should mean something.
"I was a good filmmaker ... before I sold out," says Penelope Spheeris on her audio commentary, and it's tough not to appreciate the gal's candor.
I do believe this movie was loosely based on William Shakespeare's The Tempest, but I could be mistaken.
No amount of breathless and broad energy could breathe life into a concept this shopworn.
Guys, trust me, the scant piece of Bullock booty that you get to see really isn't worth all the effort.
Venom is too darn familiar to become anyone's dark-horse favorite, but I'd say it's worthy of a rental if you love the horror stuff.
The sort of movie that's probably pretty entertaining to the people who made it, but are you one of those people? Me neither.
The thing looks like it was shot in six days for seven dollars.
Heck, I could sit through a movie a whole lot worse than this one just to see a pair of my favorite actors banter back and forth.
Flip to any random sequence in BloodRayne and you'll see a film professor's most vibrant nightmare.
A brave, entertaining, and well-intentioned piece of network television.
Basically, this one's for the Bisset addicts only.
A simplistic affair with no delusions of anything beyond B-movie fun.
Bucks the b-movie conventions by forsaking simple car chases and explosions for a surprisingly insightful little tale of rape and escape.
Nowadays you can see bare knockers by pushing three random buttons on your keyboard, and you don't have to sit through 78 minutes of pitiful comedy to get to 'em.
Just another forgotten pothole in the expansive highway of truly bad 80's comedies.
Nope, it's not as good as the first one. But considering how chintzy and auto-piloty most sequels are these days, I'll take what I can get.
Save your hate-mails, motorheads. I'm not knocking your favorite sport, just the amazingly brain-dead movie that it inspired.
It's not the diversion from source material that bothers me; it's the way in which the diversions are bland, listless, annoyingly familiar, and patently unengaging.
This low-end and agressively unpleasant entry into the teen movie canon will vanish from your frontal lobes in about the same time it took to watch the thing.
If every 'fan-made' movie were this curiously cool and bizarrely entertaining, well, it'd put a lot of Hollywood suits out of a job.

If you're an old-school Police fan, there's enough here to warrant some attention, but it's those same hardcore fans who might walk away from "Everyone Stares" wishing it had a lot more meat on its bones.
movie_title: Everyone Stares: The Police Inside Out (2005)

movie_review_blurb: I'd gladly say that Factotum is worth seeing for Dillon's performance alone -- but the flick's got a whole lot more to offer than that.

A slick take on the Frankenstein concept, a pair of excellent lead performances, and a crisp, austere directorial style are the highlights, but the thing moves at such a glacial pace that it nearly stops time.
Feels a whole lot like a rock-solid short film that was streeeeetched into feature length without adding the components than a 90-minute movie requires.
The Wizard of Oz meets What Dreams May Come by way of, oh I dunno, something post-apocalyptic, snarky, and fun.
Writer/director Laurie Collyer is smart enough to know that Sherry is the main attraction here, and also that she was really fortunate to get an actress like Maggie G. to play the role.
Those who call themselves fans of the Rapaport are in for a huge treat, because the veteran character actor delivers one of the strongest performances of his career.
Well-polished and craftily constructed, this is a documentary that's at its best when sitting down with the various crossword crackers from around the country
The b-movie equivalent of an overstuffed Halloween goody bag that's been spilled all over the carpet.
The film brings to light numerous complaints that informed film fans have had for years, and it does so in a smoothly informative and colorfully entertaining style.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's more than enough weird and wise material to keep you entertained -- especially if you're an animation buff or a Samuel Clemens aficionado.
On paper, Junebug might sound like something you've already seen a dozen times. But movies aren't made on paper, silly.
If you dig weird, silly comedies that are weird and silly on purpose, you could find a worse way to spend 75 minutes.
I'd rather sit down with a knowingly tacky little horror indie like All Souls Day than a shameless husk of a studio remake like The Fog.
This clip collection is a easily more amusing than Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, and Dickie Roberts: Former Child Star combined -- but not by a whole lot.
movie_title: Saturday Night Live - Best of David Spade (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It just might supplant David Lean's 1948 version as the one that students turn to for a 2-hour study guide.
I might not have known what the hell was going on in Sugar, but I sure as hell was interested to find out. Still am, actually.
Low-key and quiet, Cisco Pike is more or less a "forgotten" piece of 70's cinema, which is precisely why I jumped into the thing with both feet.
It's obvious and corny and 1,000% familiar, but it moves quick enough and it's not too painful.
Bloodline certainly works in an "indie calling card" fashion, and it should prove just entertaining enough to grab the attention of the hardcore horror fans.
Omnipresent camera-spinnings can't deliver enough slickness to hide Slipstream's half-baked concept and frequently horrific dialogue.
Regardless of the fact that these clips have been recycled from internet airplay, there's more than enough behind-the-scenes spectacle to please the fans.
movie_title: King Kong: Peter Jackson's Production Diaries (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's as if someone just swept up the floor at the Sci-Fi Factory, and instead of tossing the junk into the garbage, they glued it together and called it a movie.
Just another mid-70's social comedy that comes enticingly close to actually baring its teeth, but ultimately favors sitcom silliness over smart satire.
If Mel Brooks is remembered for only three films, then he can rest easy knowing that they're three of the funniest ones ever made. And The Producers was the first.
You'll most likely enjoy F.I.S.T. as much as I did: enough to casually recommend the thing, but not all that loudly or excitedly.
I watched 21 Hours to Munich with a careful eye trained for any sort of preachiness or "opinionizing" from either direction, and I was pleased to notice that stuff only by its absence.
Had I ever been a real fan of He-Man, this is the moment that would have cured me.
movie_title: He-Man and She-Ra: A Christmas Special (1985)

movie_review_blurb: The Evangalistas end up becoming a pretty fun family to visit -- but you sure wouldn't want to live with 'em.
Season 2 does suffer from a pointless change of venue and the absence of several funny faces, but the three leads still keep things suitably fun.
Worthy of a 99-cent rental, if only so you can witness the howlingly awful performance by Wesley Jonathan as a self-appointed roller-disco mega-lord called "Sweetness." Kid had me in tears, I swear.
One of the finest adventure movies ever made and the true prototype for all monster movies to follow, KING KONG is, even after 83 years, still the one true ruler of high-end escapist cinema.
While certainly not an outright awful program, Harts of the West should appeal to only the most devoted western fans, those who adore actors named Bridges, and really bored housewives.
Face had me a little skeptical at the beginning, but the flick coasts along at an appreciable clip, and it's fronted by a half-dozen really enjoyable performances.
