Lance Henriksen, Jeffrey Combs, Leo Rossi, Charles Napier, David Warner & Joe Don Baker. Felony is like the Ocean's Eleven of the direct-to-video shelf.
Every time our heroine blows a chance to shoot her enemy in the head because she's too busy monologuing, drink a shot of bourbon. You'll never get drunker.
movie_title: Excessive Force II: Force on Force (1995)

movie_review_blurb: It could be pretty creepy ... if it weren't so darn stupid.
movie_title: Devil Dog: The Hound of Hell (1978)

movie_review_blurb: That assertion that it's made for kids and therefore due for a "break" makes no freaking sense to me. Children deserve better than this garbage.
I walked into the thing expecting a lifeless mass of mirthless torture, and I walked away pleasantly surprised by the ensemble cast's consistent chuckle delivery.
A truly strange comedy that actually has a message hidden beneath its colorfully tacky exterior. Admirably twisted, too.
Crime Story sounds like any other cop show, but there's an old-school vibe that Mann brings to the show.
Aside from the already-famous naked bits, there's just nothing here you haven't seen before. And smarter.
Frankly I wouldn't be surprised if Rebound was written, shot, edited, and released over the course of ... let's be generous and say three weeks.

This massive flick is warm and nostalgic, dark and dangerous, sly and sweet, delicate, ferocious, and enthralling in a way that only great movies can be. Plus it's got, like, a million monsters in it.
Like I said before: The Amazing Race is not only (and easily) one of the best reality shows; it's one of the best things on television, period.
Because nothing makes a bad movie better than the presence of a former porn star who's now being asked to do comedy.
Somehow these things make just enough money to warrant subsequent installments, which I find sadly hilarious.
Although just a bit on the dry side, Queen: Under Review should prove to be a pretty damn fascinating piece for the hardcore Queenfans out there.
There's still a rustic style, off-kilter humor, and fluid pacing to Big Bad Mama that keeps the flick entirely watchable more than 20 years after it sauntered into the drive-ins.
Here Come the Tigers was one of the first Bad News Bears rip-offs, but it still stands as one of the absolute worst.
I really enjoyed Chicago during its theatrical run, and now that I've seen it twice more on DVD, the thing's fast becoming a personal favorite.
Formula filmmaking through and through, but it's brought home with just enough grit, gusto, and emotion to keep you suitably entertained.
Equal parts quiet, creepy, tragic, and visually gorgeous, Dark Water might be one of the best movies of 2005 that nobody went to see.
The Great Raid has one amazing action sequence. You just have to watch the whole story in order to earn and appreciate it.
Obviously inspired by the 1932 Laurel & Hardy short The Music Box, A Fine Mess represents director Blake Edwards at his most witless and desperate.
Recommended mainly to the more devoted Singleton fans, Baby Boy is pretty strong evidence of a filmmaker who still has plenty to say.
The two leads are raw but completely intriguing, and Poetic Justice offers a slice of the urban story that we generally don't get to see.
There's a good reason this flick made such a big splash and inspired so many copycats.
Reminsicient of nothing more than several wealthy persons' salaried vacation trip, Into the Blue is an absolutely merciless chore of a movie.
This thing makes Glitter look like gold.
I don't remember much of my New Testament, but someone might have to remind me what chapter it is where the president breaks into a top-secret bio-lab and uncovers Satan's Death-Bible gambit.
I mean no disrespect to the religious folks, but heck, movies like these just make Christianity seem more weird.
These folks get eternity in heaven, while I'm stuck here watching the Left Behind trilogy. I'm calling my rabbi.
It's not as gritty as John Wayne or as romantic as Louis L'Amour, but the flick's a solid enough black & white throwback to keep the Western fans suitably entertained.
Fans of Peter Gabriel should certainly enjoy what's offered here, and I know this because I myself am a fan and I quite enjoyed all of it.
movie_title: Peter Gabriel - Still Growing Up Live & Unwrapped (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Boasts Jordan's slick and efficient filmmaking, two excellent performances by Ledger and Brown, and that always-welcome air of offbeat Aussie attitude.
As a simple yet satisfying pulp-crime story from across the pond, The Escapist is quite a lot more entertaining than you'd logically expect.
As relatively stylish on the surface as it is resoundingly familiar beneath, Tamara should prove more than serviceable enough for the hardcore horror fans.
Stolen plots, stupid stories, and silly monsters I can take, but there's no damn reason a 75-minute movie should feel like 275.
More than enough insight, experience, and debate-worthy topics on display to make it worth your time -- provided you actually care about what goes on in Tinseltown's ivory towers.
Produced in the early 1980s by a Japanese production company, yet written, directed by, and starring tons of Americans, THWED is, well, it's really quite stupid is what it is.
The thing starts out with the flimsiest of premises, and then runs around in circles for an hour before crashing back to earth with one of the goofiest finales I've ever seen.
The first hour has a grim and gritty anti-charm that's quite devilishly entertaining. And then the wheels kinda come off.
It'd feel a whole lot creepier if it weren't exactly like that haunted videotape flick.
Dragonhead is dark, spooky, exciting, and (given the wild premise) rather fascinating, indeed.
Feels like an experiment that you'd be happy to catch during a film festival ... right before you nodded off for a solid 90-minute catnap.
It's as if we're randomly eavesdropping on the private concerns of one particular neighborhood ... a neighborhood that sure has its fair share of heartache.
Chock full of awful dialogue, amateur hour acting performances, and a devotion to formula so unwavering that it boggles the mind, The Choke is as unpleasant as its title suggests.
The epitome of all things cinematically generic.
A pair of excellent performances, a few fantastic little thrills, and a mind-twister of a finale that's as semi-confusing as it is strangely satisfying.
The "smallness" of Manhattan, Kansas is what makes the film so engaging.
She Spies is mindless eye candy by every conceivable measure, but hell, it's fun stuff.
The cast keeps it watchable, but it's not a flick you'll remember for more than 45 minutes.
Pretty to look at, tough to follow, and, ultimately, difficult to swallow, Stay certainly isn't a bad film ... but it sure as heck isn't one you'll be raving about anytime soon.
Drably directed, sloppily written, and an absolute chore to sit through, Ring Around the Rosie is something you'd find on HBO19. And skip it.
Dazzling art design, colorful character models, and flashy animation techniques are only extra-impressive when they're backed by some real heart, wit, soul, or character.
I wouldn't exactly call Air Guitar Nation the next important documentary, but as a colorful look at an admittedly goofy activity, the flick's a pleasant little winner.
A movie that just might inspire you to snip some of those credit cards in half -- is a good movie.
Finally and at long last comes a documentary that asks the question "Why does modern music SUCK SO MUCH?"
An absolute must for Ray Romano fans, which is what I am now.
LOL makes a pretty solid case that, despite our being able to reach anybody at any time, most of us still lack the ability to really 'reach' anyone at all.
The acting is often ripe, and the production value indicates that this must be a resoundingly low budget affair, but odds are that one or two of the mini-movies will tickle your fancy.
The flick feels like Six Feet Under meets Waking Ned Devine written on a 5th-grade reading level.

If you're the type who appreciates the half-scary, half-silly comic book-y approach of titles like Gremlins, Tremors, and Eight Legged Freaks, I'd bet you $9.50 and a small popcorn that you'll enjoy Slither.
Honestly: In how many movies can you see a polar bear attacking a bunch of whales?
Frankly I think Jane Curtin's one of the funniest women on the planet, and she does some great work in this particular sitcom.
My idea of hell is the Facts of Life theme song played on an endless loop for all eternity.
An entirely familiar yet slyly entertaining little throwback to the days of Grizzly, Pumpkinhead, and Prophecy -- with a big dose of Rear Window tossed in, just to amp the tension up a little.
This collection is actually a lot more Pluto than it is Mickey & Pluto, but hey: 8 more classic Disney shorts, presented in fine fashion, for about ten bucks.

Seems kinda odd that Pluto and Figaro the kitten would get more screen-time than Mickey Mouse in a collection called "Mickey & Minnie," but there's still a lot of old-fashioned fun to be found in this 8-piece cartoon set.
One of the best "Classic Collection" volumes yet, #11 delivers four shorts that are making their DVD debut ... and another four that are pretty cool, too.
It all plays out like a wanna-be episode of 24 or a screenplay that was deemed "just a little too good" for Seagal or Van Damme to anchor the thing.
Even at 75-ish minutes, the thing practically limps to the finish line, desperately tossing random gags up on the screen.
Cheap-looking, atrociously written, and delivered with all the energy of a breach-birth bovine, Dr. Dolittle 3 is all kinds of terrible.
Funny stuff. Not for kids.
If you're new to this series, start with Season 1 -- and then stop.
As Feed muddles through its outlandishly stupid premise, the thing just gets uglier instead of more intense, and sillier instead of more exciting.
Provided you don't watch this type of movie for the acting performances, Dark Kingdom isn't a half-bad little time-waster.
The Triangle feels a whole lot like Jurassic Park meets The X-Files by way of The Philadelphia Experiment ... but it's a pretty nifty concoction all the same.
Fun, kitschy stuff I call it.
...best of all, the series showed no discernible dip in quality between its first and second seasons.
The Scorned is precisely what a movie that was slapped together by a bunch of Reality Show Stars should be: laughable.
The perfect marriage of big-budget sci-fi spectacle and character-based comedy schtick.
Feels like a blueprint concocted by the bean-counters at Columbia Pictures.
Whether the flick is focusing on its numerous action scenes or its breathless bouts of plot exposition, District 13 speeds by like an absolute blur.
Packing quite a bit of wit, wisdom, craziness, and creativity into its slick-looking and efficient frame, Bickford Schmeckler's Cool Ideas is a bizarrely charming little diversion.
One of the most challenging and darkly, smartly entertaining movies of the year.
Darkon works as a fascinating and colorful documentary about an endearingly bizarre game and as a "can't wait to see who wins" sports film. (And as a nifty little comedy, too, actually.)
If you've grown up on the unending exploits of the 80s cinematic stalkers, you'll find a lot to enjoy here.
movie_title: Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon (2006)

movie_review_blurb: I can plainly understand why several involved parties lobbied to get their names removed from this film.
For all its broad (and periodically inane) silliness, Black Scorpion is a b-flick that delivers what it promises, with a whole lotta Severance on the side.
This patently painful flick marks the first and last time that director James Foley would tackle comedy. And the reasons why are right up there on the screen.
Eleniak enthusiasts will have to own it, I'm sure, but I can't imagine anyone else who'd sit through the whole thing.
Comedy being subjective and all that, I can't predict how hilarious you'll find this program. Me, I got 4 or 5 solid chuckles out of it, but not much more than that.
movie_title: Comedy Central Roast of Pamela Anderson (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The Final Destination series caters to its target audience without insulting it -- which is why the flicks make so much damn money.
Perhaps not the most exciting or fascinating story in the book, but a well-crafted and fairly intriguing one all the same.
Those who hold Charles in Charge in higher esteem than I do should be quite pleased with this three-disc season 1 collection.
It's not just that Death Tunnel is cheap, derivative, and clearly made by folks with more enthusiasm than talent; it's that Death Tunnel is the horror flick equivalent of elevator Muzak.
I would have been thrilled to revisit this one and walk away calling it "sadly misunderstood" or "seriously underrated," but the thing's an absolute mess from stem to stern.
Feels like it was inspired by a People Magazine article, and stretched out into feature length through the dubious overuse of sketch-type comedy droppings.
Put Alan Thicke in the lead role of Firewall and, without changing one line of dialogue, the flick would debut at 9pm Eastern on ABC's Movie of the Week.
Only the most passionate genre fans will be able to sit through House of 9 and be able to semi-recommend the thing to anybody else.
An autobiographical tale of attempted suicide, horrific schizophrenia, and frequent trips to a rather unpleasant mental hospital.
movie_title: I Never Promised You A Rose Garden (1977)

movie_review_blurb: Bad horror movies are one thing, but bad horror movies that exploit real-life murders to make a few bucks... Ugh, that's just creepy.
Acidic, acerbic, trenchant, and amazingly ballsy for a prime-time network series, Action was doomed from its premiere episode. (Let's hear it for DVD!)
Cinematic Sominex that feels like it was tailor-made for immediate simultaneous broadcast on the Lifetime Channel and the Oxygen Network.
The passage of three decades is not always kind to once-timely comedy schtick.
The charitable might be tempted to describe The Five Heartbeats as wholesome and well-intentioned -- but so is a 6-year-old who just crayon-scrawled "I love cookies" on the living room wall.
Feels like the filmmakers simply ran out of incest jokes and decided, on a whim, to shoot for some melodrama.
This thing is a movie like static is a song.
Tami Anderson, a refugee from MTV's The Real World, gets a speaking role here. I mention it only because some people like The Real World and not because it's a particularly strong performance.
A warm and funny little ensemble piece that still holds up pretty darn well after almost 20 years.
Right up there with the 1980s cult classics like Heathers, Buckaroo Banzai, and Brazil.
90% cynicism / 10% hope, and it's jammed full of funny performances, dark divergences, and a low-key air of existential angst that you simply don't see in many multiplex movies. I love this one.
A darkly insightful and entirely fascinating study of the most disturbing material out there ... and why we like to watch it.
Quiet, well-shot, and enjoyably melancholy, The Last Western is a simple little story about a brief chapter in the history of the American Western.
Might not be any sort of improvement over Craven's original flick, but it does a fine job of delivering the goods ... and with just a little more beneath the surface than you might expect.
If you took all the exciting / violent / scary moments offered in Kill Devil and compressed them into a short film, the thing would run about seven full minutes.
While perhaps not the "all-time classic" that some of its contemporaries are, Captains Courageous still stands up pretty well today.
Well-shot and crisply edited, Cámara oscura overcomes a pedestrian screenplay and manages to work just well enough for a 90-minute investment.
Astonishingly inept, ridiculously unwatchable...
Recommended to die-hard Graham groupies and gals who really love every simple rom-com that rolls down the pike.
Fun junk is what it is, provided you don't take Cerberus even remotely seriously.
The stalker here is a creatively painted (and decidedly homicidal) clown, one who's been jammed, it seems, into a rather juicy episode of Dynasty or Dallas.
Rent it for nostalgia value, if you must, but be prepared for a sex comedy with very little sexiness and a complete dearth of comedy.
My advice would be to find a copy of this fantastic documentary, settle down for an 80-minute piece of enlightenment, and then maybe use its lessons to help make the world a better place.
A little bit better than the usual Corman fare, but it's still a pretty predictable tale, all the same.
Rare is the social satire that rings as true as Network does, and the film is even more topical today than it was thirty years ago.
You could rent it for the religion, the kooky cast, or for the B-movie fun of it.
If you're a diehard snowboarding freak, then welcome to your new favorite movie.
The Tenants ranges from one-set character piece to race-centric speech-making to Cinemax style bedroom dealings... Well, at least it's not boring.
Eleven kinds of cinematic torture rolled up into one 90-minute migraine.
I see Running Scared as a slick, sick, and sly satire of all the action flick conventions, but maybe I'm just nuts.
A noxious and gratingly insincere feature-length sitcom that'll have you stampeding toward the closest bottle of aspirin. (Or arsenic.)
I was happy just to watch Malcolm McDowell go insane for two hours.
It doesn't have the magic of the original series, but it's not a terrible spinoff sequel.
Grinds its gears while slipping from one genre to the other, but I bet you'll be pretty intrigued to see how it all turns out.
It's a pretty solid (and reasonably priced) triple feature release, if mindless popcorn escapism is what you're after.
I mean, when's the last time you saw a horror victim get dispatched by way of piranha in the bathtub?
A few cheap jolts, a handful of clever ideas, and just enough energy and creativity to make it across the finish line.
One can't help but feel that the screenplay needed three or four more polishes before production got rolling.
Fun, forgettable stuff -- but also a (slightly) better film than the reviews would have you believe.
If your ONLY complaint about Alien vs. Predator is that it wasn't graphically violent enough, then you're going to love this movie.
It's as if Mr. Washington wanted to deliver a important story, but felt he had to stay firmly within the proven formula to get his message out.
A whole lot gorier than the first one. I love how the beloved PG-13 gets tossed in the dumpster once the letters "DTV" are brought up.
Derivative, obvious, and simplistic, but it's also shot with a lot of style, edited with a lot of kick, and (best of all) it knows just when to deliver its goods and roll the credits.
More than content to simply toss the same exact formula into the microwave and deliver its lukewarm cinematic leftovers to an always-hungry audience.
Unloads a volley of plot twists that'll have you slapping your head in disbelief, provided you haven't figured them out by the end of Act I.
If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, then Uwe Boll just spent 126 minutes telling Peter Jackson how thin, talented and gorgeous he is.
movie_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's a tongue-in-cheek absurdity to the flick that, after a rough start, actually started to win me over.
It's awash in grimly gorgeous sights, mercilessly dark humor, oddly amusing tunes, and all sorts of strange goings-on ... Burton and Depp strike gothic gold once again.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's presented with such color and confidence that it's tough not to get swept up in the spectacle of it all.
Funnier than most theatrical-release comedies -- and yep, that includes The Simpsons Movie.
Earns a few points for sheer silliness once Act III rolls around, but you'll have to muddle through a whole lot of familiar tedium to get there. Nice scenery, though.
So while I'd stand firm with the assertion that more than half the MOH episodes are worth checking out, Dream Cruise ranks right near the bottom.
We're treated to some of the most hilariously sloppy CGI work you've ever seen, followed by (get this) rubber spiders dangling from strings! And not just a few of 'em. They're everywhere!
Adds very little to the cannibal crazies / survival horror sub-genre -- despite its admirable-yet-ineffective attempts at creating a post-apocalyptic world.
Hitman feels like twenty short films played back to back, only a few of the mini-movies went missing, and the projectionist is hoping you won't notice.
A big, meaty monster movie that's as entertaining for its Lovecraftian beasties as it is for its more "intellectual" aspirations.
Before the diseased-yet-oddly superhuman villains start to appear en masse, I Am Legend works surprisingly well. Then they do.
A robust 80-minute burst of barely-controlled mayhem. Monster fans will love it.
A pretty agonizing affair.
The characters are barely introduced before we're plunked right into their angst-fest.
Follow the basic "killer croc" template if you must, fellas, but jeez, would it kill you to try something even remotely different?
There's always something to be said for bare boobs and pointless violence, but the flick wears out its welcome long before it reaches the finish line.
All three leads jump into the unseemly material with all the enthusiasm that the promise of "amazing indie cred" can offer.
Hardly the re-invention of the genre wheel, but that's fine by me. It's just a whole bunch of sick, sly, silly fun.
Clearly inspired by a few of Hitchcock's 'train-bound' movies, Transsiberian doesn't break a lot of new ground, but it does tell a slick story in a very chilly setting.
A simple tale of how love and affection can sometimes inspire some of the nastiest human emotions imaginable.
Not only a bleak and harrowing horror tale, but it's also Haneke's indictment / deconstruction of, well, bleak and harrowing horror tales.
All told, the entire collection runs about 82 minutes, and it closes with one dazzlingly (darkly) amazing piece of animation.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Keeps the tensions percolating, and you gorehounds will find a few nasty moments worth seeing.
It's not a stalker flick or a ghost story, although it's sort of a combination of both.
A sly poke at indie filmmaking, a non-stop roller-coaster of sexual and romantic politics, and (yes) a slightly scary thriller when all is said and done.
Clocking in around 69 minutes total, Meet the Spartans is not a movie. All involved should feel slightly ashamed.
Really, how many times will you get to see Bruce Willis, Sean Penn, and Robert De Niro work together? (And in a comedy, no less.)
Trim a good twenty minutes from this overlong exercise, and you'd help the comedic pacing a whole lot.
Much more interested in its interpersonal relationships than it is in climbing a soapbox and preaching to the choir.
Has some pretty insightful things to say about the nature of being "disabled," and it says them with a good deal of humor, style, and understanding.
The three leads seem to be having a lot of fun with this somewhat strange material.
I can automatically assume that the characters are a lot more multi-dimensional in Chabon's book -- because in the movie they're pretty much a bunch of paper-doll cutouts
A deliberately-paced crime drama that brings a strange sense of warmth, dark humor, and even some odd romance to a potentially dreary tale.
Might be the most affectionate look back at old-school entertainment since Peter O'Toole boozed his way through My Favorite Year.
Not your traditional boy-meets-girl story, but it does an excellent job of delivering two fairly unique characters trapped in a seriously strange relationship.
One can't help but think this C-minus movie would have made for a B-plus episode of Masters of Horror, with just a few trims here and there.
A light/dark, sick/sincere, weird/warm sex comedy that succeeds because of its constant contradictions, and not despite them.
Fans of the horror genre will appreciate the "leftover" stuff because it's presented in a relatively fresh package, but leftovers they remain...
About as basic and unmemorable as a horror flick gets.
With only two horror flicks under his belt, Adam Mason's already a director to keep an eye on.
As a slight and visually arresting little "what if?" tale, one that centers on a pop culture icon who still fascinates us today, Death Defying Acts is a perfectly passable period piece.
Even the lamest comedies out there manage to wring one or two chuckles from yours truly, but this ugly, obnoxious flick couldn't even manage half a smirk.
Powerfully gory, admirably unsettling, bleakly amusing, and at its best moments, the movie is deliciously suspenseful.
A patently over-the-top piece of gore-drenched survival horror. Very familiar but very fun.
The director approaches the fact-based story with equal amounts of disdain, fascination and bemusement.
All of its positive components are used in the service of a very basic genre premise that's been done and re-done to death by now.
Sometimes a big batch of small chuckles, a few strong performances and a quietly amusing concept are enough to keep a comedy afloat.
Beyond the contributions from Samuel L. Jackson and Ed Harris, however, there's very little worth talking.
An unexpectedly candid character study that features a supremely solid cast of characters.
Set to a pounding Paul Oakenfold score, Vexille offers a half-dozen action sequences that are really quite thrilling.
A bloody, brutal and oddly amusing little Mother of a flick.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: God bless the whip-smart, snarky and powerfully funny screenplay by blogger / author / former stripper Diablo Cody.
So yeah, it's a zombie flick crossed with the visual approach of The Blair Witch Project. But it's also quite a bit more than that.
A flick tailor-made for the midnight slate at your favorite film festival. Especially if it's a festival that allows you to drink beer during screenings.
If you usually dig John Leguizamo's work, then you'll definitely want to see this one.
Escrow isn't as polished or consistent as the best of its sub-genre -- but it's pretty dang funny for the most part.
The lesser moments still work because of Bacon's commitment to the part, and the better components are a firm indication that James Wan is improving with each successive film.
If you're a fan of sly, dry serial killer stories then you're pretty much guaranteed a great time with this 12-episode opening season.
While it's almost certainly guaranteed to be a box office bomb, I'm suspecting this goofy little adventure will earn a few bemused fans once it hits DVD.
Del Toro's fingerprints are all over The Orphanage, but it's first-time feature director Bayona strikes a fantastic balance between well-earned chills and strangely heart-touching emotion.
It's more than a "departure" for director Paul Thomas Anderson; it's a monumental display of "evolution" that'll wow the established fans and impress a helluva lot more new ones.
There's always something to be said for comic-book-style monster movies that deliver the gore and the giggles in equal measure.
movie_title: Flight of the Living Dead: Outbreak on a Plane (Plane Dead) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: When Matthew Broderick and Danny DeVito team up for a comedy that can't even deliver one well-oiled joke, that's a big problem.
The film succeeds on the back of one stellar performance, two surprisingly engaging plot threads, and a whole bunch of seriously unpleasant atmosphere.
There's something to be said for a chomp-em-up tale that exhibits some class, intensity, and restraint.
As a gritty throwback to a sub-genre that doesn't get much airtime these days, I'd call Welcome to the Jungle a surprisingly effective little experiment.
A mildly diverting experiment that will appeal to only the staunchest of zombie aficionados.
Stands as an unapologetically enthusiastic marriage between old-school heroism and modern-day wizardry. Plus it kicks ass!
It's a been-there, done-that sort of sequel, but it's still more creative than most of what passes for Hollywood horror these days.
Frankly I could watch Danes, Collette, Streep, Close, Richardson, etc., as they go food shopping, which just goes to show what a bunch of great actors can do for a fairly conventional tear-jerker.
A D-grade slasher flick that has delusions of comedy and mystery, of interest only to those who lust after Brad Pitt and would love to check out a performance the actor would probably rather forget.
At the very least, the flick shows a bit more creativity than your normal "forest slasher" misadventure.
An admirable little indie that earns points for keeping a poker-straight face throughout all the craziness.
Fast-paced, freakishly gory, and boasting a few unexpected surprises, Planet Terror is one of the best horror movies I've seen in years.
movie_title: Planet Terror (Grindhouse Presents: Robert Rodriguez's Planet Terror) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Offers a few unexpected shocks and an appreciably grim demeanor. And that's always cool.
There's just too much "down time" and not enough energy to keep the flick afloat.
movie_title: Return to House on Haunted Hill (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Little more than a very thin retread of several much better crime stories.
So darn good it makes me wish Spielberg hadn't given up on the horror genre.
Unapologetically sexy, oddly unpredictable and ultimately kinda (yes) sweet, Sex and Death 101 is just a solid little comedy.
So while you're being assaulted with ideas, characters and monsters that are clearly 'borrowed' from other sources, well, it's just quite the novelty to witness Pakistan's first gore movie.
From the scoring and lighting to the acting and editing, the thing wouldn't earn a passing grade from even the most lenient film professor at the chintziest community college.
It's smart, sexy, exciting, romantic, weird, funny, and intelligent all at the same time. It takes stock characters and old-fashioned heroics and updates them in the most fascinating of ways.
I'm not saying it's on the same level as Re-Animator, but From Beyond still ranks pretty damn high on Stuart Gordon's filmography.
It's dated and sort of dull but there's some amazing gore and the new blu-ray makes it shine.
Surely one doesn't toss something called Blood Monkey into their DVD player with the expectation of something brilliant in return, but there's stupid and there's stupid.
A long overdue and very entertaining documentary on one of Hollywood's most colorful salesmen.
movie_title: Spine Tingler: The William Castle Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The thing looks like it was shot over the course of six random (weed-filled) weekends, probably for fun at first, but then someone got the idea to release this glorified home movie into theaters. Bad idea.
It's got just enough charm, story, and action to fill a half-decent trailer -- and the trailer doesn't set you back nine bucks.
While Pulse 2 is a pretty arid, predictable, and consistently goofy horror sequel, I have to give the guys points for trying something different.
Suffice to say that Alien Raiders has a few modest surprises up its sleeve, and that's more than most low-budget genre concoctions even attempt.
It's the Coens meets Sam Fuller while watching Looney Tunes and making an '80s mix tape full of The Smiths and Depeche Mode. I (freak)ing loved it.
As a breezy behind-the-scenes peek at how micro-budget movies get made, Zombie Girl could be shown in high school film classes ... and probably should.
If you dug the first one, I'm pretty darn sure you'll enjoy the second visit to the Feast buffet. Bring a few extra napkins though.
Sleazy little relic of a movie. Rather fine DVD release that demystifies the whole thing.
Sometimes you can tell a lot by a title.
Sets you up for 'predictability' in both the western and horror departments, and then subverts those expectations time and again.
French horror cinema that doesn't shy away from the rough stuff and aims to bring a few extra layers to the typically anemic slash-and-smash concept.
Considering how worthless most horror remakes are, the fact that this "carbon copy quickie" actually works is fairly impressive.
Say what you will about Saw 3 and Hostel 2, but compared to this malignant wreck, those (yes, harsh and brutal) horror flicks have the subtext of Shakespeare and the moral compass of Superman.
Did we actually NEED a brain-dead action version of Children of Men? I say no.

It's not really a scary movie, no matter how you slice it, but this remake offers plenty of the stuff promised in the title, in addition to a divertingly circuitous "whodunnit" aspect that works a bit better than one would expect.
Just maybe worthy of a bored afternoon, provided you're either A) 14 years old, or B) a longtime fan of the "quest" movies and you want something to poke a little fun at. (Or maybe not.)

It's the kind of easy target that most film critics enjoy savaging, but I choose to look a little more closely at movies like this. Empty-headed and powerfully familiar, yes, boring and poorly-made ... no way.
For all its surprising little merits, Starship Troopers 3 still works as a piece of cheesy B-grade cinema fun.
The best flick of its kind since Lewis Teague's drive-in classic Alligator. And that was 1980.
I kept waiting for Silver Surfer, Neo, and Snoopy on his damn doghouse to come flying by and yell "Hey Rick! That's a lot of mummies! Mind if WE drop in?"
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Precisely the cheap-end, cash-grab non-movie I expected it to be. This is insultingly bad.
Even if you wouldn't know weed from green wool, Pineapple Express works as a fast-paced buddy comedy with lots of laughs and a few hilariously unpleasant surprises.
While the sequels may have gotten progressively more campy, I'm pleased to note that the original Child's Play holds up just as well as I'd hoped. (And the new DVD rocks.)
There are only so many alternate flashbacks and massive explanations that a horror freak can take ... but I think the series is still amusing enough to warrant 90 minutes a year.
I've always had a soft spot for bad disaster movies -- but even I have my limits.
A high-end feature-length version of The Outer Limits, combined with a fond enthusiasm for creative gore and populated by a trio of characters who are actually interesting.
One feels a sense of gratitude when a horror-thriller even bothers with unexpected divergences or surprises that feel relatively satisfying.
Ready-made for 3am HBO viewing, The Lodger is an unnecessary remake of a story that's already been covered more than enough times, thanks.
Virtually mindless, unabashedly vulgar, and knee-deep in the childish side of the horror pool, Feast 3 is still a good deal of fun.
Every 15 minutes a few blood-covered stuntmen leap out from the shadows and get involved in some uneventful carnage. You'll hardly notice.
A sci-fi action period piece with generous doses of horror, romance, picturesque scenery, second-hand costumes, and cliche as far as the eye can see. Interested yet?
At least we're spared a lot of the "legacy this" and "prophecy that" stuff that slows down both of the previous Underworld adventures.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Dark, intelligent and disturbing, supported by a force-of-nature lead performance and a clever screenplay.
One of those eminently quotable comedies that frat guys and movie geeks will come back to time and again.
Feels like 25 very brief stage plays jammed together -- maybe five of which are worth sitting through.
An ugly, blank slate of a film, one that feels like a rough outline for one of the better Ellis adaptations.
Covers the three essential bases of indie horror: It's scary, it's smart, and it pushes a few boundaries. An excellent debut for Paul Solet.
One of the most compelling sci-fi films of the past 20 years.
This stuff is scary in the same way that twelve random ingredients from your kitchen is soup.
Someone should have gotten Robert Rodriguez on the phone.
Feels like a perfectly enjoyable mid-'50s war movie that's been re-made with only the finest in modern cinematic technology.
This is far and away one of the best zombie movies I've ever seen. And I've seen 'em all.
As a passable time-waster for hardcore sci-fi fans, the remake is certainly watchable enough. But then again ... most hardcore sci-fi fans will probably have the same problems I had with the movie.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A rather solid action flick, but it's barely Bond.
For all its glitches and oddities, Repo! impressed me on sheer force of strangeness, originality, and audacity.
A sweet-yet-smutty concoction that would feel right at home in the Judd Apatow sub-section of the video store. I mean that as a compliment.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Terrible movie. And a definite must-see. Plus the DVD is surprisingly rich and moist.
What I expected to be a big fat mess of a movie turned out to be pretty dang fun -- quadruply so if you happen to be a Star Wars fanatic.
Manages to maintain that sly sense of dread that permeates the best of Barker's horror tales. Certainly one of the most effective horror films of the year.
Supremely satisfying for about a dozen different reasons. A great film.
A slightly messy movie, but it's also one of the year's best.
Amazingly bad. To call Prom Night a horror movie is to call chewing gum a cheeseburger.
It's both craftily creepy (in a subtle way) and powerfully visceral (in a kick-ass way), plus it delivers its payload in a slick and efficient 91-minute burst of nastiness.
It's cinematic junk food; I sat, I laughed, I left, I forgot all about it. (But at least I laughed.)
A damn good film, one that trades in harsh, dark material, but never loses sight of the true nature of humanity.
The main problem is that they spelled the title wrong. The first vowel should be an I.
A film that wants to speak out (loudly and clearly) about some of our nation's most obvious maladies, and it does so in an impressively honest, angry, and semi-hopeful fashion.
Easily one of the most 'personal' documentaries I've ever had the pleasure to see.
A thoroughly engrossing little film that's also quite slyly entertaining, despite its rather unsavory subject matter.
It's fast and funny, sick and sweet, geeky and gory. Basically, a whole lot of fun.
These guys make funky dance music out of old Nintendo games!
An unapologetic throwback to the days when comedies didn't have to be all that original -- just as long as they were funny.
A fantastic little comedy, filled with all sorts of weird moments, funny quips, colorful characters, and strange diversions.
One of those can't-miss romantic comedies in that there's some sweet, sensitive, insightful stuff for the ladies -- but there's also plenty of raunchy comedy for the boys. (And vice versa.)
A choir full of (very) old people get down with the rock music. Sweet, funny, touching stuff.
If Marshall's goal was to deliver a no-nonsense, tongue-in-cheek, mega-violent "throwback" action flick, I'd say he's done a damn fine job of it.
More than enough energy, mayhem and gore to keep the serious horror freaks entertained.
A shock-a-minute mini-masterpiece of sound design, tricky jolts, and wonderfully distressing tension.
An Asian combination platter of Dreamscape, A Nightmare on Elm Street, and just about every technology-obsessed J-horror flick you can think of.
A surprisingly engrossing two-person character study that (gradually) reveals something quite a bit darker beneath the surface.
Ferrell is still able to wring some real chuckles out of a very familiar blueprint. I guess the guy's just that funny.
It's fast-paced and funny, strangely warm and suddenly creepy, disarmingly charming and admirably icky, all at the same time.
Feels like stuff left over from a random episode of CSI: Dirty Cop Division.
Once it gets some speed behind it, the thing just barrels forward with reckless abandon, tossing out gags that work at an impressively effective rate.
Not exactly a great movie, but it's sick, slick, and strange enough to warrant a 90-minute look.
The film is focused simply on telling the tale, and if the movie is exaggerated or "fictionalized" in any way, you can consider me duly surprised.
Simply wants to dazzle you for 100 minutes, at least enough to get you excited for the DVD release and yep, the eventual sequel. Count me in for both please.
If you're a Futurama newbie, I'd start with S1 and S2. These flicks are for the wackos who know the difference between Morbo, Calculon, and Wernstrom.
movie_title: Futurama: The Beast With a Billion Backs (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Where the hell is Act III?
You could retitle this flick The Hulk is Bourne, and it would be a perfectly appropriate description -- albeit a really awful pun.
While The Strangers certainly doesn't forge any new ground, there's always something to be said for a horror flick that forges old ground colorfully.
To expect ANY movie to live up to the Raiders standard is simply unfair, but Crystal Skull fits very excellently next to both Temple of Doom and Last Crusade.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Broad comedy and splattery horror are a pretty tough combo to pull off, but if anyone can do it ... the British can.
It wouldn't surprise me to learn that the entire movie was paid for by the makers of Tylenol.
I just don't know what to make of a scene in which a judge sentences two selfish jerks to "six months hard ... marriage," but I'm simply too old and too smart for material this insipid.
A bleak adventure flick and a very sweaty psychological thriller.
A little scary, occasionally funny, and rather enthusiastically splattery before it's all done with.
movie_title: The Wild Man of the Navidad (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Eden is almost achingly personal, and it's a testament to the small-but-powerful Irish film industry that tiny little personal stories like this one get funding.
Please be sure to keep an eyeball out for this one, horror fans. Let the Right One In is very smart, very sweet, very sick, and very special indeed.
If you're looking for a horror flick that wants to give you a 'you are there -- and it's freaking miserable' vibe, this one should fit the bill quite nicely.
Has a basic-yet-admirable statement to make about the best and worst of human nature, and it makes the statement colorfully, sincerely, and succinctly.
And while some of the in-movie puzzles are relatively obvious, the flick as a whole proves to be sort of a puzzle in its own right.
Will undoubtedly prove very insightful to those who believe all Iraqis are 'the enemy.'
If you don't mind a lot of smutty gags mixed with a strange concoction of wit, warmth, and (yes) melodrama, I'm betting you'll become a fan of The Auteur.
57km is alternately smart, sad, sexy, and rather ironically amusing.
movie_title: 57,000 Kilometers Between Us (57000 km entre nous) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A very compelling movie that's almost ruined by a horrible narration track.
Easily the best movie of its kind since Steve James' Hoop Dreams.
Mr. Downey delivers the best popcorn flick performance since Johnny Depp first played pirate.
If you've seen the trailer, then you've already seen a much more entertaining version of War.
Heck, it could be worse: It could be an Olsen Twins movie.
Some of the "MOH" episodes turned out to be real clunkers. Unfortunately this is one of 'em.
Once the characters start spewing out reams of dialogue about "geostigma," "sephiroth," and "genova," my eyeballs involuntarily start to glaze over.
I'm certain I'm not the only one who'll make this comparison, but Zodiac could be the All the President's Men of serial killer movies.
Austerely directed but shamelessly dry, uneventful and derivative.
Binder's made some really fine movies and some curiously weak ones; my opinion is that this one falls firmly in the latter group.
This is coming from a guy who really enjoys a "slow burn" ghost story: The Abandoned is a grade-A snoozer.
Hearkens back to comedy classics like Police Academy 5: Assignment Miami Beach, specifically in the areas of quality control, production value and chuckle quota.
What begins as a standard-yet-watchable superhero adventure slowly congeals into something approaching the caliber of Catwoman. Not as bad, but kinda knocking on the doorstep.
Technical assets are predictably sketchy, but the flick maintains a light tone and brisk pace, so that kinda evens things out.
movie_title: Glow Ropes: The Rise and Fall of a Bar Mitzvah Emcee (2004)

movie_review_blurb: If you're looking for a bare-bones story about girl-on-woman love that goes precisely where you're expecting it to go, you could do worse.
Visually arresting and wildly cut together, 300 is (despite its well-earned R-rating) precisely the kind of movie that turns 14-year-old boys into ravenous movie geeks.
Not since The Exorcist had a horror flick been this applauded! It was almost as if ... "horror" were its own legitimate genre!
I loved this movie. Loved every last character, twist, kiss, joke and pie found within it.
A stunningly inert, painfully derivative, shamelessly cheap and aggressively dull ghost story that delivers nothing you haven't seen before. About 43 times.
All I saw was two guys groping each other for an hour, followed by a half hour of some truly disturbing snack-time.
Even playing the president, Lou Gossett looks embarrassed to be appearing in this type of cable network filler.
It's a testament to writer/director Mike White's talents that Peggy's miseries are shown as humorously tragic, but also simply, plainly painful.
The humor is fast-paced and character-based, and the two leads are nothing short of hilarious.
Feels like thirty pages of script in a 90-minute frame.
Equal parts affectionately silly and insightfully satirical.
It's basically just another "teens hate everyone, especially each other" story.
A few more movies like Norbit and Eddie Murphy won't have a fanbase to kick around anymore.
Slickly shot, generally well-acted, and entirely, predictably conventional from stem to stern.
A movie doesn't have to be unique in order for it to work, and Diggers provides just enough wit, warmth and insight to warrant a visit.
Thanks, Mr. Apatow, for (once again) proving that "R Rated Comedy" is not the exclusive domain of the base, the callous and the insipid.
A perfectly watchable time-killer that delivers on its promises but also kind of wears out its welcome.
Clearly we're not talking Shakespeare here, but taken at face value, the new-fangled TMNT is quite a lot better than what I'd expected.
Not even the few moments of grim humor and bloodletting can salvage the flick's leaden pacing and overbaked narrative.
Very short, very nutty, and quite a bit funnier than most Hollywood comedies I've seen in recent years.
There's very little here that the horror fans haven't seen before.
Of interest mainly to those who seek out the weirdest and most 'underground' sort of exploitation flicks.
This the kind of mini-series that the networks don't even ATTEMPT anymore!
precisely the sort of mild and harmlessly familiar TV schmaltz that goes down easy - and leaves nary a trace.
Mention this flick to any guy over 40 and watch him get all weepy.
Wavers between broad comedy, dark humor and mild thriller territory, never once settling on an approach -- and suffering mightily because of it.
Surprisingly well-acted, fast-paced, frequently amusing and packed with some really crazy kills near the end.
The flick's got just just as much first-half "filler" as it does second-half intensity, so if you're a patient genre fan, I've no problem recommending the movie.
Berman balances the weight of the actual events with the desire to mount a simply effective horror story, and I think he pulls it off quite well.
I'm amazed at how a few filmmakers can take a story so slight and trivial, and turn it into a 90-minute documentary that's as fascinating as something that Ken Burns put together.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I hate to be so down on a comedy that comes from so many filmmakers and actors I admire, but this flick's about as satisfying as a bowl of soggy Corn Flakes.
Equal parts witty, warm and almost painfully nostalgic.
It breezes by and slaps you with some ice water and then scurries right out of the room.
While I doubt I'll ever see the flick a second time, I've no problem recommending it to fans of dark and disturbing cinema.
Has "Well, at least you'll watch it on cable" written all over it.
movie_title: Decoys 2: Alien Seduction (Decoys: The Second Seduction) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I've got a real soft spot for moronic movies about massive monsters, but even I have my limits.
It's a low-budget and blood-soaked "haunted prison" affair, but it's also one that delivers the goods at an appreciably slick clip.
I discovered a solid handful of worthwhile chuckles in the flick, most of which came from the smoothly reliable Paul Rudd and the still-adorable Winona Ryder.
It sure wouldn't surprise me if my fellow horror geeks decided to embrace this one quite enthusiastically.
Because nothing in the universe is funnier than watching Jack Sparrow or Willy Wonka break out into hip-hop gyrations.
Just when you're sure you know how Delirious is going to close, DiCillo comes up with a capper that's as satisfying as it is understated.
No frills, no extras, just one classic hockey game per disc.
Not everything needs to be a reality series.
I don't know who's out there buying the American Pie video sequels, but I sure do wish they'd stop.
Just a nice sweet family flick, exceedingly well-made and surprisingly witty.
Cool in a cornball kinda way, but hey, these movies are considered classics for a reason.
An instantly forgettable confection that'll bore more kids than it entertains.
It's got 12 or 15 moments of inspired comedy ... stuck in an 88-minute frame packed with full-on wheel-spinning.
You'll probably spot eight or nine different pieces of uncredited source material as the garish smear of Eragon washes over you.
I'd probably agree that Rocky Balboa is the best entry since the first one -- but we're not exactly placing it up against any tough competition, now are we?
Shapeless and redundant, this flick is exactly the sort of movie you'd envision if I said "mildly retarded yet physically gorgeous young romance."
A schmaltzy little piece of obvious fluff that's directed in truly horrendous fashion and populated by cardboard characters who spit out simplistic platitudes and breathy pop tunes.
Frankly movies like Material Girls sicken me; they're base and soulless and entirely unworthy of the celluloid they were filmed upon.
When a small delivery of casual swearing from Seymour Cassell earns your movie's biggest laugh, there's definitely a problem.

The animation is perfectly colorful and the voice actors earn their paychecks, but it's blatantly obvious that this thing started production without a screenplay -- and hit the screens without a plot.
If you rent these flicks for the goofiness, this one's worthy of a rental. If you're renting them for fresh ideas or high-quality filmmaking, you're plain old nutty.
Comes from a sincere (as in autobiographical) place, and, despite its familiar trappings, it's presented with an admirable lack of B.S.
It's plainly evident that all of the filmmakers approached the subject matter with appropriate honor and respect. (In other words, this movie is no Pearl Harbor.)
A "guy movie" mega-classic that's really gotten better with age.
I know it's harder to write good jokes than it is rotten ones, but based on what's displayed here, it doesn't seem like the effort was even made.
It's a kung fu party, a loopy comedy, a gore flick, and a slap-your-forehead acid trip at the same time.
The thing starts out fun-bad, kind of like a novelty, but then gradually turns into a certifiable chore of biblical proportions.
Devoted genre fans should feel free to give it a rental, but don't expect to be blown away.
Feels like something that was written, shot and glued together over the course of one drab and uneventful weekend.
After sitting through the whole of Woodchipper Massacre you'll no doubt find yourself wondering how a movie this amateurish could ever find distribution. Hint: It's the title.
Exactly as bad as I thought it'd be, only with a few small glimmers of solid humor that made me annoyed there weren't more of 'em.
For all its quirky characterizations, semi-clever dialogue and convention-defying plot contortions, Rocket Science is a fairly schizophrenic affair.
Throw a rock into any year's Sundance guide and you're guaranteed to hit at least two or three multi-pronged grave and oh-so-earnest weep-dramas like this one.
I love a documentary that doles out both sides of an interesting story and then forces you to decide for yourself where the truth actually lies.
All things considered, these sets seem to be the best Bond releases yet.
One of the most realistically romantic movies I've seen in a while. And I'm not easily impressed by what generally passes for "movie romance."
Five pounds of (funny) stuff in a 12-pound bag.
I'm of the opinion that audacity is something to be admired in today's cinematic world, and Teeth has audacity to spare.
Destined to become one of those movies that college kids love to rent and smoke bongs with.
...at least it doesn't have Paris Hilton in it.
What's on display here is simply too stupid to believe.
Imagine the little kid from The Sixth Sense as a frazzled stay-at-home mom played by Marisa Tomei.
More like A Movie Stinking, or (more accurately) A Viewer Sleeping.
By the time the big finale shows up, you'll be absolutely thrilled; it's a harbinger of the end credits.
Yank the narration straight out of the movie, telling the story in only songs and pictures, and When You're Strange would be a much better film.
Living Death markets itself like a Saw wannabe, and it does get a little nasty in its final frames, but for the most part the flick is a very familiar tale of meanness, adultery, and revenge.
A few more months in the computer workshop (and okay, the editing booth) could have done wonders for this wacky little movie.
The fact that small girls line up to meet these soulless shrews makes me weep for the future. Seriously.
Despite its small handful of quality components, Night Skies is a pretty standard affair.
As a longtime fan of both horror flicks and Christina Ricci, I was willing to overlook The Gathering's five-year delay and actively look for some buried treasure in this flick. Alas, I found none.
I've always been a sucker for Animals Attack! movies, and this one manages to be a half-decent time-waster, if only in a 'rainy matinee' sort of way.
Half horror movie, half a mediocre episode of The Twilight Zone.
If you're weary of crime stories that follow the conventional path on the way to a generically inevitable conclusion, The Dead Girl is a title you might want to throw a red circle around.
The textbook definition of a Passable Matinee Comedy, Blades of Glory will please Will Ferrell's fans and irritate those who think figure skating is an activity worthy of reverence.
About as horrifying as Miss Piggy covered in barbecue sauce.
A rock-solid piece of animated sci-fi comedy that'll tickle the kids, amuse the parents, and leave everyone walking out of the theater on a sweet little flick-buzz.
It took me four attempts before I could watch the whole thing without falling asleep.
It looks pretty rotten and you've seen most of the comedy bits by now, but there's still a rusty little charm to this indie that prevented me from giving up.
A pleasant enough traveling companion for 91 unremarkable minutes, but not a flick you'll remember a week from now.
About as derivative as you can get ... which would be forgivable if only the thing had some FUN to offer. It doesn't.
Cheap-looking, witless and amateurish to the extreme.
Let's just say the first hour of the original film has more chuckles than both sequels put together.
Logically, if you're a huge fan of the actors covered in these episodes then you'll find a lot to enjoy in this box set.
Pure sitcom formula through and through, but it's delivered with a good deal of charm and warmth, too. Plus Cosby is hilarious, period.
When you actually want to climb into the movie and smack every single character, well, that can be a real chore.
A dry and dreary little affair, one that's almost shamefully beholden to B-flicks that are a lot more energetic and a lot less intent on being taken so seriously.
A pretty darn good, but not completely great, war movie that pays overdue homage to the WWII veterans who never made it home.
Yep, it's a bit too long and more than a little convoluted. It's still one of the best times I've had at the movies this year.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Wait, what movie were we talking about again?
A junior version of Underworld, minus the vampires, the action scenes, the cool FX, and the half-a-brain.
This well-produced, info-packed History Channel series covers the good, the bad, and the fascinatingly trivial, too.
A gigantic ice cream sundae for old-school genre film enthusiasts.
It's just that when you're offered two delicious treats in a row, and then the third one feels rushed, bland and undercooked, it's tough not to feel a bit disappointed.
Fans of the Hellboy property, particularly younger ones, should find enough to enjoy here.
Why the hell would you buy the rights to an established franchise when you never even PLANNED to make a good movie? It's like buying a classic car just so you can plow it into a brick wall.
Toss an extra twenty minutes on to Right to Die andyou'd have one of the year's coolest horror movies.
A novel spin on an oft-told tale, Alone with Her is a fine little indie indeed. What could have been just another gimmick flick turns out to be a pretty intense ride.
Capably blends action, sci-fi and comedy into one colorful concoction.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Call it the Guilty Pleasure of the year for me. Hell, it's a heck of a lot more entertaining than Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle.
Moore does a damn fine job of bringing "hidden" information to light in a fast-paced and surprisingly entertaining fashion.
A huge mess of celluloid that, frankly, never should have made it past the "Hey let's do BODY SNATCHERS again!" stage.
At the very least, it's an old-fashioned ghost story with half a brain -- and that's got to be worth more than a casual glance.
If you're a diehard fan of this particular series, Blood Feud is certainly worthy of a weekend rental, but feel free to skip through most of the chatty parts
A pretty chilling affair.
A fast-paced and completely unapologetic love-letter to the old-school '80s splatter sequels like Friday the 13th Part 2 and Texas Chainsaw 2. (Gory, too!)
Suffers from the normal low-budget sequel afflictions (spotty FX, lesser actors, skimpier action, lamer dialog).
"Fun enough junk" would be a fair way to describe both Darkman sequels.
movie_title: Darkman II - The Return of Durant (1994)

movie_review_blurb: It's all very colorful and pulpy and (thanks to Raimi's mega-slick direction) a real treat for the senses.
While certainly not on the same sub-level as the other SNL flicks, Hot Rod is more like 25% inspired weirdness and 75% recycled stuff.
About as scary as an episode of Unsolved Mysteries.
Not only is this a seriously goofy werewolf movie -- but they snipped out most of the juicy bits in order to earn a PG-13 rating. Gotta love it.
A fantastic little throwback, a smart and dark mixture of horror and science fiction.
I'm sure all the Monster Squad enthusiasts will be absolutely thrilled with the package Lionsgate has put together here.
Boyle and company start out with a smoothly claustrophobic space adventure, take a dark right turn into disaster territory, and end up squarely in a horror story. I enjoyed the trip.
Just when you think the agony has subsided and the kids have to go home for supper, a freakin' music video breaks out.
Just stick with a double feature of Babe and Superman. Now that's a family movie night.
Not only an improvement over its very fine predecessors -- it's easily one of the best movies of the year.
The most ridiculous film of its sort since the arrival of the equally ridiculous Boxing Helena. (Yeah, it's that kind of bad.)
One of the most creative Poe adaptations you're likely to come across.
Instead of trying to make the "be-all end-all ultimate mega-Simpsons episode," they went with their proven formula and delivered one of the year's funniest movies.
Flat, loud, flashy spectacle that's been fine-tuned and sanded down to appeal to the widest global audience possible. All in all, pretty generic.
Reiner keeps everything moving while letting Harmon do the heavy lifting as his young co-stars sprinkle the chuckles around.
Seven people and six mutants wandering through a series of basements and boiler rooms.
Nothing flashy or too exciting, but a little bit of brain food, delivered with quality.
Sometimes dry, sometimes wacky, but surprisingly compelling throughout.

A straight-faced and reality-based piece of "old-school" science fiction, the kind that's more concerned with concepts like mind control and the power of suggestion than it is flashy chases or explosions.
I still have next to no freaking idea what I just sat through, but (despite the surreal ugliness of the thing) I can't say I actually regret watching it.
Clocking in at a meaty 136 minutes, Spider-Man 2.1 manages to improve upon an already darn fine film.
There's nothing brilliant or revolutionary about Fracture. It's simply a well-made crime thriller, period.
A pretty clever mixture of slow-burn horror and tongue-in-cheek satire.
An absolute must-own for anyone who's seen Jaws at least 10 or 12 times.
If you're a hardcore video game junkie and you've got a soft spot for scrappy little indie flicks, I'd call Gamebox 1.0 worthy of the rental fee.
A one-note slog through some painfully familiar territory.
A homogenized and entirely pre-packaged "thriller" that doesn't even bother doling out any "thrills."
As tiresome as it is beholden to a dozen (much better) crime stories.
The first film is like an actual nightmare, whereas the sequels feel more like someone's garish descriptions of a nightmare.
Doesn't fall into any of the easily-classifiable genres, and I suppose that's one of the reasons it's so well-remembered all these years later.
The flick doesn't do all that much for me, but there's little denying that some long overdue care and effort went into this DVD release.
You'd think a southern-fried stew full of Lovecraft, Carpenter and Spielberg influences would make for a fairly decent way to spend 91 minutes. Nope.
A movie that could teach a cup of strong coffee how to yawn.
Call it C-level horror fluff if you like, but at least it moves quick and has lots of (obvious) in-jokes for the horror nerds. Like me.
The flick feels like it wants to be a stark, dark and female-empowered shocker like High Tension, yet it fails on nearly every count.
When a movie can't even make something like "biblical plagues" worth watching, you just know you're in the hands of filmmakers as lazy as they are lost.
Gilliam's weirdest -- and most disappointing.
If you're looking for a movie so bad it could teach small children what bad filmmaking is all about, here's the first thing you should pull off the shelf.
Truth be told, the only entertainment value to be found here is strictly of the "accidental" variety.
Admirably matter-of-fact about its antagonist and his ceaseless barrage of emotional road blocks. (Plus it's funny.)
While certainly an entertaining enough romp through the world of bullet-defying tough guys, the movie could use perhaps 10% more action or 15% less chit-chat.
One last pass through the editor's office could have turned a darn good movie into a truly great one, but fans of the genre will almost certainly enjoy it.
A tight-fisted and hard-hearted little "under the radar" horror flick that I quite enjoyed.
A salad bar of misogyny, homophobia and hatred for all things that aren't A) American, B) male, and C) stupid.
Aspiring filmmakers should check it out as a lesson plan from Bizarro World: Make a movie that's the exact opposite of The Ex and it could be the funniest film ever made.
So yeah, it's kind of fun. Even if it's not very good.
The first film in the series I'd choose to describe as "sloppy," and given the money and talent behind these flicks, that's one serious disappointment.
A devious and admirably twisted little mind-bender of a genre flick.
The guys basically drive right into trucks and fling their bodies through billboards with no fear whatsoever. It's pretty wild.
Well-intentioned, well-shot, well-acted and, well, boring.
Credit is definitely due to writer/directors Kim Roberts and Eli Despres for trying to come up with something a little brainier than "three chicks get killed in a cabin."
Just a simple little "people drama," nothing more, but a very well-crafted and heartfelt one all the same.
A mixed bag, to be sure, but it's a bit slicker and smarter than most flicks of this type.
Born to Fight exists solely for the action, and there's no denying that the flick delivers it. And how.
If you're looking for cheesy B-movies on your next visit to Netflix, you could do worse.
Each lame-duck gag hits the screen with an audible thud before the director decides to point his camera at something even less amusing.
A movie about that panicky feeling you get when you know the romance has died.
What Saw 5 might look like if it were co-directed by David Lynch, Rod Serling and the Pang brothers.
Two out of three is not a terrible batting average, as anthology pieces go...
I'd call Vacancy a 'guilty pleasure' -- only I don't really feel any guilt about enjoying and recommending a fast-paced fright flick like this one.
Those with a taste for the international scary fare may want to give the flick a shot for themselves, but I recommend they bring a lamp, a book and some coffee.
A quick, smart, slick piece of comedy filmmaking that features a once-great comedian at the very top of his game.
Straddles a fence between adequately clever and surprisingly stupid ... but most of it is still fun anyway.
The fans will dig the brief-yet-nasty FX work, but they'll have to slog through a pretty tiresome movie just to get their hands on those nuggets.
The idea that you'd dole out 15 dollars for something so poor is just laughable.
As a meditation on horror films, and even film itself, Resolution might be in danger of coming across as pretentious, if it weren't so damned entertaining throughout.

Despite doubling as a plausibility-straining endorsement for the battery life of Apple's iPhone, Dickerson's claustrophobic survival thriller proves itself a technically proficient, expertly paced affair.
As a mild diversion that won't bother either person on a date, one could do far worse.
Just another entry in Bland Fairy Tale Theater, a shapeless riff on those hapless German siblings with the worst parents ever.

Many viewers will lack the emotional fortitude (or cinematic masochism?) to withstand About Sunny. But for those who can, there is, at the center of its interminable sadness, a beautiful portrait of the sacrifice a mother will make for her child.
Like Edgar Wright's Shaun of the Dead, Coscarelli's film functions as affectionate homage to the horror material from which it draws its inspiration.

Although audiences may find themselves similarly frustrated by the film's reduction in scope, it nevertheless effectively focuses on the efforts of Josue Lajeunesse and his vision of building out the foundation laid by his father.
The audience has been delighted to spend some time with a couple of remarkable young ladies.
Within the barebones scaffolding of its story, there are ample opportunities for delivering many massive martial arts smack-downs. All are wasted.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: That Disney's in-house effort mostly plays like an actual Pixar film is a fine compliment.
A brutally efficient exercise in B-movie know-how.
They would have been better off channeling their inner Ellen Ripley and pulling the release to the airlock before this voyage departed.
Taken as a whole, The Wolverine is nearly as hit-and-miss as the rest of Mangold's filmography.
The most frustrating thing about Jeremy Power Regimbal's directorial debut is there's part of a very effective thriller here. It's just not the good part.
Despite the occasional failure of the film to let the atmosphere and subtle performances stand unadorned, We Are What We Are is an impressive entry from director Mickle.
The love story at the center of Spring is mysterious, funny and often poignant -- a tough enough thing even to describe, let alone commit to film.
La Camioneta wrings an extraordinary amount of humanity and geopolitical insight from its subject.
movie_title: La Camioneta: The Journey of One American School Bus (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's obvious that, at the very least, the production ... must have been an absolute blast. Whether or not that's enough for the viewer? Well, sometimes it's okay to defer to one's instinct in the end.
Enjoy The Endless-Benson and Moorhead are on a roll.
Henry Hobson's morose family tragedy, Maggie, features zombie-ism incidentally, seemingly with nothing on its mind other than witnessing its characters suffer.
What a throwback pleasure director Lee Toland Krieger's latest would have been, if it weren't so exasperatingly unfocused.

Although [this film] is easily the best entry in the (theoretically) Bilbo-centric franchise, the inherent problems with blowing up a compact children's fantasy book into a three-part epic film series... is never more apparent than it is here.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The blood-slicked, vividly drawn film universe John Wick illustrates is such a generous slice of pulp that, even if not original, per se, it exudes a confidence rarely seen these days, surefire franchises be damned.
Pair it with the likes of Machete or Hobo with a Shotgun, and you've got yourself a fantastic way to waste a Sunday afternoon.
Now, it's 2014, and the third iteration has arrived, working itself into such a lather in its attempt to resuscitate the momentum that one can practically smell the flop sweat.

[It's] filled to near bursting as its enormous cast scrambles through the vagaries of its time travel paradox-rich design. But Singer threads the needle with such apparent effortlessness in stitching it all together, the seams are practically invisible.
It's a rare feat for a film to successfully convey the voice of the Other. Especially when that voice is an Other to everyone else here on Earth.
As a horror flick, even one held to the impossibly low standards of the found-footage variety, Alien Abduction fails to thrill or chill.
Spike Jonze is, despite proof consisting only of four features, one of the best filmmakers working today. His latest, Her handily verifies it.
Side Effects is, ultimately, another example of the director's commitment to fine craftsmanship above any identifiable fingerprint.
Ragnarok ain't a home run, but it's a solid double, and certainly enough to cause Hollywood scouts to raise an eyebrow.
Each of these stories slowly unfurls its metaphoric underpinning and meaning in modern Portuguese politics just in time for the next fable to begin.
movie_title: Arabian Nights: Volume 1 - The Restless One (As Mil e Uma Noites: Volume 1, O Inquieto) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This horrifically precious, self-satisfied brain freeze of a movie is what most of America probably pictures a Bernie Sanders presidency looking like.
This film's nastiness is a virtue.
Confined to a few locations and shaking with ecstasy, possibility and the torment of being alive, "Cosmos" is like absinthe distilled secretly in a prison cell.
Gomes plays with the traditions of the past and the tangible facts of the presents, hoping for a brighter future for his homeland.
movie_title: Arabian Nights: Volume 3, the Enchanted One (As Mil e Uma Noites: Volume 3, O Encantado) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The melancholy that falls over this chapter is hard to shake but its tempered slightly by the love Gomes has for his characters, bad habits, ingrained sadness and all.
movie_title: Arabian Nights: Volume 2 - The Desolate One (As Mil e Uma Noites: Volume 2, O Desolado) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If Slaboshpitsky retrofitted his tiresome screenplay with sign language because he wanted to prove that everyone, no matter their circumstances, is only human, I can think of a dozen much less dimwitted strategies he might have employed.
Holland never risks overlooking the hardship that comes with being on the right side of history. "Burning Bush" is a riposte to the idea that there's anything beautiful about dying for your beliefs.
It's a little heavy on incident, and a little light on soul.
Saying "P'tit Quinquin" is Dumont's funniest and warmest film doesn't count for much, but could I interest you in one of the sharpest autocritiques in recent memory?

"The Blue Room" often feels like a work of cinematic futurism, not dissimilar to the films of Steven Soderbergh. It constructs ideal romantic and erotic zones, only to eye them from a clinical remove mere seconds later.
"The Congress" is a roll call of the orgiastic pleasures and bountiful comforts that art provides, and, a reminder of what waits for us when we leave the theater.
A good faith but blank retelling of McCarthy's first major statement.
Naturally, the problem with the movie isn't the four women ably kicking adversity in the teeth, it's the man behind the camera.
It illustrates, both bluntly and gently, the stultifying trap of male influence.
Kopple spends a few minutes at a time on any given subject before changing focus. If she'd kept the camera trained on Jones, the payoff would have been titanic.

"The Captive" may appear to bite off a little more than it can chew but it's one of the most satisfyingly baroque thrillers of the year, and thanks to a perfectly judged performance by Ryan Reynolds, it's quietly heartbreaking, too.
