With this panting, ragged chase through the end of the world, Cuarón and Lubezski have reinvented the language of the action film.

This is a mournful, difficult film, but also a masterful one. Eastwood finds pockets of kindness and humanity where you'd least expect them, and once again cements his hard-earned reputation as the restless inquisitor of our national mythologies.
The worst movie of 1998.

Such a tangled thicket of overwritten, labyrinthine mythology, backstabbing betrayals and mixed motivations that a massive chunk of the running time is devoted to characters standing around on boats, trying like hell to explain the plot to one another.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: These sometimes draggy two hours feel like time well-spent with a gentleman, and Lord knows there aren't many Presidents you can say that about these days.
A nutzoid chiller devoted to proving the strange, unseemly notion that even bloodthirsty serial killers are more enjoyable company than bad MySpace comedians.
As typical of even the decent Farrelly productions, it's indifferently photographed and runs at least half an hour too long.
This, ladies and gentlemen, is a Movie Star.

The mosaic of moods conjures something that feels both ancient and startlingly contemporary -- with the same doom-laden DNA as great druggy, fatalistic 1970s anti-Westerns like McCabe & Mrs. Miller and Pat Garrett And Billy The Kid.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers must've noticed what a hit that first film was among teenage girls, and thus for the sequel instructed Blanchett to play the 52-year-old monarch as if auditioning for High School Musical 3.

Real life comes crashing into Anderson-ville... and for the first time in his career, the filmmaker seems to be playing the pain for real, without any sight gags or ironic distance to cushion the blow.
Everybody's got a song to sing, and we'll all believe exactly what we want for just as long as we can.
It's official: Ben Affleck isn't embarrassing anymore.

Terrific character actors such as J.K. Simmons furrow their brows. Streep responds by speaking in Red-State bumper-sticker slogans, ordering up some torture and then gnawing the heads off newborn babies.
...about as pleasant as a movie can get without actually being any good.

Lumet shrewdly hangs back, exploiting the long-take potential of his crappy DV and letting scenes play out for what feels like ages, granting this naughty little noir a soul that probably never existed on the page.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Even a stale old tune can sound great if it's covered properly...
The best children's stories are the simplest, and this one's a complicated mess.
The simple saga of two tough hombres, a bag of money and everybody unlucky enough to get in their way blossoms into something far more delicate, contemplative and almost mythical.

It's the role of an artist to not just comment on current events, but also to shape that commentary into a dramatic form that'll excite, move and inspire people. Lions for Lambs isn't filmmaking; it's list-making.
Perhaps nowhere outside pornography have you seen performances as stiff, amateurish and off-putting... shattering every illusion of realism the film grasps after so fervently.
Grindingly unpleasant yet undeniably hilarious, the movie might as well be called: Squid 2: This Time It's Mommy's Turn.
Okay, so there is a certain 'gotta-see-it-to-believe-it' factor when you're watching Tony Soprano suffering horrific bowel problems and singing Springsteen's Red-Headed Woman, but seriously, folks...

From scene to scene you sense Coppola has a strong personal connection with both this character and the material, but it's never articulated clearly enough to elevate her film beyond an admirable head-scratcher.
King went so far as to issue a press release saying 'anybody who reveals the ending should be hung from the neck until dead.' Funny, I could say the same about whoever came up with it.

It throbs with color, possibility and hope, fueled by an un-ironic adolescent yearning as plaintive (and only occasionally embarrassing) as the mega-earnest Eddie Vedder tunes that fill the soundtrack.
Somehow Garlin maintains a buoyant, humanistic tone throughout the parade of lonely humiliations. It's an endearing little movie with a great big heart.
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It feels more like the pilot for a cable series than an actual movie. (In fact, the nicest thing you can say about Feast Of Love is there's a ton of nudity.)
I saw a film today, oh boy.
It's fairly charming, extremely well put-together, and by this time next week I doubt I'll remember even having seen it.
Jolie delivers a performance that's astonishing in its control.... she's dialed down her natural histrionics and gone for something far quieter and deeper than expected.

Willis lumbers through the movie like an angry dinosaur, while Wiseman panders to a generation that wasn't even born when the first flick was released. 'Yippie-kay-yay, motherfu-' -- whoops, can't say that one anymore either.
In another lifetime, Michael Moore and George W. Bush probably would have been great friends.
Most directors would be content to retire with Armaggedon as the stupidest film on their resume. Let it not be said that Michael Bay doesn't know how to top himself.
Broad as a barn door, but shamelessly entertaining...
The first 2007 mega-budget summer blockbuster that's actually worth a damn... four sequels into this saga, it finally feels like we're watching a bona fide, honest to God movie.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There's a lot of promise here, but Cashback can't get out of its own way.
Nobody expects a Spanish Inquisition!
Lewd, crude and straight from the heart...
The movie is trying to tell you that gays are people too. Sure they're icky, embarrassing people, but you should still be nice to them.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: For starters, Buscemi is woefully miscast. The movie needed Anthony Quinn, not Peter Lorre.
As propulsive and nerve-jangling as any action flick I've ever seen...but what's most interesting is the harsh moral severity Greengrass has imposed on this series.
...the saddest, scariest horror movie I've seen in years.
2007: The Year Judd Apatow And Seth Rogen Saved Movie Comedy.
Brian Steidle wants to show you some pictures. Please look at them.
A well made, if extremely hollow, technical exercise... so wafer-thin, I'm a little wary of calling it a movie. It's more like a photographed premise.
Improbably compelling... it's every bit the rousing crowd-pleaser I wanted Rocky Balboa to be.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Crowe adopts a stance of detached bemusement, his eyes alight at what he's watching, almost as if he's decided to play along with his adversary's dogged persistence... just to see where they'll end up.
Completely retarded and totally awesome...
After a mesmerizing first hour, the film implodes so quickly our sputtering sun can barely keep pace.

Malick makes up his own cinematic language as he goes along -- a drifting, painterly eye-of-God perspective that discards boring narrative conventions. Savor this one, folks.

movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As always, Beckinsale remains a beautiful void --one with all the right curves and not a glimmer of personality... a pretty, porcelain nothing.

A loose, generous, funky little oater with a deliciously ghoulish sense of humor, it's probably the sweetest movie I've ever seen about taking a road trip with a rotting corpse.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's the most intimate concert picture I've ever seen. Reading between the frets and chords, here's a movie all about friendship and community.
...the movie everybody wanted Fahrenheit 9/11 to be.

Rude, smarmy and sickly hilarious, Manderlay has a little something to offend everyone... and I wouldn't have it any other way.

...maybe the all-around finest Christmas flick I've seen since the original Die Hard.

An almost absurdly pleasurable and well-crafted entertainment...
There's so much good stuff in here you'll wish it all fit together somehow.

movie_review_blurb: A full-frontal formalist assault on the very concept of celebrity bio-pics... drifting and riffing on contradictions, drop-dead funny, and easily the most go-for-broke, energizing movie I've seen all year.

So, um... when does the movie start?

The most focused Potter movie yet... it's all about puberty and death.

movie_review_blurb: Something like a dream Madonna might've had while she nodded off during Spellbound...

Clumsy, well-meaning, and almost rescued by the amazing Diane Keaton.
This year's Million Dollar Baby, it's a similarly plainspoken, straightforward little masterpiece of heartbreak and regret.

Has M. Night Shyamalan lost his damn mind?

Playfully profound... and crazier than Michael Jackson on the top floor of a skyscraper nursery surrounded by open windows.

movie_review_blurb: A broad, ribald circus flagrantly in love with the English language, The Tailor bustles with swaggering, jubilant showmanship.
Diesel is Rambo by way of the Village People
Always audacious and never less than entertaining, even when it's coming apart at the seams.
What a strange and beautiful film!
...the most dispiriting leap backward into irrelevance by a filmmaker since Francis Ford Coppola directed Jack.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Yawn. Remember when war movies didn't need love triangles?

This is the first R-rated movie that feels PG-13, a heavy-metal saga you can take Mom to see.
A mean, ugly exploitation picture with sophomoric delusions of grandeur.
I'm just too bored to care.
...the kind of movie you see because the theater has air conditioning.
Sam Mendes has become valedictorian at the School for Soft Landings and Easy Ways Out.

...perhaps the heaviest, most joyless movie ever made about giant dragons taking over the world.
Spielberg has never walked such a dangerous tightrope, never made a movie so fearless.

The truth is, I have never seen a movie with this much exposition, and I still have no idea what was going on most of the time.

movie_title: Der Krieger und die Kaiserin (The Princess and the Warrior) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Most amazing is that Favreau not only keeps things hilarious even at their darkest, but he plays it all for keeps. There's not a "hip" or glib moment in the whole picture.

The worst thing to happen to movies in the past decade--a bold-faced negation of art, craft, emotion and importance.

A lot of the time it feels like Angela's Ashes have been scattered in Pleasantville.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Eighties nostalgia has seeped so far into our pop-cultural landscape, it's starting to feel like VH1 took over the movie studios.
Now this is more like it! Mostly you remember the sadness -- a strange, tired melancholy distilled from a thousand weary Westerns

A perversely compelling collection of ghastly ideas...
Illogical, dour, humorless...and Penn played a smarter character in I Am Sam.

movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: If Clint Eastwood were a parrot, he'd be Connor.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Most of the actors have elected to play their knights like crotchety Western gunslingers, a bizarre choice that blows a good deal of fresh air into the stuffy pageantry.

Disappointingly superficial -- even the most interesting children get lost in the constant shuffle on and off-stage. It spends too little time with too many people.
Growing up Star Wars is like growing up Catholic- no matter how bitter you might become, ya can't shake it. Last week I bought CHEEZ-ITs because R2-D2 was on the box.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Like The Sopranos, Layer Cake presents the criminal underworld as a tiring, middle-management nightmare.

movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Somebody give this guy the next Harry Potter movie, please.

movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: What an odd accident of fate --and sad collision of dietary demands-- that the stage's most famous Jew would wind up being played so wonderfully by film's most delicious ham.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

... slick and unpretentious, it wants nothing more than to be this year's Cellular -- and for maybe an hour or so it succeeds.

movie_review_blurb: That faint scraping sound you hear coming from the floor is Robert Aldrich rolling in his grave.
Marty's most crowd-pleasing, well-behaved movie -- The Aviator is the first Scorsese picture that feels housebroken.

A low-rent movie with an expensive cast.
Shoes, money, outfits, shoes, vagina, money, shoes, jewelry, outfits, money, shoes.

Peckinpah's final word on a genre he helped define, and the greatest movie you almost never got a chance to see.

One of the great sustained acts of virtuosity in American cinema.
More than once I recalled David Letterman's crack: "Sorry you couldn't be here tonight, Joaquin."

Everyone here has the best of intentions. The Intern has a gentle spirit, and is about people who are decent. There's not a lot of conflict, but we root for these characters because we enjoy spending time with them.
Ant-Man is a lark. It's a lighthearted, human-scaled matinee adventure that feels like an antidote to this summer's dour Avengers: Age of Ultron and its droning marathon of destruction.
The film got me fuming about the meat-grinder of modern stardom in our garbage popular culture, the way we toss in these defenseless kids and then amuse ourselves to no end as they're shredded.
The movie is stiff and enervated. It's all punch-punch, banter-banter, like a sitcom in which cities get leveled.
Arnold's doing Eastwood again, and this is his Million Dollar Zombie.
You stumble out of the theatre giddy about what films can do, transported by the breathtaking velocity in this battering ram of a picture that just goes, goes, goes and then keeps on going.
A deeply personal blockbuster. It feels like actual human beings made it instead of some anonymous, corporate focus-group Marvel committee.
What makes Results so special is that it delivers all the conventional rom-com satisfactions while also stubbornly being it's own unique thing.
Ayer is like Sam Peckinpah without the self-loathing, or the poetry.
The final reel of Camp X-Ray is actually kinda terrible, but that's not enough to undo all the excellence that has come before. At least not for me.
For a movie that tries so hard to be disturbing, Nightcrawler is actually quite comforting. It takes a societal sickness and blames it on a boogeyman.
Light as an anvil, Birdman is a sometimes dazzling, often infuriating act of gaseous virtuosity. I was never sure if I should applaud or roll my eyes. A lot of the time I was doing both.
Some might call it 'meta' but to me it just feels sour. Turns out self-loathing is not an attractive quality in a blockbuster entertainment.
This pleasant, spectacularly uninformative documentary celebrates a venerable television institution that already spends quite enough time celebrating itself, thank you very much.

This may not be a pleasant viewing experience, but it is an enormously compelling one, and with exceptional artistry it forced me to look at and consider people from whom on the street I too often look away.
I found this all rather thrilling to watch even when it wasn't going anywhere.

I don't normally like to cast aspersions on people over differences of opinion, but this one's engineered to suck up so hard at easy-lay critics that I swear you little boys can do better. Try harder. Please. The dying girl deserves more than you.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Does a cliche s--t in the woods?
I had a really good time watching this movie, remembering the simple pleasures of a goofy, ripping yarn. Big Game is huge fun.
A pointless but not unentertaining diversion, Terminator Genisys exists for the same reason a dog licks his balls: because it can.

The movie's sunny generosity of spirit serves as a sneak-attack on conventional movie masculinity, ripping machismo away from toxic Wahlberg-ian Bro culture and offering a more evolved, inclusive concept of manhood.
Bad art movies can be such a chore sometimes.
Tangerine is a lewd, madcap romp tempered with unexpected moments of sweetness and grace. It's a bawdy farce with a heart of gold and I loved it from start to finish.
Sean Penn is without question the greatest actor of his generation, but that doesn't necessarily mean he can carry an action movie.
A single sequence can't make a lousy movie great, but the one in The Walk comes awfully close.
A warm, wistful documentary that fondly recalls a time when buying music was a communal activity and not just clicking on things.
movie_title: All Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This film isn't a masterpiece by any means, but it is at times very good, with an unfussy jewel of a performance by Tom Hanks that's all the more remarkable for appearing so effortless.
I often feel like the only movie characters more tedious than Linklater's leads were played by Zeppo Marx.
The sad middle-aged dudes who cling so desperately to these films require constant reassurances that they're not just fun stories for children in which men wear tights.
"There are never really any new toys in Shane Black's sandbox but he always plays with them better than the other kids."
The Meddler feels toned down a few notches from your typical movie comedy. It feels like life.
In the sequel these guys should all run for president.
This year's best superhero movie yet, which isn't saying much.
An aesthetic shambles on every front, fanatically overpraised in certain circles for its strenuous and spotty bits of progressive lip service.
I enjoyed Money Monster enormously, right up until it turned into one of the stupidest movies ever made.
The Horsemen, The Eye - a lot of the names here feel like placeholders nobody got around to filling in later.
One of the best movies ever made about making movies.
An amazing thing happened when Ralph Fiennes started going bald because that's when the world found out he's funny.
Perhaps it's because I'm a soulless husk of a man and dead inside, but the Pixar formula just isn't cutting it for me anymore.
The movie has a heart as big as its Johnson.
Hightower has a naturally commanding screen presence. Imagine if Steve McQueen was an eleven-year-old black girl and you're starting to get the idea.
Minus any movie stars and skimping on production values, it's the off-brand blockbuster equivalent of shopping at the Dollar Tree.
It is a strange feeling to be watching a movie that seems to be apologizing for itself as it goes along.
Feig's girl-power Ghostbusters was forged in a crucible of man-baby cyber-bullying and it wears a chip on its shoulder proudly.

Waititi's film has the stylized exaggerations and emotional directness of the best children's literature. Everything is just a tiny bit louder and more colorful than real life, but the feelings are straightforward and unadorned.
The slow-drip plot mechanics lead us to assume that all our questions will eventually be answered, but what makes Midnight Special so damn frustrating is that most of them aren't even asked.
Trash is a step up from Extremely Loud's cloying 9/11 exploitation simply by virtue of not being one of the most appalling movies ever made. It's still pretty crummy, though.

The movie has a bullying, hostile tone that comes through in the surly performances, a callous indifference to innocents killed and the general philosophical disposition of a teenager who just discovered Nietzsche after being grounded.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: From moment to moment the technique can be rapturous, and taken out of context any given few minutes of Knight Of Cups are thrilling to watch. It's just when you have a hundred and eighteen of those minutes in a row that it becomes numbing.
Directed with patented flashy sleight-of-hand for no particular purpose by Danny Boyle, Steve Jobs is slick and empty. It looks and sounds like a movie but it really isn't about anything.
A sci-fi horror cannibal exploitation picture by way of John Ford, it's a deliberately paced, old-fashioned Western that occasionally morphs into a splatter movie.
There's a jagged energy and a rawness to it. Miss You Already jerks its tears honestly.
Not bad for a brazenly derivative, time-killing knock-off.
Those screams you hear are thousands of Us Weekly readers trying to process an Antonioni homage.
Probably the lousiest Bond picture since the Roger Moore era, but I'll be damned if I'm gonna watch those Brosnan blunders again to make sure.
It's a lot of half-baked conceits that don't really fit together, but I'd be lying if I said I didn't laugh.
There's a flatly functional artlessness to the visuals. Spotlight is drab, sometimes bordering on ugly. It may be a film worth seeing, but there isn't much to look at.

Creed is the first Rocky sequel that feels like the first Rocky. It's human-scaled, rambling and idiosyncratic, with emotional payoffs larger than life. I spent most of the running time crying my eyes out.
A glorious provocation. At once deeply sorrowful and exuberantly silly, it's a scabrous, sexy musical comedy shot through with an almost unbearable sadness.
I spent the following 93 minutes wondering what kind of absurd bet Errol Morris must have lost to have his name associated with this dire project.
But nowhere here will you find the insights into obsession and humanity that made Melville's book a classic. The movie doesn't know Dick.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There's a reckless energy with which it lunges from one ga-ga visual flourish to another, consistency and coherence be damned.

Abrams nails the feeling of (re)visiting a rusted-out, slightly sarcastic fairy tale. Still, a few hours after the credits it's all evaporating and I'm struggling to recall a remotely original or inventive moment in the entire damn thing.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Amusing as this may be, there's something a bit studious about "Body Heat." Kasdan's ceiling fans and Venetian blinds often come across as film school affectations.

A spectacularly sleazy send-up that finds the puckish, thin-skinned director confronting his critics and doubling down on everything that upstanding, respectable people hate about Brian De Palma films.
An elliptical and at times preposterously entertaining load of hooey that both kids and embraces every chest-beating trope in that old 'He-Man Of Letters' tradition.

Another epistemological prank from cinema's snarkiest philosophers, "Hail, Caesar!" is a Passion Play played for giggles, with the Golden Age of Hollywood serving as the garden of Gethsemane for yet another in the Coens' long line of serious men.
The menu suggests filet mignon but Triple 9 turns out to be a really good cheeseburger.
Such a ramshackle affair that to call it slapdash would be a compliment. Yet still, I laughed like a drain.
Ultimately an excellent technical exercise, more interested in sustaining a mood and feeling than exploring the truly scary ideas rattling around beneath the surface of this story.
I'm speaking as a notorious aficionado of bad John Travolta movies when I say The Forger is a chore to sit through.
The movie feels stitched together and soldiered-on, with a heart-like-a-wheel coda that's not particularly well-executed, and is weirdly moving all the same.
What a difference a director makes.
A richly symbolic meditation on aging, mortality and precious time wasted.
A shoddily made, amateur-hour barrage of chintzy music, stock footage and flashy video effects that were presumably state of the art during the Reagan administration.
My favorite movie in years.
Every ill-considered editing choice here bears the sticky fingerprints of statuette-grubbing producer Harvey Weinstein, attempting to tame this rough material for mass consumption by Oscar voters.
Far more attentive to visual storytelling than most actors who step behind the camera, Fiennes conveys shifting dynamics through his characters' positions within the frame.
So histrionically abysmal that it makes you realize how lazy and complacent most other movies are in their banal mediocrity. The atrociousness is thrilling. As I left the theater, I felt alive again.
Clooney's lugubrious direction mimics the worst of those star-studded early-1960s epics, with lots of long dissolves and chunky inertia.
There's a doomy grandiosity befitting the title, and when violence inevitably occurs it is something not to be cheered, but mourned.
A curious cult oddity about the initially inspiring but ultimately codependent and destructive relationship between a man and a large chunk of sentient fungus growing on his bathroom floor.
The only prayers Left Behind inspires are for Nicolas Cage's career.
The muddled movie contains all the elements of a top-notch muckraker, deployed erratically and to increasingly diminished returns.
An endearing, affectionate snapshot of a fading way of life.
It all comes down to the electric toothbrushes.
Wild earns its emotional payoffs honestly, always underplaying where lesser movies would've lunged for Oscar Gold.
The key to best appreciating this stubbornly singular entertainment is to view these characters as the last men on the field, still playing a game they're achingly slow to learn is already over.
Everyone involved with this picture should be embarrassed, and boy do they look it.
A horrible masterpiece. Ugly, abstract and unrelenting, it's like having someone else's nightmare.
movie_title: Twin Peaks - Fire Walk with Me (1992)

movie_review_blurb: A hugely entertaining and almost entirely inscrutable lark, with a punk rock air of both surrender and rejuvenation.
Everything about Nebraska feels secondhand. It's a gimmicky sitcom script gussied up with 'artful' affectations borrowed from the New Hollywood heyday of the early '70s.
A slippery, enigmatic and altogether mesmerizing film about the passage of time, and the way our ideas about art evolve according to our life experiences.
It follows the template of every Bill Murray slobs-vs.-snobs comedy from the '80s, except this time people are dying.
Exarchopoulos' performance is a miracle, with every raw emotion rippling across her yearning, endlessly expressive face.
Tom Hooper's direction is an aesthetic crime.
It's a chilling, pitiless vision that offers no relief, just a portrait of decline.
I liked it better than Zombieland, if you're lookimg for something in a similar wheelhouse.
When did John McClane become such a dick?
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The most cutting gag is just how much Saavedra's political ads resemble his recent campaign for a diet cola. And the punch line is that they work.
Derek Cianfrance could probably be a great filmmaker if he wasn't trying so hard to be a Great Filmmaker
Reefer Madness with smartphones.
A film about fading out, about how youthful passions dissolve over time.
A smirky, sardonic sensibility smuggled in by Shane Black is almost enough to cure these summertime blues.
A slick piece of work that juts out at just enough odd angles to be idiosyncratic, but never alienating.
It's a private party, for Whedon fans only.
For the first half hour I thought it was gearing up to be one of the worst movies I have ever seen, but eventually it grew on me.
Despite the sometimes childish sight gags, what salvages the movie is a refreshingly adult attitude toward the messy matter of sexuality.
Andrew Dice Clay holding his own against Cate Blanchett? Now I've seen it all.
This is a giant nothing. I can't think of a recent picture where I've seen less effort to enlighten or entertain.
Thuddingly obvious and proud of it, Rush is a slick, breakneck entertainment.
It's a wonderful movie-funny, sad and wise about the crazy ways we torment ourselves in this thing called love.
This film sticks in your gut.
It's a cast of relaxed old pros with easy chemistry, all of whom seem to be having a great deal of fun. The feeling is almost mutual.
We've seen movies about the horrors of slavery before. This one is about the mechanics.

This middling little number feels like a rejected pilot for one of those sex-crime-fixated, baby-napping network procedurals designed to scare the crap out of senior citizens and security moms for ratings gold.

It is impossible to observe the film's interviews with Spinney and not be taken aback by the man's extraordinary sensitivity, and the deeply unhappy childhood that seems still very much with him today.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's fun checking in on Seagal every now and again in that mean way that the Germans have a word for, because the dude got really fat. Like, he's getting Brando heavy.
Such a deranged, half-kidding symphony of color, movement and sheer cinematic muscle, I spent most of the running time trying to pick my jaw up off the floor.
A complicated movie about an uncomplicated man, American Sniper strips down and rearranges Chris Kyle's best-selling autobiography into something far more troubled and unsettling.
A stubbornly conventional chronicle of a life that was anything but.
Morgen's lacerating collage swirls stock footage, animated interludes and brilliantly edited music cues into a slippery, impressionistic rendering, pitched at the wail of a soul in agony.
What we don't get is anything new. Nothing about Katie Holmes' great escape, no Leah Remini at all. This story didn't end four years ago, even though the movie does.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Unsparing about the ravages of time, cocaine and Lorne Michaels, Tirola's film also does what was previously considered impossible: it makes Chevy Chase seem like a human being.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A spiritual sequel to the Grumpy Old Men franchise, this often ignominious effort from offers the not inconsiderable pleasure of two old pros outclassing their surroundings at every turn.
Not what you'd call a well-made movie, but at least it has the good sense to let Lily Tomlin run wild for ninety minutes or so.
This thing is a dud for reasons that have nothing to do with casting, much as the trailer might look like a Funny Or Die sketch.
It's a slim, shadowy one-woman-show, with Silverman shedding every last vestige of her onstage persona and gazing long into to the abyss. A tough sit, but that ending sticks in your gut.
Short of a vaguely exploitative framing device, it's otherwise a thoughtful and perceptive exploration of power dynamics within the patently phony setting of a celebrity interview.
It's a slender conceit stretched out about as far as it can go.
Depending on your mood and sensibility you'll find this either effervescent or annoying as hell.
As it turns out, I love California Split so much that I didn't mind watching it again.
Another two hours hanging out in the Wachowskis' world. There's a groovy, multicultural, pansexual vibe where all are welcome and the deliberately artificial visuals are to die for.
There's a really funny, sexy comedy here that might have been wonderful, were it not also stuck with being an adaptation of this loathsome novel.
It's an easy, obvious target, which is probably why Maps To The Stars feels like such a crushing disappointment from a filmmaker I usually revere.
Exhilarating. And this is the best movie wedding since Melancholia.
A smoldering dumpster fire of second-hand elements from better movies.
The Chris Rock movie we've been waiting for, it's boisterous, rude and genuinely romantic.
It sneaks up on you as it goes along, offering unexpected shadings and variations on the minor-key absurdism.
A very odd film that ends as abruptly as it begins, so I guess we must all tune in next year to find out if it actually amounts to anything. This is just how big movies work now.
A stubbornly uncommercial and richly challenging inversion of Americana, this time with an eye towards the pioneer women pushed to the margins of our history books.
With every film, Crowe's formula comes more increasingly unhinged from any recognizable reality. Now his movies seem to take place on Mars.

It's slow, it's sad and it's very funny in ways that don't really revolve around punchlines. It's about characters who have been around the block one too many times and they're exhausted, full of dreams deferred, just trying to scrape by.
Just about every directorial choice here is so clankingly at odds with the material that, as the song goes, I couldn't take my eyes off of it. It's like watching Ingmar Bergman's Grease.
The film feels fatuous and irritatingly complacent. Everybody's calling attention to the barrage of familiar clichés without doing much to subvert them.
It's brawny, ballsy and cheerfully subversive. Howard Zinn meets The Road Warrior.
Desire makes buffoons of us all. Now strike dear mistress, and cure his heart.
A very easy movie to admire and almost impossible to enjoy. I spent most of the running time appreciating the artistry while wishing I could be anywhere else.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Moderately impressive while never truly incendiary, The Purge: Anarchy isn't a bad film. I just want Paul Verhoven to direct the next one.
Swanberg has become the foremost chronicler of a generation's belly-button lint without once having demonstrated even the slightest interest in learning how to make a movie.
Star Trek, in its many permutations and generations, is supposed to be about optimism, inclusiveness and faith in the future. That's something this picture gets right, and it's no small thing.
I think the moral of the story is that drugs are awesome. So is Scarlett.
And I'm the guy who usually likes this kind of crap.
More of the same, yet shockingly less.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A throwback-y, meat and potatoes potboiler that manages to get the job done with a minimum of fuss. The nastiness is bracing.
Schechter's staging is so flat that Leonard's dialogue never pops. You hear the words but not the music.
Movies seldom did right by Gandolfini, though he always did right by them.
A pulpy, sweaty and often insanely preposterous thriller. Gone Girl is a blast.
The movie is a sleek machine. It's viscerally thrilling, and distressingly hollow.
Yeah, so it's practically Oldboy. Except they don't make a big deal about it. Just a casual incest comedy subplot
It's just a really weird film, the strangest and most misguided fake-Spielberg picture since Super 8.
While still suffering from a few symptoms of blockbuster-itis, Guardians feels more relaxed than your typical corporate summer tentpole. It has a puckish, sideways wit.
A tedious affair about a tedious affair.
It's a strange picture; a melancholic dirge in the guise of a comic bauble, at once light as a feather and pitilessly sad.

I watched it in the morning and liked it just fine. By dinner time I had forgotten I'd seen a movie that day.
Neither the catastrophic disaster fanboy circles would have you believe nor particularly any good.
Yes, the movie's harrowing middle hour is almost too excruciating to endure. It upsets viewers and sends them streaming for the exits because it's supposed to.
Conjures an impossibly cool, fairy tale New York. One of those movies I wish I could live inside.
Heckerling undercuts the usual teensploitation tropes at every turn.
Taylor Sheridan is a very good writer with potential to be a great one if he ever learns when to put the pencil down.
Logan Lucky reminded me most of Howard Hawks' El Dorado. It has the tossed-off, casual sophistication of an old master's late work.
It's a marvelous piece of writing, smart and funny with even the most casual conversations ping-ponging back to the film's slippery central questions about the malleability of memory.
Crackles with nervous energy and uneasy laughs.
After an awfully rocky start, Bell eventually slows down the pace and lets her scenes breathe a bit. By the end I was surprised how much I'd come to care about these people.
I'm depressed to report that it's timelier than ever.
Like most comedy sequels, it assumes audiences want a louder and more outrageous version of what they enjoyed last time. And like most comedy sequels, it's pretty lousy.
The filmmaking choices here exhibit a bone-deep understanding of visual storytelling that's remarkable for a first-timer.
It's deflating to watch a film start out wanting to the be The King Of Comedy and settle for Single White Female.
Director Chadwick brings a stodgy, Oscar-bait sensibility that's firmly at odds with the pulpy, bodice-ripping plot mechanics.
At its best It feels like an R-rated version of The Goonies, if The Goonies wasn't one of the worst movies ever made.
The characters all feel one draft away from being distinctive, and while we're at it the set decoration could use some touching up.
Brilliantly crafted, perversely hilarious and also something of a chore.
A cautious work of corporate bet-hedging and product integration.
The best Boston movie evah.

Last year's despicable movie star auto-fellatio Patriots Day invented a phony hero to save the day. Stronger reminds us that tragedy and survival are a lot more complicated than a bumper-sticker slogan.
It's already shaping up to be the surprise hit of the summer, which really isn't surprising at all once you've seen it. This is the kind of movie people tell their friends about.
Relentlessly barreling between dive bombings, torpedo attacks and dogfights, the movie works your nerves. It's just one damn thing after another.
As sure-footed and satisfying an entertainment as I've seen so far this year. It's the kind of movie you can point to when people say they don't make 'em like they used to.
All that quiet is full of contemplation, as the film allows viewers room to bring their own baggage, time and space to meditate on how mortality one day comes for us all.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a movie obsessed with authorship, chock full of revisions and refinements as directed by a legendary tinkerer who never does know when to leave well enough alone.
A solid debut made with warmth and a cozy charm.
We watch with morbid fascination as Gere talks up, down, around and in circles trying to stave off the inevitable.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's two-thirds of a terrific picture, and I'm hard pressed to think of a recent movie I was enjoying so much that s**t the bed quite as spectacularly as this one does.
This isn't just one of the best movies of the year, it's one of the best movies ever made about rock 'n' roll.
movie_title: Long Strange Trip: The Untold Story of The Grateful Dead (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An icky, post-apocalyptic wallow that relies on gut-churning dread instead of traditional jump-scares. I hated it so much I didn't want to talk to anybody afterward and went for a long walk by myself.
Some movies feel like they're made by a committee, The Mummy feels like it was made by a conference call during which nobody was listening to one another.
You leave with a lot of questions, first and foremost being: Bruce Willis woke up for this?
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's got vision and atmosphere to burn, yet at the same time feels strangely hollow and incomplete.
Love him or hate him, there's nobody else making movies quite like this guy.
I found the movie's slick, shiny surfaces entertaining to a point but once again wish this frustrating filmmaker would go as deep as his debut.
Gina Gershon has the dirtiest smirk in movies and hardly ever gets a chance to use it.
The richest and most thorough cinematic exploration of an American ailment I fear may eventually be the end of us.
An exercise in diminishment. Feels like like one of the smallest and most inconsequential Marvel films yet.

Sofia Coppola's radical re-envisioning of Don Siegel's lurid 1971 Civil War melodrama works in the same way as Hendrix covering Dylan's "All Along the Watchtower" or Johnny Cash singing Nine Inch Nails' "Hurt."
Personally I found it all a bit distasteful and more than a little unpleasant. Cool shout-outs to "Schindler's List" though, bro.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As years rush by the ambitions grow increasingly more cosmic and grand. This little low-budget film begins to contain multitudes.
That the film feels like a ten-year-old directed it is both an accurate summation of its shortcomings and a high compliment indeed.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A welcome reminder that the most exciting works of art can come from somewhere elusive and instinctual, or they may just be about what it's like to live in Philadelphia.
It's a grand performance of toothy grins, aw-shucks charm and pure movie star magnetism. Barry's so much fun to watch you keep forgetting he's one of the bad guys.
A movie for people who miss the voice-over narration. It turns poetry into prose.
It's a film of constant, agonizing rejection, almost impossible to sit through but even harder to forget.
Here's the first 'Star Wars' movie since 'Empire' that you don't have to make excuses for enjoying.
The movie feels at odds with itself, chiding the audience for disrespecting Harding's underprivileged background while at the same time chock full of sight gags sniggering at poor people.
I'm pretty sure there's an audience for this film. But I'm even surer that I'm not part of that audience, given how much of the running time I spent groaning with my face buried in my hands.
The film luxuriates in the sun-kissed settings, languorous and largely devoid of conflict. It's an awfully nice movie, maybe even too nice?
Alexander Payne's softening over the years has been one of cinema's slow-motion tragedies.
There are a few days left before the movie opens, so maybe Ridley still has time to replace Wahlberg with Clive Owen, Michael Fassbender or anyone who might make sense in the role.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A dance between exhilarating escapades and unthinkable brutality, which though largely confined to offscreen spaces nonetheless lurks over the movie like a dark cloud.
It's breathless, a little goofy and an altogether grand old time at the movies.
It is a film that feels tantalizingly incomplete, missing just a few crucial pieces that you feel certain you're bound to catch the next time around.
This is a fiendishly funny movie, one that follows its own internal logic to a conclusion that makes perfect sense while being entirely mad. I laughed myself sick.
It's an expertly effective genre exercise that only occasionally feels like an exercise. A lot of the time it feels like an exorcism.
Mom Snd Dad really isn't much of a movie but it's a terrific delivery system for a bonkers Cage performance.
A pungent piece of social history, chronicling the early days of the ACT UP movement in Paris with bawdy humor, bottomless compassion and a rebel yell.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Jordan *hurts* in this movie. He aches in a way our bullet-proof, melancholy Prince could never begin to understand, lashing out at the very fantasy this comic book movie represents. This wonderfully messy film is actually angry at itself.
Mordantly funny and mercifully brief. It's a pleasure to watch these performers ping-ponging off one another.
Feels like one of those goofy old Star Trek episodes in which Kirk and Spock go back in time to make some sort of baldly allegorical point.
I'm not exactly sure what to make of this movie but I can't seem to shake it.

The most beautifully fluid of Fosse and Heim's collaborations, it's the raucous fantasia of a spectacularly horny man who can't stop drinking, drugging and screwing around, even when he's at death's door.
A terrific-looking movie photographed with intelligence and written in crayon.
'Lenny' is a lousy movie about a comedian but it's a great film about a toxic marriage.

Too fussy and dignified to embrace the material's romance novel absurdity.

Too full of busywork to ever get around to dramatizing the horror of being trapped, helpless and alone, which I thought was supposed to be the whole point.
The pleasure is in watching the straightforward, unfussy performances by two seasoned pros who know better than to push too hard.
